236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: Chamale
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed:
There are so many good things to put onto the battlefield with this creature.

Akroma, Angel of Wrath, Archangel of Strife or Iona, Shield of Emeria.

Demon of Death's Gate, Kuro, Pitlord or Pestilence Demon.

Dragon Tyrant, Bogardan Hellkite, or Vampiric Dragon.

Those are some of my favourites, but a Commander deck using this card wants lots of powerful Angels, Demons, and Dragons to put into play with Kaalia.

236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: Feralsymphony
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed:
Character Bio:
Kaalia of the Vast sits within her mountain chapel pondering both the heavenly host and the infernal horde, tormented by her past, scarred by devastation. Her once-simple life as a cleric was reduced to ashes when shadowy beings massacred her congregation. Somehow she survived, but her soul was fractured, and a growing hatred soon grew in the cracks. Now, driven by a righteous fury and an unholy thirst for revenge, Kaalia broods feverishly, amassing her vast power, waiting to unleash her apocalyptic might upon any who stand in her way.

The strategy with her: R.P.K.C. (Reanimate, Protect, Kill, Creatures)

Reanimate: Trust me, the kill spells will fly out of hands early and often. Reya Dawnbringer, Unburial Rites (so good, don't underestimate flashback), Torrent of Souls, Karmic Guide (now an angel!), and of course Phyrexian Reclamation are all fantastic options that you don't see in many current Kaalia decks.

Protect: I'll spare you the ton of ways to protect her, but two big ones are Emerge Unscathed, because it often leads to 3 protected attacks and Apostle's Blessing for the colorless quality. Of course equips can play in here as well, but I'm a fan of instant speed.

Kill: Get rid of the blockers and future attackers, duh. Phyrexian Purge has been a particularly awesome one for me, gets rid of the early board and its a good trade off even if you're getting rid of a mulldrifter. This deck attacks to work, get rid of things that will hurt you.

Creatures: Use creatures that give you flexible options OVER face-punching power. For instance, Hoard-Smelter Dragon is an absolute MUST for this deck, repeatable artifact destroy means screwing up opponents early game sol ring and signets, gets rid of annoying equipments & combos, and devestates Sharuum the Hegemon & Reaper King decks. Rune-Scarred Demon, Bloodgift Demon, Deathless angel all good examples of this principle and should be immediate adds as well.

TL;DR: The one card you weren't thinking about, and is just devastating with the Kaalia deck?

Fervent Charge

This is insanity on a stick in this deck. Tempered Steel for EVERY creature in the deck. And adding 2 toughness to Kaalia means she can get over the early flying blockers opponents will try too put down to respond to her.

236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: Etsap
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed: Just a rules note for the curious, when Kaalia puts a creature onto the battlefield, it does NOT trigger "When a creature attacks" abilities, because the creature wasn't on the battlefield at the beginning of the declare attackers step. It also doesn't have to pay for Propaganda effects. See Gemini Engine rulings for similar notes. This means Kaalia is amazing with Rakdos the Defiler, but not so good with Victory's Herald, Flameblast Dragon, or Mana-Charged Dragon.

236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: Zielheim
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed: I'll be honest, not a fan. EVERY time I've played her she was killed IMMEDIATELY, even with the Lightning Grieves that come in the decks. Not only that, but the deck is filled with so many big costing creatures, that some decks could just overrun you by the time you get them out. Ok, use Kaalia to get them out for free, I get it, but how can you get them out with her if they keep killing her before hand? The bullseye on her head is just way too big. Not only that, what if they have a creature with flying, reach, or just in general anti-flying permanents out? She's not strong enough to take down most of them, and if the whole point is for her to be swinging like a madman, she's going to end up dead more often than not. If I could change her ability, it'd be  "T: Put an Angel, Demon, or Dragon creature card from your hand onto the battlefield tapped and attacking. Only activate this ability during the declare attackers step, and only once during your turn." You get the same effect except instead she remains alive, and she even gets depowered some since if you have multiple combat steps, you can keep throwin' angels, demons, and dragons out (if you managed to get her to survive up to that point) but you can't do that anymore with this new one. Either that, or tap it to put one of the three down, it gains haste, and then you sac it at the end of turn. Or hell, give her regenerate. Not like it'd be out of color for white or black. Make it cost one of each, and there ya go, now she can swing into stuff and drop creatures without worry.

236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: DarthParallax
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed:
Timmy: (scribbles 'and', instead of 'or')

Johnny, Vorthos, Spike, and Melvin: O.O

Timmy: ^_^


But seriously, folks--

Kaalia needs lots of help, because she has a really awkward cost. (1 colorless is tres annoying when you're trying to understand 'what's so great about Sol Ring?' :p)

Thankfully, the colors are anything BUT awkward- really it's pretty disgusting:

You know how Commanders like Equipment? Stoneforge Mystic. You know how Commanders like Board Wipes? Read the colors. You get 'em all o.o
Ditto for Targeted killing if you want.
You know how Commanders like Card Draw? Necropotence, I hear, draws rather a lot of cards. Especially after a Congregate. Oh, and there's always Bob (Dark Confidant).

Anyone can search Gatherer for the 15 or so highest rated Angels, Demons, and Dragons. Spikes will probably settle what the 'best' ones to use are in fairly short order. I say go ahead and run your Serra Angels, Shivan Dragons, and Lords of the Pit, because frankly these colors are a match made IN Heaven, FOR Hell, ON Earth. Avatar of Slaughter is 'the wrong type' and fits disgustingly perfectly. The on-color Titans are good times too. The support cards for Red, White, and Black put together get you: Tons of Death, Tons of Reanimating, and Tons of Swingy Bombs in general. Hell Warp the World while you're at it.

The specific card choices matter the least because of the ludicrous redundancy in Magic in these three colors of EXACTLY the things you want to be doing. Compare to Blue and Green, which to me are colors that of course have their own power, but feel to me like the question of 'strictly better' or not matters MUCH more.

"Tinker Belle" just not enough? Need moar Tutoring? How about Demonic Tutor? And Bladewing the Risen? And Idyllic Tutor? Token Generators: Dragonmaster Outcast, Luminarch Ascension, Skirsdag High Priest. Just pick one for lawlz. You know how the best draw spell in the game is secretly BLACK, not Blue? (Contract From Below) Land Tax is WHITE, not Green.

I don't know how long it will take to maximize the build, but I foresee Kaalia eventually becoming the Ultimate Commander- Not because of Timmy- that color combination just says 'PAIN. LOTS AND LOTS OF PAIN.' to me.



EDIT: IGNORE THIS POST. Elbrus, the Binding Blade + Stoneforge Mystic.

Vorthos, Spike, Melvin, Timmy: 8O 0_________________________O that's....just....dumb. really really dumb.

Johnny: >:D >:D >:D >:D >:D >:D >:D >:D >:D

236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: BMK43
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed: Hey Guys- I'm a little underwhelmed here.  I do absolutely love Kaalia and her abilities but my problem is that she has to be attacking in order to put the additional creature out and in EDH with multiple players, attacking leaves one wide open for the next guy.  A simple damage or removal to Kaalia leaves her right back in the commander zone with the need for 2 more colorless to cast out again.  Hit her twice and she almost becomes prohibitive to get out and in the meanwhile my hand was filling up with huge currently uncastable demons,dragons and angels!  In the meanwhile, I was not fetching any smaller blockers and was left wide open and gutted.  I was in fact getting a bit mana hosed for about 4 turns which probably did me in overall but I feel like this deck relies too heavily on Kaalia and once shes down n out, the deck falters hard.  Which makes me question building edh decks around the commander's abilities. Commanders are easily wiped.  Whispersilk Cloak?  Sure with a 1 in 99 chance of coming out.  Not the answer.  However, I could in fact imagine a normal deck with 4 Kaalia etc etc...   Comments to help?  I really do love this deck to death but I'm a bit concerned.  Maybe further plays will turn things around...

236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: MANABURNWASGOOD
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed:
She's a very fun casual commander. I personally enjoy playing with her, but as was mentioned, she will always have a target on her. In my deck I run whispersilk, mask of avacyn, the boots, greaves, those equipments that will keep her around, but if you're playing her, you're going to be a target, and since people will have a tendency to run a lot of beef with her (myself included) she can be pretty slow at times, BUT, the colors, her colors are key, three of the best removal colors around. White can run disenchants, oblivion ring, wraths, swords to plowshares, and all of the other creature, artifact and enchantment removal that has. Then you have black for removal and search with the tutors and rune-scarred and the bloodgift, blood speaker, and pestilence demon are all fun. and then there's red for just mass destruction if need be, sneak attack can also help supplement getting that beef out.

Those are just the mono colored spells. Then you have to gold beauty Vindicate for B/W.

Yeah, she's a target, but if the deck is done right, there is a metric ton of stuff to help her survivability. Hell, let her go to the graveyard...living death, reanimate. So many possibilities.

Must I mention Rakdos, oh, and who won't be using the new Avacyn in a deck, combined with Iona...opponent = rage quit

236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: Trygon_Predator
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed: One of the most brutal Commanders. Kaalia, along with The Mimeoplasm, is one of those few that are immediate threats the moment they come roaring out of the command zone. You'd better be prepared to take her out as soon as she hits the battlefield, or be prepared to face the rising tide of Angels, Demons, and Dragons. And there are a lot - a lot - of them. Innistrad alone has given Kaalia such toys as Avacyn, Angel of Hope, Angelic Overseer, Griselbrand, Gisela, Blade of Goldnight, Balefire Dragon...

236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: ParallaxtheRevan
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed:
Night on Bald Mountain- by Mussorgsky + Through the Fire and Flames- by DragonForce + I Wish I Had An Angel- by Nightwish = Kaalia of the Vast. E. nuf. SAID!

And SERIOUSLY, WATCH THIS:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V92OBNsQgxU&feature=results_main&playnext=1&list=PL0BD11298BD17737A

Just skip to track 3.
Couldn't you SO imagine Kaalia singing with Tarja's voice :O
although I could see her playing the 'axe' like the Viking dudes too xD

And it's not just 'Creature-Angel' that makes some cards stand out as favorites for Kaalia, adrian. For example, creatures like Serra Angel, or creatures with lifelink, or first strike- i.e., anything remotely defensive.

You want hasty Dragons, DOUBLE striking Angels (because, for some unholy reason, they MAKE those now o.O) and Demons of Blasphemously Powerful Terror. If it looks like Avatar of Slaughter with Wings, put it in. If it looks like Jace, the Mind Sculptor with Wings, put it in. If it looks like Barney the Dinosaur with Wings, leave it out.

The only exception to the 'No Defense' rule is Indestructible. You should be Wrathing the Board every turn. Wraths should actually be like Nukes, and thus count as offense, not defense. I'm talking Cold War In Hell END OF THE WORLD levels of nuking. Wrath effects in a Kaalia deck should be like Targeted Removal effects in a Red Deck Wins deck. You should ALWAYS have one in hand or in play. Thanks to Griselbrand and Necropotence and Nicol Bolas knows WHAT else, there are enough exploitable effects either on creatures or ways to get your spells online that casting them shouldn't be an issue.

Oh yeah and I guess Griselbrand has lifelink. I suppose we can let him in. Maybe. He seems likely to do something bad (like EAT OUR SOUL) if we reject his application. :p

236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: KingRusty
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed:
Shooot, I don't even run her in commander, personally, I think I'd like to run something less easily removed, but she works wonders in 60-card decks.

Tutor Avacyn, Angel of Hope and play Kaalia (Use Dash Hopes to discourage removal)
Drop Avacyn next turn covering Kaalia and my army of vampires and angels attacking with her.
Smile wide and evil and laugh if it's total overkill.

Kaalia gives me Avacyn; Kaalia makes my day. :)

Barring giants like Worldspine Wurm though. The thing is, she's not overpowered when faced with casual decks that drop things like that as fast as you do. Elvish Piper is the green equivalent, if they need it given the massive mana ramp green has. (I say this because my brother uses it.) Kaalia won't always be available as you may not always draw her. Sure, she can be tutored, but I'd rather search Thought Hemorrhage and get rid of Elvish Piper or nuisances like Eldrazi Con***ion or Asceticism. The only reason I mention all this is because I often hear about how overpowered Kaalia is. Really not. Unless you're lucky enough to consistently draw her you really only have a .07% chance of drawing her; that's if you run 4.

In commander, she's a much bigger issue since she's always available and you wouldn't typically play her unless you had a big reason in your hand, but given any other player can just as easily pick something "overpowered" means Kaalia can be overcome. Take Phage the Untouchable for example, It That Betrays is particularly dirty. Nicol Bolas actually makes a terribly sadistic general. It all depends, but I'd like to point out Kaalia, no matter the format, isn't OP. She's just useful in decks that facilitate her stats and ability.

236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: blurrymadness
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed:
Put this up there with Doubling Season, Training Grounds, Painter's Servant, and Intruder Alarm for most referenced cards.

Aside from that, she just bugs my Timmy a bit because I've been making all kinds of Demon decks for years. Unplayable, huge, demons and decks filled with them all in the name of "These are so awesome!"; but this card makes stuff like that too easy. Hear me out..

To me; part of Timmy-ism is actually paying the huge mana cost. I can get a 9/9 for 3 mana off of a Titan Forge and Coretapper; but that doesn't feel even half as huge as the Sundering Titan to my Timmy. Getting a 6/4 wind-mill slammed Pit Spawn feels bigger and way more bad ass. Why? Because you paid huge mana for it. Timmy's don't want to Show and Tell or Kaalia in my experience; they want to ramp into a giant beast and smile smugly at the achievement of *casting* huge things. Anyone can get a 20/20 indestructible T3; but it's too easy. It's two cards. Timmy wants the cogs to work in a Rube Goldberg kinda way; building the suspense as this ramp into that ramp plops something unstoppable and big way too early.

I like to think that true Timmys would bypass this card and run Rakdos the Defiler as their general; suffering all of his drawbacks in the name of hardcasting and dealing with an oppressive creature. To feel like they're really wrangling with a demon that's crushing them as much as it's crushing you.

This is what I think Wizards doesn't understand. Lord of Riots is big; but he's too easy. Kaalia drops *big*; but it's free. There's no suffering or accomplishment when the card just says "Here's some fat." The accomplishment of putting down a fearsome creature with fearsome art and suffering all the bad things it wants to do to you is what makes it fun.

Apologies for the wall of text; but I'm passionate about my Demons.
(And golems.)

236473: Kaalia of the Vast.author: Three_Toe
236473: Kaalia of the Vast.text_parsed:
I am in favor of the notion that EDH should be casual and fun, but to those who dislike this card for that reason, I think you are misdirecting your frustration. People are competitive, cards are not. A Card is only as good as the other x in the deck make it. it is true that this commander doesn't leave a lot of room for creative deck-building, but it itself doesn't make a powerful, no-fun deck. I bought this very early in my EDH playing career, and I didn't own all the flashy Kaalia targets, so I was essentially using her for tempo, not ramp (similar, i know, but the difference is plopping down a serra angel with her turn 5 so I can use my 5 mana on other things, versus getting out iona, shield of emeria 100 turns early).

No one is saying you can't run casual cards. electropotence, magus of the moat, earthquake. No one's saying you have to run general tucks like chaos warp, terminus, or BS like Master of cruelties or sorin markov. So, in summation, hate the player not the game, son.

236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.text_parsed:
For the Political Puppets deck, he's the general best suited for duels, while Zedruu, The Greathearted is best for multiplayer.

And yes, just as Lorendorky suggested, slap either Vow of Lightning, Vow of Duty, or Vow of Flight, or ALL THREE, give him to a (newly made) buddy, and they'll have a 13/13 flyer with first strike and vigilance that mercilessly attacks everyone else but you.

He may not make you anything but enemies as a Commander, but as a gift, he's one of the best in the deck to give as a metaphorical treaty.

236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.author: SleetFox
236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.text_parsed:
I don't like the choices they made with this card. For starters, there's nothing blue about him. It can be argued that he's white because he's very fair. But nothing blue. Secondly, he was put in the deck as an "optional commander", and yet he's incredibly uninteresting as a commander that's virtually impossible to build around.

I like him as a card, though. He's very efficient in duels.

They should've made him cost WWRR instead and made Basandra the third WUR commander, giving her flash or shroud or something that'll justify her being blue (and making her less weak).
236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.text_posted:
I don't like the choices they made with this card.  For starters, there's nothing blue about him.  It can be argued that he's white because he's very fair.  But nothing blue.  Secondly, he was put in the deck as an "optional commander", and yet he's incredibly uninteresting as a commander that's virtually impossible to build around.

I like him as a card, though.  He's [i]very[/i] efficient in duels.

They should've made him cost WWRR instead and made [autocard]Basandra[/autocard] the third WUR commander, giving her flash or shroud or something that'll justify her being blue (and making her less weak).

I don't like him, completely mindless beatdown, doesn't belong in such a delicately interesting deck as Political Puppets. He should have been mono green, the colour of huge mindless beatdowncreatures.

So you're gonna switch to this guy as genral in 1on1's? So the rest of your deck is based on donating things while this beat down brute swings away? Sounds like a bad idea imo.

Don't like this at all, and there is nothing blue about him.

Character Bio:
Ruhan defies every rule, every expectation, every stricture meant to hold him. He was born blind, but chose a life of war. He was trained by famed Fomori swordmasters, but chose his own deadly great-mace. His elders form alliances, but his allegiance is to none but his own whim.

236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.author: Gheridarigaaz
236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.text_parsed: I'd say he's got a bit of blue in him, considering how you're meant to use some amount of trickery when building around him, think about it. If, say for instance, your "ally" runs a vow enchantment, and blue being the enchantment-transferring colour... or that either blue or white can cause him to "flicker" when he goes for someone you want to keep alive, maybe even play on those cheap turn gaining spells like stitch in time and savor the moment. Maybe its just the size that makes him blue. Yes of all colours blue has a tendency to have the largest creatures, e.g. ludevic's test subject, leviathan, jokulmorder... and now with illusions like phantasmal dragon i can really see why, being the undercosted creature that he is with a "downside" he could be blue

236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.author: brunsbr103
236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.text_parsed: Ruhan is my commander of choice for one of my favorite EDH decks. For the longest time I used Numot the Devastator, but I felt like a jerk destroying lands, and tbh in the deck he functioned about like a shivan dragon as my commander. I then switched to ruhan-and he is WAY better than I expected (and I thought he was good). The thing is, Ruhan forces out removal to make room for my actual threats. He is an amazing lightning rod that comes down two turns earlier than Numot! And if they don't answer to him he can start wreaking havoc and forcing my opponents to block, knocking out their utility creatures. Flavor wise, he does not feel blue, but in play I can see it.

236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.author: EvilDarkVoid
236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.text_parsed: Wouldn't giving your ally in a multiplayer game the vow be better than giving them Ruhan himself? That way you can still sacrifice Ruhan if you have any effects that require it, and they can't sacrifice it to their cards if they turn against you. It also allows you to use enchantment bounce or removal on the vow to let Ruhan hit them when you are no longer allies and prevents them from doing that to you.
236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.text_posted: Wouldn't giving your ally in a multiplayer game the vow be better than giving them Ruhan himself? 236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.author: Existential
236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.text_parsed: What is this card? A 7/7 for FOUR MANA!? It can be an early addition, and probably the most powerful thing on the field when it came about. But beyond meta flavour, it is an absolute beast. 7/7!? You need to attack each turn; it's continued presence implies its continued aggression, in fact, it is a fundamental part of it. You can't think of this without it being aggressive. It attacks a random opponent; they did what, exactly, to deserve this? The aggression may prove to be it's downside, in the end. Finally, there is a hint of diplomacy; if you're into EDH politics, you hedge a bet with each of the players, and for whoever does not get attack, it usually pays off. Related, having a grudge or an alliance with someone else is just not realistic; best just stick it our for yourself. Oh, and it is also the colours of the American flag...

236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.author: Madarakita
236477: Ruhan of the Fomori.text_parsed:
When I first made a deck with this guy, I looked into stuff like Gustcloak Savior, Reconnaissance or Maze of Ith.

Then I realized; this guy's an early game 7/7. I boost his power even a little, make him unblockable, and give him double strike, and he can easily hit the level of being able to take out opponents in a single swipe. Don't hold him back from attacking; just make sure he's damn near impossible to successfully block.

So now I use things like Steel of the Godhead, Battle Mastery, and Clout of the Dominus.

Those three alone make him an 11/11 lifelink shroud haste double strike that can't be blocked.

236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.author: caldur06
236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.text_parsed:
The art on this card is just amazing. I'm not normally one for interpreting all this, but I can't keep quiet about how fantastically this represents everything that is GU, BG, and UB. To her right is an orb of black, she herself is decked out in a leafy green, and to her right is an orb of blue. Her face is the security and self-assurance one expects of a creature that's both 4/4 and has deathtouch, and possess all the grace and intelligence one finds inherent in both B and U (and even the ferocity of G in her hair). Even down to her abilities- she doesn't cast a spell, she doesn't summon or enchant or trick things out- she just pushes you to your own natural limits: the power of the natural world at its darkest, at its best.

All three colors, the philosophy of G/B/U, the flavor of gorgons and wizards- it has it all. I hope to god they use this artist again- he is on the ball!

236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.author: Feralsymphony
236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.text_parsed:
Character Bio:
Thanks to their petrifying gaze, gorgons make few allies. But many seek out the gorgon sage Damia, whose breadth of magical knowledge rivals that of any archmage—and whose prices cut deep. Many have thought of forcing secrets out of her; her statuary is littered with the stone forms of those who've tried.

236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.text_parsed: Alright so I am deconstructing this deck. I ran into my first problem with it last night. I powered her out quick with a sol ring and a grim monolith. I had no way of drawing cards for the entirety of the game. my hand literally remained at 7 full of cards I was unable to cast for the rest of the game. they just took the damage because 4 is not all that threatening. I know this probably does not happen all that much but 1 time seems too many for me.

236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.author: Kitty_the_Kat
236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.text_parsed:
You don't wanna run this with a lot of fat spells, you want to be largely low in cost so its easier to dump portions of your hand before next turn to get maximum benefit of her draw, loading with 1-for-1 spells like Go For The Throat and Naturalize with low cost mana artifacts like Coalition Relic, and you wanna run some discard engines as well like Psychatog . Board control is also ideal for when you first get her out there, so your opponents don't just kill her.

One card I was looking at for late game hand suppression was Words of Waste, where you forgo your massive hand draw in favor of tapping down some mana and making your opponents discard large portions of their hands. You wouldn't need to do this often because they will soon be top-decking where you will still be getting large amounts of draw. And then if you really wanna be mean, combine this tactic with Geth's Grimoire, and maybe Consecrated Sphinx, to force them to dump anything they cannot immediately cast. Yes, people have threatened to kick my ass for using this strategy. :3

236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.author: DarthParallax
236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.text_parsed:
This card is in the same colors as Conundrum Sphinx and Necropotence. And there is probably a stupid broken Green draw spell I haven't memorized, but have heard of. Oath of Druids? Sylvan Library? One of those old wierd Green cards was pretty good at drawing, I thought for sure....


just in case any of you were unsure what you should be doing with this.
Funny thing: if it wasn't for Necropotence, I would say this card had roughly 0 Gorgon flavor beyond the art.

However, BECAUSE of Necropotence, I always associate 'skip your draw step' with 'you are about to do something so evil, it took the deaths of 1000 innocents just to find a DECODER to the MAP that led you to the KEY to the VAULT with the actual evil inside it. A large amount of death will ensue when you open that vault.

Also because of Necropotence, I assume that anything that says 'skip your draw step' causes your library to shit cards into your hand.

Oh, and Necropotence's art is like a Stone Skull. Really, this card owes half of it's essence to Necropotence. To not use Necropotence with this is to disrespect them both.

Necropotence. :)

236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.author: Diachronos
236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.text_parsed:
Surprised nobody's said this yet: Archmage Ascension.

Yes, it's a huge target for removal, but what enchantment isn't? And while it can be slow to get going in anything short of an "I draw cards" deck where the entire purpose of the deck is to draw cards, the fact that you can easily draw 2+ on each of your turns with Damia makes up for it.

Once the Ascension is active and Damia's on the field, you get to refill your hand with any cards you want at the start of your turn.

236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.author: LordRandomness
236479: Damia, Sage of Stone.text_parsed: I believe Damia to be the best Relentless Rats commander available. {G} for ramp, Bloodbond March, and assorted shenanigans such as Doubling Chant. {U} for protection and copying abilities. {B} for the rats, obviously. And a draw ability that lets you just dump rats, then dump more rats, then dump MORE RATS. Color fix is a bit of a pain, but as long as you don't want {B} on your opponent's turns and you don't want {U} on your turn it's probably manageable (Oh hey, there's the design rationale behind River of Tears!)

Color fix is a bit of a pain, but as long as you don't want {B} on your opponent's turns and you don't want {U} on your turn it's probably manageable (Oh hey, there's the design rationale behind [autocard]River of Tears[/autocard]!)

236485: Skullbriar, the Walking Grave.author: Ashrubel
236485: Skullbriar, the Walking Grave.text_parsed:
@ Verdant_Handshake: Neither of those are very good... That Which was Taken's counters have no intrinsic effect, they merely allow the permanent to be made indestructible by That Whic was Raen... If TWwT leaves play, those counters do nothing.

Sensei's Tokens do nothing a all, they just mark the creature, i is an added ability that gives it Bushido, Skullbriar leaves play and the counter does nothing at all.

The best combo's fo this involve things tha give it free counters, such as Ashnod's Transmogrant and any Graft abilities. (many of the best are in green). Remember, when Skullbriar leaves play he forgets what changes were done to him, such as permanently becoming an artifact, or gaining bushido. He only tracks counters, so anything that gives him extea counters = awesome. Too bad Gildet Bairn is blue...

236485: Skullbriar, the Walking Grave.author: WolfWhoWalks
236485: Skullbriar, the Walking Grave.text_parsed:
@A060Z: Nope. Skullbriar also keeps counters in the Command Zone, which was the whole purpose behind giving it this ability.

I ran a B/G zombie deck for a while with this guy as commander, and I really love the flavor, art, and feel of this card. However, high rating aside, if you're running this card against skilled opponents with good 1-drops, it can actually be quite hard to land a blow. In EDH especially, almost everyone has a chump blocker by the time Skullbriar swings. However, in early game aggro where opponents can't find a chump blocker, Skullbriar owns face.
236485: Skullbriar, the Walking Grave.text_posted:

236485: Skullbriar, the Walking Grave.author: SAUS3

@WolfWhoWalks
If you're playing in a multiplayer game, it is actually highly unlikely that every one of your opponents will have a blocker when it's your turn 2. Just poke the guy without a blocker until you can force bad trades from the other players.

I love this guy because he's a monster. Just keep poking and threatening the commander damage kill. If they board wipe, you just recast and swing through the empty battlefield.

5/5

236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.author: JaFaR_Ironclad
236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.text_parsed:
In commander: Vish Kal, Mikaeus, the Unhallowed for infinite LTB's/ETB's/targeted creature removal.

1. Have both cards in play.
2. sac Vish Kal to its own ability, let undying trigger resolve, he comes back with a +1/+1 counter.
3. Use Vish Kal's second ability to clear counters and hit a creature. If you've already wiped your opponent's boards by now, just debuff himself.
4. Repeat step 2-4.

236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.author: Dr.Pingas
236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.text_parsed:
I hate this guy; he's the perfect example of how Wizards didn't know what they were doing when it came to EDH/Commander. Anything, ANYTHING could have made him more balanced and less broken; pay 1-2 life to sac, say "sac another creature", tap to use his second ability, ANYTHING. As it stands, he's a Novablast Wurm that never has to worry about being targeted, with flying and lifelink - like they were necessary. I've seen huge cards rendered useless simply because he can just sac around them and then come back the next turn with all the B/W(/G) recursion.
You simply throw away your creatures, tokens, and all the stuff that you know you can get back, kill their flyers, and then pump him up to 21 and swing for the win. They try and even TOUCH him? You sac him to his own ability, and bring him back with Unburial Rights. The deck makes itself, and that is NOT the intention/goal of EDH AT ALL.

One note though, I'm not sure where people are getting the idea of -1/-1 counters. He gives them a direct -1/-1 to their stats, until end of turn; there are no counters besides the +1/+1 that he uses himself.

236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.author: Zielheim
236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.text_parsed:
I've got a messed up combo involving him, Rune-Scarred Demon , and Karador, Ghost Chieftain . Sac the demon, put 6 +1/+1 counters on Vish Kal, then bring the demon back with Karador and tutor any card out. Expensive, but it basically lets me spend one turn getting the card I need sooner instead of later, and it helps pump Vish for damage & life gain, plus a potential kill with it.

@Dr.Pingas
I wouldn't call Vish Kal broken or unbalanced. For one thing, while he CAN sac himself to his own ability, what real gain do you get out of it? You get to avoid certain exile spells, yay? If you use him as the general, sac'ing himself does you NO good since he'd go straight to the command zone again, even if you did want to avoid a Path or a Journey or O-ring. If you try to combo him with dead Mikaeus, the opponent is going to realize it very quickly and then just get rid of Mikaeus. Heck, his first ability is disadvantageous if the opponent has a kill spell ready for him of some sort since if you try to go for the kill with him, they're just going to nuke him when he swings. Not only that, but you have to get rid of ALL of his +1/+1 counters to give one creature that much in terms of -x/-x, meaning if they can come back from his swing, you're down quite a few creatures while they can chump and swing through Vish Kal and widdle you down until they get rid of him. Now, can he be a good card? Yes, but you also have to make sure your field is ready for him to go to town, one false step and you're screwed. Heck, even in my combo that I listed, it can be disrupted fairly easily if Karador gets taken out, or if I'm seriously lacking in revival spells.

236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.author: JohnnyDepth
236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.text_parsed:
The "removal-hate" general, lol. I "LOVE" being able to shuffle commanders in their owners' libraries, but can't do that with this guy. He'll just sac himself, and if the player's mana base is strong enough, they'll just bring him out again in a turn or two. Shoot, toss out a Debtor's Knell while you're at it and he'll return every turn if you can keep him in your graveyard, or will keep his tempo up 'cause you'll be able to sac the creatures you get and continue to pump him up. And since his abilities occur at instant speed without a tapping requirement, he can do this as quickly and as often as he's played.

I even tried devising how one could stop his abilities from activating, and I thought, "Well, Azorius Guildmage is the first thing that comes to mind." But if they've got any other creature with at least 2 power, they can sac THAT, add 2 counters to Vish Kal, then remove those, and simply kill the Guildmage before she can nullify his ability. So that means you have to provide either shroud or hexproof onto the Guildmage, or pay another 3 mana for each creature they can do that with. Gaaahh, what a headache.... >_<'

236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.author: SAUS3
236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.text_parsed:
@BongRipper
That's why he only has 1 white mana symbol in his cost, and 2 black symbols. He's more black than he is white. His white probably comes from his 'arbiter' title (a person who settles a dispute or has ultimate authority in a matter). He is kind of like a corrupt judge (his back story indicates so as well).
Check out this link for his back story: http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/stf/148

I use him as my EDH general in one of my strongest decks. Due to his low commitment to white, I run an almost mono-black style deck using things like cabal coffers and necropotence to fuel the deck. I use his lifelink as well as other sources to gain some of the life back that I spend on suicide black style draw cards. I get all the advantages of mono-black, but also get the power to destroy enchantments and artifacts easily.

Check out this link for his back story: http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/stf/148

I use him as my EDH general in one of my strongest decks. Due to his low commitment to white, I run an almost mono-black style deck using things like [autocard]cabal coffers[/autocard] and [autocard]necropotence[/autocard] to fuel the deck. I use his lifelink as well as other sources to gain some of the life back that I spend on suicide black style draw cards. I get all the advantages of mono-black, but also get the power to destroy enchantments and artifacts easily.

236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.author: Kamishini
236487: Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter.text_parsed:
Okay, I see a few people have said that he doesn't seem like a good commander, or a good card for that matter...

And I ask, are you noobs?

Sorry, that was rude, but seriously, Vish here is freakin' ridiculous. A 5/5 Lifelink, Flying itself is worth about five mana with a white and a black. now add his abilities...? Suddenly seven mana seems a little under-costed, really. He's a sac outlet, which lets you get around everything that exiles or sends to deck for creatures, and if you're playing black and white, you have TONS of recursion, so sacing something and having it come back in a turn or less isn't uncommon. That alone makes him awesome. And then you throw on an ability which gives him the possibility to destroying indestructible stuff?

And his abilities don't even cost mana! And activate at instant speed! As is, I personally think he's kinda broken, not that I mind, I love him as my B/W Samsara Commander.

236490: Basandra, Battle Seraph.author: scumbling1
236490: Basandra, Battle Seraph.text_parsed:
Shuts down Condemn, but you're playing Basandra -- you're playing Condemn yourself as you have white in your color identity. I just don't see this as being particularly useful. Removal normally cast during combat has to be used pre-emptively, but this seems to hurt white's removal more than any other colors.

As for her ability to force attacks, it's nothing special; red has several other cards that do that sort of thing.

The artwork is pretty, so it's probably best if you simply never look at the bottom half of the card.

236490: Basandra, Battle Seraph.author: GracefulInferno
236490: Basandra, Battle Seraph.text_parsed:
Using her as a general just changes how you handle combat. R/W is still very potent in combat when limited to activated/triggered abilities. Just change the types of spells you would normally use.

Can't run Condemn? Use Oust.

No Wing Shards? Try something that skips combat altogether, like Moment of Silence.

Sure, it's not as effective, since you're limiting yourself to second-rate white removal and such, but with Basandra as your general, the discord created by her abilities should at least work in your favor. Long story short: if her abilities turn you off, pick someone else. Commander is cool like that.

236490: Basandra, Battle Seraph.author: Zielheim
236490: Basandra, Battle Seraph.text_parsed:
If there's one reason why I like her so much, it's to prevent any kind of 'flash into play to wreck your board' shenanigans that can ruin your day, and it forces defending players to waste their fogs early and not leaving you wide open to attack. Her berserk ability is pretty good too for picking off particular threats when everyone's in a stalemate.

For those going 'but white/red love combat tricks themselves!', think of it this way; your opponent is inevitably going to want to get rid of her so they can do their own tricks, and in the mean time, you're forcing them to play by your rules and manipulating them in quite a few ways.

236490: Basandra, Battle Seraph.author: DarthParallax
236490: Basandra, Battle Seraph.text_parsed:
I COULD be wrong....but I think, actually, it might be perfectly alright to put in some combat tricks in a Basandra deck....noooo, you can't 'load up' on them a super ton...but just because one of your 100 cards is asynergystic with a good handful of cards that, in general, her colors like having, why would you not go for just the very best of them?

Fight to the Death and Master of Warcraft seem to me like they should still make the cut in a Basandra deck. Moreover, Commanders are not normal creatures. You have quite a lot of control over which Zone they are in at any given time, especially if you are playing White. (Only Black has more Zone control, I think).

I say an interesting move would be to see if you can find the right combination of 'trick' cards to 'flicker' Basandra in just such a way that you end up 'cracking' her ability and turning the drawback into a One-Sided affair. It's what the first Pros learned how to do with Wrath of God. there really aren't any creatures that are 'great with Wrath of God', but it's also pretty hard to win completely without creatures. So what you do is you work out your timing so you have Basandra when you want her, and not when you don't, just like you fire Wrath of God when you don't have creatures, then go ahead and cast them after the coast is clear.

236497: Avatar of Slaughter.author: Chamale
236497: Avatar of Slaughter.text_parsed:
Almost all of your opponents' creatures will be tapped out, leaving them unable to defend themselves, when this card is in play. In a red/white Commander deck, I'd think about putting in Otherworldly Journey on the off chance that I manage to knock out Avatar of Slaughter during an opponent's attack phase.

Reality Ripple or Vodalian Illusionist could cause Avatar of Slaughter to disappear until its controller's next untap phase.

In a red/white Commander deck, I'd think about putting in [autocard]Otherworldly Journey[/autocard] on the off chance that I manage to knock out Avatar of Slaughter during an opponent's attack phase.

[autocard]Reality Ripple[/autocard] or [autocard]Vodalian Illusionist[/autocard] could cause Avatar of Slaughter to disappear until its controller's next untap phase.

236497: Avatar of Slaughter.author: TheWrathofShane
236497: Avatar of Slaughter.text_parsed:
An 8/8 double strike that gives your army doublestrike for 8. That right there can end some games with a bit of help from haste.

It also forces your opponents to attack next turn. Drop this on your second main phase and keep your army untapped. Now everyone has to attack each other or they run into your well prepared army with a nice 8/8 avatar of slaughter guardian. And then when it is your turn again, besides fresh summons your opponents will be defenseless for the kill.

The major drawback is giving your opponents armys doublestrike. But Avatar of Slaughter should be able to rule the ground and deter most ground forces from coming at you, or risk being diced up. Pair this up with an efficient flyer and you should be golden.
236497: Avatar of Slaughter.text_posted:
An 8/8 double strike that gives your army doublestrike for 8. That right there can end some games with a bit of help from haste.

It also forces your opponents to attack next turn. Drop this on your second main phase and keep your army untapped. Now everyone has to attack each other or they run into your well prepared army with a nice 8/8 avatar of slaughter guardian. And then when it is your turn again, besides fresh summons your opponents will be defenseless for the kill.

The major drawback is giving your opponents armys doublestrike. But Avatar of Slaughter should be able to rule the ground and deter most ground forces from coming at you, or risk being diced up. Pair this up with an efficient flyer and you should be golden.

236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.author: Smauls
236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.text_parsed:
This and Homeward Path is crazy! I can't believe Political Puppets didn't include it in the original list..

You give away your walls for political/life/card advantage. Then if someone doesn't play along, you wait for them to be attacked. Once this happens, you TAP the Path to take all your walls back and they're screwed! You don't have to worry about retaliation because you have things like Ghostly Prison and if you added it, Norn's Annex, to potect you. Not to mention YOU HAVE ALL YOUR WALLS BACK!!

The path also helps if you get targeted by a kicked Gatkeeper of Malakir or the like. Just tap it to get your stuff back, sac something you didn't have anyway, and begin anew.

But Artscrafter is right, we need more offensive cards to give our opponents.

4/5 simply for it's Johnny appeal!!

236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.author: Atali
236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.text_parsed: If you just load up on giving your opponent things that they don't want, you'll just get Zedruu killed and never benefit from his first ability. It's political, give another player a blocker at a key junction and gain an ally. Attack, then give that creature to another player so they can attack with it as well, makes ganging up on someone better. Give someone control of one of your Vows so THEY can't be attacked. This is political manipulation, not little combos with Bronze Bombshell and the like (though that's really fun too =P).

236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.author: Feralsymphony
236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.text_parsed:
Character Bio:
Zedruu the Greathearted was born into a warrior family, lithe and combative like her father, but her path led her away from war. When she was young, a plague cursed her Erlundi people, leaving a wake of death. She learned painfully that not every fight can be won by the sword. In desperation, she offered her life in exchange for her people's, and thanks to her willing sacrifice, the curse was broken. Now she is revered among her people for her patience, benevolence, and hard-won wisdom.
236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.text_posted:
Character Bio:
Zedruu the Greathearted was born into a warrior family, lithe and combative like her father, but her path led her away from war. When she was young, a plague cursed her Erlundi people, leaving a wake of death. She learned painfully that not every fight can be won by the sword. In desperation, she offered her life in exchange for her people's, and thanks to her willing sacrifice, the curse was broken. Now she is revered among her people for her patience, benevolence, and hard-won wisdom.

236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.author: sonorhC
236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.text_parsed:
Jinxed Idol isn't the best choice, since it gives your opponent a way to get rid of any creatures you might want to give to them (like, say, Steel Golem). Or even just that Gilded Drake you used to steal their general-- It's probably doing you more good than them.

Another point, though: Obviously this is great for the cursed things you'd use with Donate or whatever, but let's not also forget that there are a lot of cards out there that don't really care who their controller is, including EDH staples like Arrest or Pithing Needle. Once you've cast these things, you might as well donate them the next time you have the mana to spare, to increase your lifegain and card advantage.

@Cyberium: This wouldn't work too well with the vows, though, since the "you" in "can't attack you" is the aura's controller.

236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.author: Mode
236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.text_parsed:
@caldur06: Maybe even "Zedruu the Goat-herded" ;)

But she indeed is greathearded: she shows that being generous improves your mental health and awareness :D

Being triple-colored i'd have liked her more without the colorless mana in the activation cost, but she has still a very interesting upkeep trigger nonetheless.

Confusion in the Ranks and Puca's Mischief are probably the most fun cards with this. The trick is to keep her on your side of the field then obviously...because let's face it, in the end we're not really that generous. At least not to our opponents :P

236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.author: alexanderwales218
236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.text_parsed: Having played this as my general for a bit ... the activation cost is too high to be really useful. It would have been much better if it were three colorless, or even just a tap effect (which it is on Bazaar Trader, a clearly not-too-powerful card). As it stands, you pretty much have to build the whole deck around giving things to people in other ways, because the cost for Zedruu is just too high unless you're abusing it like you would with Donate. So Zedruu doesn't really work that well, even if it is flavorful.

Dominus of Fealty
once per turn take control of a permanent an opponent controls, then use zedruu to give it to a different opponent permanently

I dont really like table talk, it undermines deck construction and internal strategy in my opinion, but im seriously thinking of making a zedruu edh deck for large multiplayer games.

236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.author: Lazrbeams
236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.text_parsed:
Once upon a time I was playing a 4 player edh match on octgn. One of the players was playing Nylea, God of the Hunt and had out a primalcrux, a Khalni Hydra, a Terra Stomper and a bunch of other scary but less notable stuff. All I had was a Celestial Dawn a Phyrexian Metamorph'd Primalcrux, and zedruu with around 3 donated cards floating around. Obviously his board position was scary, I had a choice, lock him with a celestial dawn, or lose (he was gunning for me because of a previous game) so I donated celestial dawn to him, and slapped down Solitary Confinement to stop the inevitable onslaught of hate. He didn't understand how celestial dawn prevents you from generating colored mana if you're not playing white. Once he figured it out, he got ***ed, really ***ed. He started attacking me despite the fact that it did nothing, then he made about 100 copies of celestial dawn, spelled the F word with them, dragged them over my board, passed control to me, and left the game. We couldn't finish the game because I couldn't use anything on my board. It was so funny though, and I will forever love zedruu for that moment alone.
It also pretty much made me stop playing EDH, too many people who play it can't handle control or locks, and freak out like babies. It sucks, because it's a fun format, but people like that just ruin the game for me.
(Sorry about the lack of autocard, on my phone)

236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.author: Syrtees
236499: Zedruu the Greathearted.text_parsed: @TwentyFifthBaam Fun fact! Saving someone with Lich's Mirror when they're losing as a result of commander damage causes the mirror to FOLD TIME AND SPACE IN ON ITSELF and end the entire game in a draw. This is due to the nature of commander damage functioning similar to poison counters, two things that the mirror cannot get rid of. Therefore the game initiates an infinite loop which ends in a draw. That's right! Your hugs deck does indeed have a way to end the game.

236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.author: ClockworkSwordfish
236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_parsed:
He's tailor-made for EDH, and it shows. He is very, very good but does not seem broken in the format, like Animar does. He was clearly designed as a build-around card, but the good part is that what you can build around him is not so well-defined. You can run the token-deck route, the +1/+1 counter route, the heavy sacrifice/death trigger route, and probably a few others. Let's start by listing cards he is ridiculous with:
Sigil Captain: All the Saprolings you can pay for and subsequently huge creatures.
Juniper Order Ranger: Al the Saprolings you can pay for, and no sacrificing before you get a huge creature
Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter: Decent since you can pay to kill something with toughness X or less, Vish himself gets huge for cheap, nuts with Juniper Order Ranger and/or Sigil Captain. Potentially -4/-4 for if you've got both.
Skullclamp/Fecundity: Hahahaha. Hahahaha! HAHAHAHAHAHAHA! BAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA!!!
Aura Shards: No one has artifacts/enchantments. EVER
Grave Pact/Martyr's Bond/: No one has creatures. EVER. Also Ghave Pact
Algae Gharial/Scavenger Drake: Become huge.
Forgotten Ancient/Mold Adder: Every spell anyone casts becomes a Saproling/counter.
Phytohydra: Always awesome, here SYNERGISTICALLY awesome.
Nemata, Grove Guardian/Pallid Mycoderm: Attack with everything, sac whatever they block. Win.
Protean Hydra: The way it is worded makes it clear that this guy was meant to be with Ghave.
Psychotrope Thallid/Skullmulcher: Draw your deck. Win.
Any enters/leaves battlefield triggers.

Awesome abilities, a solid and efficient body, a kickass backstory (seriously, look it up. I lol'd), incredible versatility, and great deckbuilding opportunites make Ghave a true general. 5/5. Wizards, you did it.

[autocard]Skullclamp[/autocard]/[autocard]Fecundity[/autocard]: Hahahaha. Hahahaha! HAHAHAHAHAHAHA! BAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA!!!
[autocard]Aura Shards[/autocard]: No one has artifacts/enchantments. EVER
[autocard]Grave Pact[/autocard]/[autocard]Martyr's Bond[/autocard]/: No one has creatures. EVER. Also Ghave Pact
[autocard]Algae Gharial[/autocard]/[autocard]Scavenger Drake[/autocard]: Become huge.
[autocard]Forgotten Ancient[/autocard]/[autocard]Mold Adder[/autocard]: Every spell anyone casts becomes a Saproling/counter.
[autocard]Phytohydra[/autocard]: Always awesome, here SYNERGISTICALLY awesome.
[autocard]Nemata, Grove Guardian[/autocard]/[autocard]Pallid Mycoderm[/autocard]: Attack with everything, sac whatever they block. Win.
[autocard]Protean Hydra[/autocard]: The way it is worded makes it clear that this guy was meant to be with Ghave.
[autocard]Psychotrope Thallid[/autocard]/[autocard]Skullmulcher[/autocard]: Draw your deck. Win.
Any enters/leaves battlefield triggers.

Awesome abilities, a solid and efficient body, a kickass backstory (seriously, look it up. I lol'd), incredible versatility, and great deckbuilding opportunites make Ghave a true general. 5/5. Wizards, you did it.

236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.author: Feralsymphony
236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_parsed:
Character Bio:
When monsoons devastated the land of Drakkus, the herds drowned and the harvests washed away. The humans there were forced to the fungal forests to find sustenance, and find it they did—in the form of the mycoids and their saproling offspring. What the humans saw as salvation, the mycoids called genocide, and they declared war on the invading mammals. Mages tore through the sporeborn troops with fire and steel. Only when the mycoid hero Ghave, Guru of Spores emerged did the tide finally turn. Gifted with mystic influence over the sporeborn, Ghave sculpted the fungal matter of his people into an ever-mutating army and reclaimed his forest home.

236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.author: Ertai23
236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_parsed:
To all people who don't see why this is three colours, I think I've got it figured out:

He's Green, White and Black.

He comes into play with five +1/+1 counters. This makes him big and symbolises growth. Which is green.

He can remove counters from some creatures to create others. Those creatures sacrifice personal strength to contribute to the community, or the greater good. Which is white.

He can sacrifice creatures to add to the strength of others. Which is black.

236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.author: ICEFANG13
236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_parsed:
I agree with GrimjawxRULES, if it said spore counters instead of +1/+1 counters it would be much cooler (although probably broken in its current state)

Good yes, but not fungus cool/not really good with fungus decks, I am disappoint. All he can do is buff up your fungus, when I from my own personal experiences hate losing saps for any reason other than fungus abilities or protecting myself.

If I added him to my fungus deck, or as an EDH commander in my EDH fungus deck,

Ability one: completely worthless, other than himself, so what? He is 10 mana into 5 Saprolings? Lame

Ability two: I can sack fungus, which is bad, they do more work the longer they are on the field, turning one into a 2 mana Saproling isn't a good investment, I'm probably losing if I have to do that. I could buff fungus or other Saprolings, but when they start at 1 power... there is a reason it's called Sprout Swarm. Usually its better to have 5 1/1 Saprolings than 1 5/5 Saproling in a fungus deck. It can recycle Saprolings however, making for 2 mana (or 1 and later 1) chump blockers. That is really really good.

As is stands, I can only think of 2 creatures it works with that are also fungal

Mycoloth- If you have read a few other comments of mine, you may know I play with a Time Spiral Standard (TS, Ravinca, and 10th) deck, he can't be in there. When I first made it though, it was extended (had some Alara/Zen too) and he was in there. You may also know that I greatly dislike Mycoloth for fungus decks. Why do you say that? Well, it was like a crutch, I would win every game using Diabolic Tutor and finding him, making a huge unfair army of flying indestructible 2/2s. All the other fungus existed to feed him. It was way too easy to win with a 130 card deck (I started with all the cards I wanted to try and trimmed it down to 60 over time, but at that time, 130 was still winning every game). Basically, Mycoloth would win every game, no contest, and the other fungus wouldn't do crap (other than feed him). Other than no one wanting to play me, when I win every game, its boring and stupid to have a one combo deck thing going. I win same way, next game, I win again, I have the will of the warrior.

However, Mycoloth is extremely fair in non-standard, but when your friends play standard, welllll you get my picture I hope. I like to win, but only with a deck I love, and he wasn't in there because I didn't love him, I ruv all my fungal friends!

There is also Fungal Behemoth, which I have never used (its really like ability 1, it's not that good in a fungus deck, especially mine, which had low mana costs). Fungal Behemoth would work well with this card, but not other fungus...

Ok, sorry Ghave, Guru of Spores, not happening for my fungus deck, not worth the mana, not worth the colors (I play B/G), Thelon of Havenwood is still my man (and EDH commander)

Now, when he's not in a fungus deck, more like a saproling deck, token deck. He is really good. There are many combos to abuse his abilities in the commander set here. So easily a 5/5 for goodness, but I was really hoping for a cool fungus commander.

Please don't say he combos with Doubling Season I have 2 in my fungus deck, and yes he 'combos' with Doubling Season, however, we can all read

236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.author: cranial.distraction
236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_parsed:
Sigil Captain or Juniper Order Ranger + Ashnod's Altar.

1) Tap a land for . Pull a +1/+1 counter off of Ghave to create a 1/1 saproling using Ghave's first activated ability. Saproling comes into play with an additional +1/+1 counter thanks to Sigil Captain or Ranger.

2) Tap a land, pull that +1/+1 counter off of saproling to create another saproling using Ghave's first activated ability. That saproling also comes into play with a +1/+1 counter on it because of Captain or Ranger.

3) Sacrifce the first saproling to Ashnod's Altar to add to your mana pool.

4) Return to step 1. Repeat until somebody reaches across the table and smacks you.
236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_posted:
[autocard]Sigil Captain[/autocard] or [autocard]Juniper Order Ranger[/autocard] + [autocard]Ashnod's Altar[/autocard].

2) Tap a land, pull that +1/+1 counter off of saproling to create another saproling using Ghave's first activated ability. That saproling also comes into play with a +1/+1 counter on it because of Captain or Ranger.

3) Sacrifce the first saproling to Ashnod's Altar to add [2] to your mana pool.

4) Return to step 1. Repeat until somebody reaches across the table and smacks you.

236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.author: Zielheim
236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_parsed:
@4wolf359

Actually, you can't. Summoning sickness. Life and Limb makes the saprolings into forests, yes, but they're still creatures, they still suffer from summoning sickness.

I'll admit, I did not like Ghave at first. I thought he was so much inferior to Karador that it wasn't even funny. Then I realized that with the way I have my deck set up, I need instant-speed sac engines, and Ghave actually delivers, AND provides some form of pump at the same time, which means some of my other creatures can hit harder. Ghave, alongside the other five sac'ers, allows my deck to get more creatures into my grave for the recursion effects to properly go off (as well as allow last-minute sac's to get Karador out for cheap on my turn).

236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.author: endersblade
236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_parsed:
This guy just replaced Savra, Queen of the Golgari as the general of my Saproling EDH deck. (Sorry, I refuse to call it Commander.) This allowed me to splash in white. All you naysayers seem to forget how EASY it is to get a stupid amount of +1/+1 counters on your creatures, Mycoloth not withstanding. Juniper Order Ranger and the ultimate powerhouse, Primordial Hydra. The Hydra will start making more +1/+1 counters per turn than you are capable of using!

Also, since I was able to add in Rhys the Redeemed, the shenanigans have just gotten even worse. As long as you have a reliable untap ability, like Patron of the Orochi and Seedborn Muse, Rhys can double your saprolings on EVERY PLAYER'S TURN. With Juniper Order Ranger in play, as well as an excellent mana source like Gaea's Cradle, you can make a massive army in little time at all. Use a card like Psychotrope Thallid to make use of all your newly grown saps.

This guy just replaced [autocard]Savra, Queen of the Golgari[/autocard] as the general of my Saproling EDH deck.  (Sorry, I refuse to call it Commander.)  This allowed me to splash in white.  All you naysayers seem to forget how EASY it is to get a stupid amount of +1/+1 counters on your creatures, [autocard]Mycoloth[/autocard] not withstanding.  [autocard]Juniper Order Ranger[/autocard] and the ultimate powerhouse, [autocard]Primordial Hydra[/autocard].  The Hydra will start making more +1/+1 counters per turn than you are capable of using!

Also, since I was able to add in [autocard]Rhys the Redeemed[/autocard], the shenanigans have just gotten even worse.  As long as you have a reliable untap ability, like [autocard]Patron of the Orochi[/autocard] and [autocard]Seedborn Muse[/autocard], Rhys can double your saprolings on EVERY PLAYER'S TURN.  With [autocard]Juniper Order Ranger[/autocard] in play, as well as an excellent mana source like [autocard]Gaea's Cradle[/autocard], you can make a massive army in little time at all.  Use a card like [autocard]Psychotrope Thallid[/autocard] to make use of all your newly grown saps.

236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_parsed:
Eeyup... This guy here has made my playgroup play a biiiiit more carefully..
BECAUSE I AM THE COMBO NOODLER!!!!!!!!!
Ghave + Utopia Mycon/Phyrexian Altar/Ashnod's Altar + Doubling Season/Parallel Lives + Lumberknot/Champion of Lambholt/Cathar's Crusade/Mortician Beetle/Sigil Captain = Infinite mana, infinite counters.
And what do I do with that?
Well...
Mentor of the Meek/Psychotrope Thallid/Skullclamp: Draw my deck
Soul Warden: Gain ALL of the life
Aura Shards/Butcher of Malakir/Spike Tiller: Empty the field of everything and ask if they'd like to scoop
(in my defence, I only did that once and swore never to do so again... ya know, mad with power :)

Thoughtpicker Witch/Extractor Demon: Mill out, they lose come their draw step
Blasting Station/Triskelion: Death of a thousand stings!

I love going infinite, and all teh ridiculous power that comes with it!
OH! also, because why not, Fertilid + Skullclamp. Give every player all the land he can get, then I kill myself to watch em fight it out :)

236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.author: Quantumbiologist
236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_parsed: Going is infinite is one thing, making busted 2 card combos is slightly better since its more consistant. Not saying going infinite is not doable just seems easier fetching a single card and abusing the synergy out of it than setting up a 3 card combo which is a tad fragile. Ivy Lane Denizen means for 1 mana you produce a 1/1 without loss. My personal favorite is comboing with Vhati il-Dal - they attack, you spam a 1/1 and make the attacking creature a toughness of 1 and just chump... not even just vhati and Deathspore Thallid. The trick with Ghave is not only to include cards that combo with it but make sure those cards can combo with each other.

236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.author: 4wolf359
236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_parsed: How has no one caught onto incorporating proliferate with this guy? The wording states "choose any number of target permanents or players with counters on them." All of your creatures can be targets for proliferation. It doesn't even limit the kind of counters-- +1/+1, fungus, infect counters on your opponents/ their creatures, whatever. Contagion Engine becomes both offensive and defensive, and it grows your army exponentially.

Moral of the Story: We need more saproling lords.

236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.author: creepycrawler
236501: Ghave, Guru of Spores.text_parsed:
Scavenger Drake looks like it'll be fun with this. Sacrifice a saproling to give him a +1/+1 counter, he gets another +1/+1 counter, remove the counters for saprolings and sacrifice again...etc. Protean Hydra is another good one.

I like seeing just how I can convert other things into saprolings and saprolings into other things with this guy as general.

-Unspeakable Symbol / Souldrinker : Life into saprolings
-Nature's Blessing : Discard into saprolings
-Scavenging Ooze (Necrogenesis doesn't need Ghave): Graveyard into saprolings
-Triskelion : Saprolings into damage
-Fertilid : Saprolings into lands (which, with Life and Limb out, can be saprolings again)
-Death's Presence : Besides being insane with Ghave, converts dead creatures into saprolings. And with Utopia Mycon and Suture Priest also in play, you've got infinite lifegain.

236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.author: InfernalIncinerator
236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.text_parsed:
Out of the entire set, this is the general I wanted most until I saw he came with Riku, then I just about crapped my pants.
These 2 generals combo in SO many ways, even though Riku will likely see more action as the general, this can be a prime substitute if you build your deck right.
As for him alone and his abilities, I saw the protection and thought AWESOME, he has some means of unblockability for general damage which is just priceless.
Then I saw how he grows whenever you play creatures, this makes him a HUGE target whenever you play him, even with his protection, there are ways to get rid of him.
Finally on to how he is actually a general position creature, he makes every other creature you could possibly cast cost less for how many creatures you have already played after him, that is the foundation of commanding an army, use their strengths to make the others strong.
All in all, I would love to rate this over 5 stars, but I am only limited to 5. And on one final note, use with with artifact creatures or the eldrazi to make them free since they are colorless in the first place.

236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.author: Leonidus78
236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.text_parsed: If I'm not mistaken, Palinchron infinitely combos with both animar and riku. Making him almost a staple in the Mirror Mastery commander deck. Once animar has enough counters you can cast and bounce plainchron back forth as many times as you want. And when you play one with riku, I think you can play it copy it then bounce it before the next comes in and then play him again. So it depends whether you want infinite 4/5 flyers or infinite 4/5 flyers with a infinitely big animar staring them down too. Right now I'm trying to build a deck that can utilize both riku and animar as a commander so when I whip out animar and people start cringing and glaring at me I will whip out riku. (which may still cause some ager as well.)

236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.author: ForestFire0
236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.text_parsed:
@Wanderer25: Note that Stingscourger limits his bounce ability to a creature one of your opponents controls, so he couldn't be used in this scenario. I've found that Shrieking Drake has been the best card in my Animar deck and the one I most often tutor for.

I wouldn't rate Animar on the same level as Zur, Azami, Momir Vig, or Sharuum. If he is killed early, before he gets big, he loses a lot of his bite. A Wrath of God is particularly devastating for Animar decks. Zur decks keep their enchantments, Azami still will have a handful of cards, Momir Vig will still have the combo pieces in hand, and Sharuum will only be played when it will start the infinite loop. That said, Animar still can explode quickly if he can last a turn on the board late game with a hand of cards.

236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.author: endersblade
236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.text_parsed:
@LordofAwesome33

That card is exactly why I run Shattering Pulse, Shatterstorm, and Shattering Spree in all of my red-based EDH decks. People always find some stupid awesome way to break that card...and then I break it even harder, into their graveyard.

Animar is indeed an amazing general. I wouldn't say best; that's kind of up to the people running it, and the people playing against it. You make a crappy deck with him in it, it's still a crappy deck.

Alluren is definitely a good card to run with him. After you get around 5 counters on him, basically everything is free to cast. His colors also open you into a whole slew of infinite combos; for damage, for creatures, and to feed the other two.
236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.text_posted:
@LordofAwesome33

People always find some stupid awesome way to break that card...and then I break it even harder, into their graveyard.

Animar is indeed an amazing general.  I wouldn't say best; that's kind of up to the people running it, and the people playing against it.  You make a crappy deck with him in it, it's still a crappy deck.

Alluren is definitely a good card to run with him.  After you get around 5 counters on him, basically everything is free to cast.  His colors also open you into a whole slew of infinite combos; [R] for damage, [G] for creatures, and [U] to feed the other two.

236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.author: Wanderer25
236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.text_parsed:
Future Sight / Magus of the Future + Cream of the Crop. If you build your deck properly and Animar has enough counters on him, this can simply spew creatures out into play. Just be sure you have something that gives haste, like Fires of Yavimaya.

Aluren + Man-o'-War + Stingscourger can make him infinitely large... and if you have Tidespout Tyrant out, it will bounce all of your opponents permanents as well. Or just kill everyone right then with Furious Assault.

This guy has to be one of the top three strongest, if not the strongest, of the Commander legends. I can't say he'll be the most fun to play with or against, though... he makes for an extremely versatile deck that can be explosively aggressive but can also win through a combo late in the game.

I honestly expect that this will, unfortunately, be one of those generals that makes you a target through reputation alone, rather like Zur, Azami, Vig, and Sharuum...

@ForestFire - Ah, you're right about Stingscourger. Don't know how I missed that. I'm honestly not so sure about his power level any more, as I've yet to see an Animar deck in my playgroup.

236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.author: kenethare
236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.text_parsed:
This guy is my Commander League general. I originally built him because my casual group was hating my Damia, Sage of Stone deck (for good reason, control decks are annoying). Animar looked like a fun casual deck so I put together a basic one out of the precon and some cards I had that fit. I focused on Primordial Sage and it quickly became clear that with some development he would be a very powerful deck. My casual group ended up stating that Animar was stronger than Damia and I had not put major development into Animar yet. So I started developing Animar into a stronger deck to transfer it to being my league deck and I built a new casual deck.

After a bit of work I got http://tappedout.net/mtg-decks/animar-soul-of-elements-edh-2/ which came out really well. I am really liking Animar as a general and the deck itself. It has a lot of exciting lines of play, alot of depth, it requires attention to detail and trigger orientation. Overall it is very interesting and fun deck to play with that can be anything from incredibly casual (I board out some combos and put in a Laboratory Maniac for casual and try to draw my deck) to very competitive.

A note to people looking to play Animar on line with Nick30075's compliant: Make sure to not miss triggers, and if you do miss it then it didn't happen, you don't get to go back and put counters on things later. I fortunately enough had played Soul Sisters in standard for a couple years so I was used to moving dice around every time I played something. It takes a bit of paying attention but it makes for a better play experience for everyone if you do things a bit slower but more accurately.

Funny note: after about turn 7-8 I find it difficult to spend the mana from sol ring on anything....

236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.author: DeathbyCoffee
236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.text_parsed:
I got out Mindshrieker, Garruk's Horde,Vorinclex, Voice of Hunger, and Joiner Adept once. All of this happened AFTER we had Collective Voyage for pretty much every land in my deck.
Garruk's horde let me cast all my creatures from the top of my deck, and when the top card wasn't a creature (or when the top card was Anger) it was milled by Mindshriek. I pretty much played every creature in my deck, and then swung for lethal at 2 other players.
It felt pretty radical.

236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.author: Kragash
236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.text_parsed:
All of you saying he combos with Riku are wrong. Animar checks if you've casted a creature. Casting a spell that puts a token copy of a creature you casted does not result in putting two +1/+1 counters on Animar.

You'll have an easier time upping the counters on Animar with sorceries, creatures, and artifacts that proliferate.

236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.author: SnackyNorph
236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.text_parsed:
EDH shenanigans with this guy as your general!
Step 1) Have Vigor; make him indestructible.
Step 2) Have Animar, Soul of Elements.
Step 3) Cast Blasphemous Act; this will place 13 +1/+1 counters on Animar.
Step 4) Cast any fatty Eldrazi (Emrakul, the Aeons Torn if you don't care about EDH legality; Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre or It That Betrays if you do) for free.
Step 5) Win, presumably.

236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.author: Three_Toe
236504: Animar, Soul of Elements.text_parsed: Well good, I was waiting for a chance to run my foil copy of hamletback goliath! I went with Hydras and other X-cost creatures work well since they are never a dead draw (primordial hydra, vastwood hydra, etc.). Creatures with graft help him out as well (sporeback troll). The Theros block has been kind to Animar, with the gods and archetype cycles (Xenagos, god of revels,archetype of aggression, etc.). Big colorless guys are good cause they eventually become free, wheel of fortune/jace's archivist is a deathblow after you've just pooped out a handful of creatures... nullstone gargoyle, Garruk's Horde, Urabrask the Hidden, Steel Hellkite, Soul of the Harvest, Sages of the Anima, Kalonian Hydra, Beguiler of Wills, draining whelk, Prophet of Kruphix, Fauna Shaman, the list never ends. Just think, "What do I need, and how do I do it with a creature?"

This one is so much drastically worse than the others that it should NOT have been printed as is. This is just terrible, even without comparing it to your other options in white. THe others ALL make sense- you buff their guy, he attacks your friends instead, they get hurt, the creature cant ever attack you so if they want to attack with it it now cannot block your guys. Elegant card design. This is just awkward, as they can still always block your attackers with their guy when you were trying to play this card as 'REMOVAL' for their guy... ughhh wizards dont make cards into cycles if some are gonna be just bad.. :/
imo blue and green are awesome, red and black are fine, i just think it shoudl've been a 4 color cycle.

236986: Vow of Duty.author: Smauls
236986: Vow of Duty.text_parsed:
I see this as more of a political card than a win card. If one of your opponents has poor defense, offer to Vow of Duty one of their creatures for an extra trade off (this way they can attack and still be able to block; not to mention the +2/+2 boost). If they accept, you're ahead for two reasons:

1) This Vow'd creature cannot attack you or your Planeswalkers.
2) Whatever else you just agreed to. (say they agreed to rid the board of a certain artifact for you).

Granted, every card can be played politicaly - I get that - but this card in particular offers a lot to players in need. I'm sure you can get some pretty good deals out of this one.

3.5/5

236995: Tariel, Reckoner of Souls.author: sarroth
236995: Tariel, Reckoner of Souls.text_parsed:
It shouldn't surprise me that Tariel's only really gotten bad comments so far. Most people don't like random. I feel the random part makes this card more exciting than it otherwise would have been. Random really is a love-it-or-hate-it concept in this game. I don't feel it's that bad, as you get to choose the player, so you already know what your possibilities are.

Add to Splizer's Void Maw the list of Cemetery Reaper, Nezumi Graverobber, Withered Wretch, and Rag Dealer. If you want to make her work, you can.

I do agree that the mana cost is high. Should we expect anything less, though? She's an Angel. At cheapest we would've seen {2}{W}{B}{R}.
