247202: Call the Skybreaker.author: leomistico
247202: Call the Skybreaker.text_parsed:
@SliverApocalypse: You're quite right, buy you don't see a huge (at least a 4/4, for me) flying creature that regenerates. In Modern I can see only Hellkite Overlord and Skithiryx, the Blight Dragon... However, this isn't exactly a regenerate creature: a standard creature can be exiled (with Path to Exile, fo example), or destroyed without being able to regenerate (with Putrefy, for example...). Note that even an indestructible creature can be removed in quite few ways, and even if there are indestructible flying creatures out there, there is always a little effort to make them work...

In order to deal with this you have to destroy the creature AND remove the sorcery from the graveyard, so it's almost a 2x1 alone, even before starting to retrace it... So I think this has a build-in recursion that shouldn't be understimated. I like retrace so much, hope to see it again!

Obviously it's not a tournament worth card (maybe in a very rouge deck), but for casual is a great choise, for me... I like it very much, and I give it a 4/5 (previously I gave it a 4.5/5, but it's a bit too much), but I don't think that it deserves less than 3/5...

247203: Desecrator Hag.author: TappTapp
247203: Desecrator Hag.text_parsed:
Like most people, I tended to overlook this particular hag and compare it to Gravedigger or Cadaver Imp, until one day I built an Omniscience deck.
I wanted a combo win, and the deck was already running Bloodthrone Vampire and Blood Artist, so I chucked in a single Gravedigger, figuring I could cast him, sacrifice him to bloodthrone, retrieve him with his own ability, and play him again for free with omniscience. Only when I tried this did I learn that I had to pick the target of his ETB ability before I had the chance to feed him to bloodthrone.
Not with the hag!
Since the hag doesn't target, you can sacrifice her immediately as she enters the battlefield, then retrieve her with her own ability (assuming there's nothing above 2 power in your yard), meaning I don't have to bother with 2 gravediggers for my combo.
Not something that comes up all the time, but it's good to know there's at least one scenario where the hag beats the professional.

247204: Dominus of Fealty.author: Amnesigenic
247204: Dominus of Fealty.text_parsed: @Leonin_Kha_Cameron: Actually, Zedruu says you can give control to target opponent, whereas Bazaar trader is target player. Being able to keep something for yourself is nice, but giving one opponent's best creature to another opponent to keep is a pretty useful political move. 247204: Dominus of Fealty.author: EvilDarkVoid
247204: Dominus of Fealty.text_parsed:
Time Vault + Donate / Zedruu the Greathearted / Bazaar Trader.

Give Time Vault to your opponent, then during your next upkeep take it back and untap it. Tap it to get the extra turn. At the end of the first turn it goes back to your opponent's control (I think? If it doesn't then give it back with Zedruu or Trader some time during that turn) and then at the start of the extra turn take it back, untap it again, and repeat. You win.
247204: Dominus of Fealty.text_posted:

247204: Dominus of Fealty.author: JarieSuicune
247204: Dominus of Fealty.text_parsed:
I hope I'm not the only person who first only saw the image and assumed that Dominous was female... until finally read the flavor text.

Time Vault shenanigans are totally moot. It only will untap at the cost of a player's turn, and it is totally optional. Since your opponent will see it coming immediately, the only way it's untapping is if either you sacrifice your turn, take control of their turn (in which case, why aren't you just winning?), or using alternate untap methods (so why combo with Dominus?).
247204: Dominus of Fealty.text_posted:

247207: Nucklavee.author: JaxsonBateman
247207: Nucklavee.text_parsed:
While it certainly can be used to make a Warp World deck go infinite (seeing it first hand, another player in a 4 player FFA was playing a Warp World deck and was down to a low enough number of cards in deck and on the battlefield that he was getting all his permanents out each time - so he'd always hit Nuck, always get Warp World back, and would have enough mana to recast), I really can't see the Cruel Ultimatum 'infinite loop'. Sure, it can get Cruel Ultimatum back... once. Seems like it'd need a few other cards involved to create some sort of infinite loop.

As for the card itself - love it alongside Cackling Counterpart - for 3 mana, you get a 4/4 body at instant speed while using no cards (as you fish the Counterpart back out), plus you get a red sorcery back if you have one. Pretty groovy!

247273: Magus of the Vineyard.author: sonorhC
247273: Magus of the Vineyard.text_parsed:
He might benefit you more than your opponents, but he still benefits them, too. Given how many other mana acceleration options green has, I'll pass on this one. The net benefit (benefit to you minus benefit to everyone else) isn't worth the card.

@Myrofkoth, this will only get you a first-turn Superion if your opponent was nice enough to cast it for you. This gives you no mana the turn you summon him, because by the time you're able to summon him, the beginning of your precombat main phase has already passed.

247273: Magus of the Vineyard.author: Vlad74205
247273: Magus of the Vineyard.text_parsed:
@spirit_of_blue

Actually, its not cheating. The mana goes into their pool no matter what. This is an automatic action. This is similar to creatures that remained tapped unless its owners pays mana (or life, or...). Nobody declares the trigger goes on the stack, then pays the price or leaves it tapped. They just do it. True, you may hear a person say, "Paying 1 to untap Brass Gnat." However, the majority of the time, they just take care of it.

In this case, the player has the mana to use however they wish. This isn't a creature token that they must have, or an extra card that they should have drawn. The mana is in their pool. If they don't use the mana (just like if they tapped one too many lands), they lose it. What would happen if you forgot your own trigger? You would lose the mana. The game doesn't back up because you weren't paying attention.

You may call it unsportsman like, but I don't waste my time making sure my opponent remembers non critical effects.

247273: Magus of the Vineyard.author: Missile_Penguin
247273: Magus of the Vineyard.text_parsed:
Nearly every card in Time Spiral block was a throwback to at least one previously printed card.

This card references Eladamri's Vineyard and is part of the "Magus" super cycle of rare creatures. The Future Sight part of the cycle focuses on powerful enchantments, even matching the mana cost; the others are Magus of the Future, Magus of the Abyss, Magus of the Moon, and Magus of the Moat.

The Time Spiral part of the cycle focuses on powerful artifacts: Magus of the Candelabra, Magus of the Disk, Magus of the Mirror, Magus of the Jar, and Magus of the Scroll. The Planar Chaos cycle focuses on powerful lands: Magus of the Bazaar, Magus of the Coffers, Magus of the Tabernacle, Magus of the Arena, and Magus of the Library.

247274: Zoetic Cavern.author: Mickacabra
247274: Zoetic Cavern.text_parsed:
This is an underrated card. In draft, I see this as a utility tool. Sure at 5 mana, its an expensive extra land drop, but in a lot of situations, it's 3 colorless for a 2/2 and an additional 2 colorless to prevent damage from a creature for a turn OR to eat a creature removal spell. Late game, I would be happy to draw this guy over a land that only produced mana.
This is a land that can be a creature if youre flooded, or serve as card advantage by taking a lightning bolt or doom blade away from an opponent. There is a reason this land card is in my cube.

247274: Zoetic Cavern.author: blurrymadness
247274: Zoetic Cavern.text_parsed:
-Too many lands? You can have a creature
-Not enough lands? you can have a land
-Block a creature and then save your chump
-Like fatties? It's colorless mana-ramp!
-Safely attacks into players as well. Many morphs have very very disadvantageous effects when blocked; The opponent has to consider that there's a good chance when you swing with a 2/2 that their giant blocker could get eaten.
-Adds to the morph creature count so you can distract kill spells in general (I use it next to Liege of the Pit and/or grinning demon
-can be used to counter a kill spell as well: (I.E.)
"I doom blade your morph"
"*flurp* It's a land!"

Another nice thing is that next to mana-sac thrulls (blood vassal for example) it's very hard to actually kill as you don't need lands open. You can additionally nigh-guaranteed kill spells go for it when your friends know there's a 50-66% chance it's a giant demon about to punch them. It's lose-lose! They either waste their spell, or leave mana open to kill it at instant speed; slowing their game. Swing with it to put the pressure on!

These are all reasons that it works good in a casual demon deck. You need mana, you need things to sacrifice, you need early creatures, you need ways to suck kills spells out or to quickly nab your demons (I.E. liege can morph on T4 with no ramp; handy indeed!)

Awesome Story, that I swear to God is True: I was thinking up what sort of deck list I might pick for the Black-White-Red deck after I saw the spoiler for Kaalia of the Vast. Based only on I thought the arts looked awesome for the tone that kind of deck wants, I called:

Akroma, Angel of Fury
Malfegor
and this.
I also remember wanting to put either Firemane Angel or Razia Boros Archangel in, but I guess that's what Basandra's for instead.
I also wanted Reiver Demon again, but they made a better version with dumb art. the art is the only reason I play Reiver Demon. he's from Mirrodin, but for a reason I can't explain his art looks like it belongs to Ravnica, the best goddamn most BEAUTIFUL set Magic has ever had.
the name is why I pick Lord of the Pit over Xathrid Demon EVERY time.

247276: Electrolyze.author: Magnor_Criol
247276: Electrolyze.text_parsed:
@ Superllama - I was just noticing that as well. I think someone went through and rated all the EDHcards lower for some reason. Path to Exile and a few other classic great spells are also suddenly low.

@Henrietta - actually, if you look over Magic's history and compare a card that cantrips to the same spell WITHOUT the cantrip, they've fairly clearly decided that stapling a cantrip onto a card is worth about 2 mana. This is often just 2 colorless, but sometimes it's some combination of colored mana. Using Brainstorm and Ponder as your rubric for what a card draw is worth isn't a good comparison because those spells are designed for the narrow (but good!) application of manipulating the top of the library - it's not the same as a cantrip.

Still, this is pretty well costed. Forked Bolt cost R to do exactly this damage-wise; A number of cards cost just a single blue for some marginal effect and a card draw (or just the card draw, if you're Reach Through Mists). So + + one extra colorless to cover splitting the damage and stapling them together and you've got a well-costed card. Great spell.

247279: Izzet Boilerworks.author: ghstrydr
247279: Izzet Boilerworks.text_parsed:
Question on this card, I have been taking this card to read: "...return a land you control to its owner's hand." meaning: I play Izzet Boilerworks, I control several land cards, say for example 2R and 3U. My opponent controlls 2R and 3G. Since I control a red land, I force my opponent to return one of his red lands into their hand.

The card reads, "return a land you control to its owner's hand," it doesn't say "return a land you control to your hand," it refers to it's owner. I control a red land, therefore I can return a land of that color to an owners hand? I have read on a few places that you should return your land to your hand. Why would the card not say return a land of yours back to your hand, etc....?" confusing, any help is appreciated. I am totally new as you can tell, so any help would be appreciated.

Also, when laying a card that says it enters the battlefield tapped, do you not get to reap the benefits of tapping that card the turn you lay it? Say you lay a card that grants you R and G when tapped, if you lay that card and it is tapped already, don't you get to add that R and G to your mana pool that turn, or does it mean it is tapped, you cannot use it/receive it's benefits until next turn?

247279: Izzet Boilerworks.author: leomistico
247279: Izzet Boilerworks.text_parsed:
@ghstrydr: you posed the most bizzarre question of all time, but somehow licit... At least isn't the usual question about "What if I play this and it's the only land that I have in the battlefield?" (If you wonder, you must return it to your hand)

It doesn't say "...return a land you control to your hand." because you can control a land that you stealed from an opponent with Conquer, Shifting Borders, Vedalken Plotter or something else... In a player's graveyards, hands and libraries can go only cards that that player own (those cards that were in its library at the start of the game).

For your second question, in order to use your land, it has to be in the battlefield and you have to tap it. But this land enters the battlefield already tapped, so you wouldn't be able to meet the condition to use the land until you next untap step (unless you use a tool that untap it...).

Those lands may not be the most intuitive cards, but if you manage to understand them, they are a lot of advantage... Only, not put a lot of them on the same deck, because as said, you wouldn't like to start a game with a hand without a non-Karoo land...

5/5

247279: Izzet Boilerworks.author: RowanKeltizar
247279: Izzet Boilerworks.text_parsed:
I feel like in casual play the karoo lands are pretty nice... even in tricolor decks they aren't too bad. But they can result in massive loss of tempo if they get nuked, and in multiplayer that's pretty likely to happen. As with any card you have to weigh the pros and cons...

Pros:

*color fixing
*combo with untap land effects such as Candelabra of Tawnos
*Landfall trigger

Cons:

*comes into play tapped
*massive loss of speed if it gets removed

For me that already kills the card for me, at least in a competitive 2 color deck. I just don't need the extra color fixing that badly. There's a reason this is a $0.20 common :/

3/5

247283: Orzhov Basilica.author: Dankirk
247283: Orzhov Basilica.text_parsed:
@ PsyV: That would violate the 1 land per turn rule.
The key is to return an already tapped land to hand. This is not a real mana acceleration in terms of turns it takes to reach a certain point, but it allows you to build your mana base with less cards/lands.

Further more, if you draw one of these late in the game and have some cycle lands on the battlefield like Secluded Steppe or Barren Moor, you can return those to hand and cycle them for something else as mana might not be a concern at that point. You can even tap the returning cycle land to pay it's own cycle cost.
Another good choice to return is a land that has a "when this enters battlefield" effect, such as Bojuka Bog. Just remember to keep a balance between "comes into play tapped" and regular lands or put in a couple of Amulet of Vigors

247284: Orzhov Guildmage.author: HeartbreakerStudios
247284: Orzhov Guildmage.text_parsed:
Probably the most badass (<- I hate you, censor) card art in the game, but sadly he's very lukewarm.

A 2-drop hybrid for 2/2 is nice if not par. Black and White is promising. No tap to activate abilities, awesome. Abilities are minor, yet versatile, excellent. Abilities are 3-cost each... not cool.

There are insanely better things to spend 3 mana on, especially when the damage ability damages you too, you're forced to use the healing ability, a total cost of 6, to break even on a 1 sap, which you can get with other 1-drops.

This desperately needs to be broken, and not by Training Grounds.

Can technically win you the game with Bloom Tender + Umbral Mantle + 1 other colored permanent, but there have to be better, more practical, non-blue dependent combos.

So, I was playing a Grand Arbiter EDH deck. It was mostly made to moderate how the game will go.

I had a Leyline of Anticipation out. This is important.

So my friend is playing his retarded-ass Ghave token deck. Lo and behold, he plays this, with 59 life.

I say, revealing the Suture Priest in my hand, "Your actions are unsuitable for this game. The court finds you guilty for being a giant dippedy-doo (I wasn't thinking about what I was saying).", and literally laughed out loud, BECAUSE SUTURE PRIEST WON ME THE GAME!

It was a glorious moment. Don't play this when there's a Suture Priest on the field.

247291: Spurnmage Advocate.author: sarroth
247291: Spurnmage Advocate.text_parsed:
@Luseto: It's because you target the cards in the graveyards, so there must be valid targets. It's no different than casting Doom Blade, which requires a nonblack creature as a target even though that's the ability, not the cost.

NoeKoda is right, it's a great card for Commander. Group Hug decks should definitely run it, as not everyone likes to sit back and let the Group Hug player do their thing - they might think you're just biding your time to come in and win (which you might be) or just not like that you're helping their opponents just as much if not more than them (again, you might be!). It's a great removal spell that gives a player something of your choice, so you can be Group Hug-y even as you blow something up.

247293: Wonder.author: Ferlord
247293: Wonder.text_parsed:
I understand that saying "Strictly Better" is frowned upon in the Gatherer community, so I'll just say this...
Wonder is... much better than Levitation in many ways.

Before I continue, Levitation is an enchantment. You play it, and the effect comes into play. That's the only advantage.

Besides that, Wonder costs only 1 blue symbol rather than two, can be Buried Alive to nearly take full advantage of its effect, can come into play and block, and not only is it a 2/2, but it has fliying, making it a more versatile blocker than most creatures.

It can be extremely useful in a token deck as well as a Voltron deck, despite just improving one creature. Only a few effects can counter Wonder's ability (exiling, putting back into the deck (Condemn, Hallowed Burial)) and to finish it off, it comes in a 100 card deck for only $30+.

This card is worth a dollar plus, and rightfully so. It's nice that cards like this are getting "reprinted" in the new border for newer players.

Overall, it's just... a happy card. No dickery like Oppression, or any of the Praetors. No shenanigans like Dark Ritual or Sorin Markov... It's just solid. If it were Black, it'd be "When (card) is in your graveyard, you can play creatures from your graveyard". I can actually see that happening (if it hasn't already :()

247295: Aethersnipe.author: Oblivax
247295: Aethersnipe.text_parsed: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.

247296: Arbiter of Knollridge.author: bluewiz7
247296: Arbiter of Knollridge.text_parsed:
@Ferlord

False Cure would work. In taking the ruling from another card, but same principle:

If a player's life total is doubled, that player actually gains or loses the necessary amount of life. For example, if the life total of the enchanted creature's controller is 14 when Celestial Mantle's triggered ability resolves, the ability causes that player to gain 14 life. Other cards that interact with life gain or life loss will interact with this effect accordingly.

You gain or lose the appropriate amount of life to get to that total.
247296: Arbiter of Knollridge.text_posted:

247297: Austere Command.author: JaxsonBateman
247297: Austere Command.text_parsed:
How is this possibly a 4? Come on people, it's a 4.5 to 5. It's just a powerhouse of a sweeper; yes, it costs 6, but it's so versatile and so powerful. In a worst case scenario it's just more Day of Judgments which is rarely a bad thing. Best case scenario, it's a one sided sweeper, getting rid of all their best permanents while leaving yours alone. It's just great.

Personally, I've got it in a white/black 'sweeper' deck, that consists of 4 Wrath of God, 4 Damnation and 4 Austere Command among other things. The Austere Command is just so strong against any deck relying on power artifacts and enchantments, and so versatile that it still helps against creature decks. Why, just the other day I won a game against a guy who had no creatures in his deck, all thanks to Austere Command continuously sweeping away his artifacts (it was a blue deck designed around MCing creatures with Vedalken Shackles and Crown of Empires). Managed to comprehensively win thanks to Austere Command, despite having 3 dead cards in hand (2 Wraths and a Damnation).

There aren't many cards which can go so far towards deciding the outcome of a game.

247297: Austere Command.author: Asmodi0000
247297: Austere Command.text_parsed:
An important thing to keep in mind is the order in which the effects happen.

For example, a creature that is enchanted by Indestructibility would be destroyed (since enchantments are destroyed before creatures), but an artifact that is enchanted by Indestructibility wouldn't be destroyed (since the enchantment would break after all breakable artifacts were checked).

This makes a lot of interesting things happen.
Aegis Angel would be able to protect just about anything (except for herself), and Angelic Overseer would die if all the humans on the board were less than 3 CMC (assuming the last two options were picked). Eldrazi Monument dies well before you destroy any creatures, and those pesky creatures enchanted by Shield of the Oversoul can have fun eating dirt before they die.

Artifact creatures also make things interesting. If there's an Iron Myr with a divinity counter on it from That Which Was Taken, and the first and third options are chosen, then there's a brief instance where you try to destroy the Iron Myr but find it immune to your power. Of course, once That Which Was Taken is out of the way, that Myr quickly learns humility, and of course death.

I know that when you play a card like ponder, the first part happens first, then the second part. You can't draw the card, then shuffle your deck.

These effects are seperated by semi-colons so I believe that they would happen in order from top to bottom, not at the exact same time.

So, if you have eldrazi monument out, and use destroy all artifacts and destroy all creatures of cmc 3 or less, the monument would die, then the creatures would die, they would not be indestructable for the resolution of the second part.

247297: Austere Command.author: Kafkanod
247297: Austere Command.text_parsed:
@MithosFall;NeoKoda

You're wrong: the creature would also be destroyed. From the Lorwyn FAQ:

The _Lorwyn_ set features a cycle of five cards with "Command" in their name. These are modal cards in which you choose two modes rather than one.
* The chosen modes will have their effects in the order they appear on the card.

@coff

You don't stack the modes, you stack the spell, so you can't choose the order. The third mode has its effect before the fourth, but even if they were reversed, Wurmcoil's Engine triggered ability would still be on the stack after Austere Command finishes resolving, so the tokens would not be on the battlefield yet.

You look at this card, and its clearly amazing- but unlike similar"choose" effects, I am always blown away by the fact that you get to pick TWO! Having those kinds of options, the kind that let you sculpt the board-state to your liking is kind of card advantage that wins you games. Very well designed, very powerful, and yet still fair.

247299: Faultgrinder.author: Oblivax
247299: Faultgrinder.text_parsed: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.
247299: Faultgrinder.text_posted: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass. 247301: Lash Out.author: Gelzo
247301: Lash Out.text_parsed:
I think it's weird that this is rated more than 2 stars lower than the original print. People must not have liked seeing this in the deck, and I can't say I disagree with the sentiment. Direct damage this weak really sucks in EDH.

But.

I thought standard procedure for rating cards was to attempt to rate how good they are in general and not just for a particular format. How misleading is it going to be to a new player to see this rating and be led to conclude that it's a bad card? I think this can be a pretty decent card for casual or modern burn. It isn't fantastic, but it deserves a four or at least a three in my book.

247301: Lash Out.author: HuntingDrake
247301: Lash Out.text_parsed: Clash does make sense in EDH. It has a subtle draw-smoothing effect, and it gets better in multiplayer. Since you clash with "an opponent", not "that creature's controller", you can give away a minor boon to someone whose help you need. You can even choose the opponent with the lowest average mana cost, or one who for whatever reason is known to have a land coming.

247304: Scattering Stroke.author: The_Jabberwocky
247304: Scattering Stroke.text_parsed: @ TheWrathofShane - Excising a player because he plays a Mana Drain is pretty close-minded. I agree with you that too many people play to win and not for fun, but you shouldn't automatically assume because someone plays an expensive card that they are only playing to win. I own a Mana Drain and play it because it has incredible nostalgic appeal for me and because it is one of my favorite pieces of art from my all time favorite artist (Mark Tedin). I put a priority on having fun when I play Magic and I try to out-play my opponents, not out-wallet them. That said, I still use some expensive, powerful cards, but I don't stack my deck with all of them in one deck. I like to play with a lot of mediocre cards too that have awesome artwork, so it usually balances out. Besides, who is to judge how much is too much to spend on cards? Unless you are a dedicated Pauper player the argument can be made that anyone who spends even $1 on a piece of cardboard is stupid. I would much prefer to ban someone based on a bad attitude than the cards that they use. I'm tired of hearing about cry-babies who scoop because someone plays a card they don't like. How about grow up instead and challenge yourself to build a better, more versatile deck.

247311: Whirlpool Whelm.author: Mode
247311: Whirlpool Whelm.text_parsed:
@lica_barelli:I wouldn't compare it to Disperse or Into the Roil.

This is more something between Unsummon or Repel. You might also compare it to Metamorphose.
Since in this case there are ways to manipulate the clash, this is actually a pretty decent card.
In the worst case it's still an Unsummon for , since even if you win the clash you don't have to put the creature on top, which is important if you use the spell on your own creatures in response to removal.

I'll give this a 3.5 because it has the potential to put a big creature on top for little mana.
Compared to regular bounce effects it's card disadvantage for your opponent.

And you can put it on a stick. Couldn't imagine a deck where this would work out, but it might be worth a try.

247311: Whirlpool Whelm.text_parsed:
This card deserves more than two stars. It's very versatile and has so many uses.

The clash ability allows -- if nothing else -- to see your top card and decide if you need it or if something else would be better.

It's useful for ETB effects on your own creatures, saving a creature, reducing an opponent's card/board advantage and combos well with cards like Coiling Oracle.

I run a playset of these in my G/W/U ETB deck.

247311: Whirlpool Whelm.author: SpawnOfVirtue
247311: Whirlpool Whelm.text_parsed:
I read the comments on this card, and I agree with what most have said thus far. I believe that lica_barelli has this card properly assesed, however. The key to the clash mechanic is not whether or not the creature is placed on top of their library. Yes, I realize this is a plus and what most of the comments have been aimed at, but this is not the point of this card.

Imagine that the card read instead:

Instant 1U return target creature to its owner's hand. Both players Scry 1, if the card you revealed is a higher CMC than your opponents revealed card, instead put the creature on top of the owner's library.

I hope that you now understand why this card is perhaps better than at a first glance. Yes, you are allowing your opponent to scry with you, but the card is still in your favor because you have the potential to win the clash and set them back a card. This is something that both "Tempo" and "Control" decks can benefit from immensely. Your opponent being forced into, albeit occasionally, put his creature on top of his deck makes his next turn essentially dead draw. Replaying the creature will not help with this kind of "tempo" and over all card loss.

I enjoyed the part where you said to put it on an Isochron Scepter. This card is near and dear to my heart, and certainly having a card on scepter that does 2 things consistantly and one thing occaisionally is good, very good. Think of it like a miracle card in your deck when associated with isochron scepter. In your opening hand, its ok. If you draw into the scepter however... it will consistantly bounce their creatures, consistanly scry your deck (and yes, I realize their deck as well) and every lucky once in a while, it will give them true card loss.

To everyone who read this long...drawn-out analysis of a card that most won't give a second glance at, I thank you. You probably have a similar appreciation of MTG. Also, you probably love Isochron in a similar fashion. This was my very first Gatherer comment, I have used this wonderful website to brew decks, and I will continue to brew and offer my own experiences with cards.

247312: Wild Ricochet.author: UsagiYojimbo
247312: Wild Ricochet.text_parsed:
I absolutely adore this card as a blue hoser, not necessarily because it's particularly good at it (though it's definitely good) but because it is the funniest way to stop a counterspell ever printed.

I drop a Cruel Ultimatum and my opponent tries to Counterspell it.

My Wild Ricochet is on the stack first, the first thing it does is change the target of your Counterspell, but it makes a copy of Counterspell too. So I change the target to my Wild Richochet. Then the copy of Counterspell targets the first Counterspell . Then, naturally, the Counterspell copy counters the first Counterspell which retroactively causes the Wild Ricochet to not be countered, thus protecting Cruel Ultimatum.

Oh Red, you so wacky!

247312: Wild Ricochet.author: Lief098
247312: Wild Ricochet.text_parsed:
This card is a ton of fun in EDH. Just today, it stole me a game that I had no business winning.

Here's the scenario. I was playing my Brion Stoutarm deck against my friend's Jaya Ballard deck. He had a Mana Flare on the field and 12 Mountains, and I only had 4 Plains and 4 Mountains. He was at 31 life, and I was at 45 life.

During his turn, he used about 4 different burn spells (the first of which was a Past in Flames) to get me down to 17 life. With 6 cards in hand, he passed the turn. I knew that I probably had one turn to live, as his deck is somewhat based around spells with X costs. With no cards in hand, I drew, hoping to pull anything that could help my situation. In what was possibly the luckiest topdeck I've ever had, I drew Wild Ricochet. I passed the turn.

Eyes gleaming, my friend drew, then played a Banefire for 22 damage. "Try countering THAT!" he said. In response, I cast the Wild Ricochet and sent both copies at him.

The look on his face was absolutely priceless.

247312: Wild Ricochet.author: TwentyFifthBaam
247312: Wild Ricochet.text_parsed:
Really good card, but I think some people are confused on how it works.

Someone mentioned copying a counter to counter itself. No. That doesn't work. If wild richochet's on top of the stack, it is played. After that, it's already resolved. You can't make it counter itself. You'd have to choose other targets for that. For example, keep the original target of the counterspell, then make the other counterspell counter the first one. Still works, just not like you're thinking.

Always fun with really rigged instants or sorceries. Hymn to Tourach? Hey, noob, discard four cards!

At worst, a mildly amusing way to get card advantage. At best, this wins you the game with style.

247316: Howling Mine.author: Artscrafter
247316: Howling Mine.text_parsed:
@Fenizrael and ICEFANG13: Clock of Omens works perfectly with this, even if you have Unwinding Clock as well.

Recall that the untap step happens before anything else. All you need to do is activate Clock of Omens during your opponents' upkeep steps, targeting Clock of Omens (it doesn't say you have to target a tapped artifact) and tapping Howling Mine and Clock of Omens to pay the cost. The clock untaps, the mine stays tapped, and you're good to go. If you're not playing Commander, note that you can do this with one Clock of Omens for any number of Howling Mines.
247316: Howling Mine.text_posted:
@Fenizrael and ICEFANG13: [autocard]Clock of Omens[/autocard] works perfectly with this, even if you have [autocard]Unwinding Clock[/autocard] as well.

Recall that the untap step happens before anything else. All you need to do is activate Clock of Omens during your opponents' upkeep steps, targeting Clock of Omens (it doesn't say you have to target a tapped artifact) and tapping Howling Mine and Clock of Omens to pay the cost. The clock untaps, the mine stays tapped, and you're good to go. If you're not playing Commander, note that you can do this with one Clock of Omens for any number of Howling Mines.

247316: Howling Mine.author: ICEFANG13
247316: Howling Mine.text_parsed:
@ Fenizrael

Clock of Omens would be my choice, but probably isn't as good for you because of Unwinding Clock.

Relic Barrier does exactly what you want it to do, as long as you don't mind a lack of other uses.

Icy Manipulator is probably the best choice, but only if you have mana ramping, not a lot of other players, or use artifact lands.

EDIT @Artscrafter I know that, but the reason why its not as good for this deck is because untapping things with the effect is much less useful with Unwinding Clock then it would be in a deck without it.

247316: Howling Mine.author: BongRipper420
247316: Howling Mine.text_parsed:
Politically, this is one of the best cards in the game. The neat thing in multiplayer is, if you play this card, you've likely built a deck which is helped quite a bit by it, or needs the draw power from artifacts (W/R control comes to mind), so much so that the cards your opponent('s) draw are irrelevant to some degree. In multiplayer, most people see this played and stop attacking the guy with Howling Mine. While that's cool, it can be a pretty bad decision if that deck is a combo deck searching for it's last combo piece to win, ect.

Still, a fun card and if nothing else will make a game interesting.

247316: Howling Mine.author: ReneesAnatomy
247316: Howling Mine.text_parsed: I was playing a casual gauntlet with some friends, and one of them asked if she could borrow my collection of Mox cards. I said sure; we stuck little pieces of Post-It on the front of mine so we'd know which ones belonged to me, and off we went. Turns out she had an "overdraw" deck with three copies of this card plus plenty of land-and-creature wipes (so she just used Mox for mana while the rest of us were screwed), plus cards like Black Vise, Font of Mythos, and Kederekt Parasite to continuously screw us. And as impossible as it was for us to beat her...we couldn't stop LAUGHING! We all looked ridiculous juggling hands of 20 cards. It's just so much fun to play with this.

247318: Angelic Arbiter.author: SkyknightXi
247318: Angelic Arbiter.text_parsed:
{sweatdrop} I think you just brought up the reason they may have pulled this in over Akroma Mk. I (besides taking care not to get singles-selling stores incensed at them, like what happened when they reprinted so many high-value rares at once in 4th and Chronicles): More amenable to Commander politics and intricacy, rather than just being an immense frigate (although I'm not sure how political Kaalia's Dega deck is supposed to be...). I doubt preconstructeds were ever meant to just be a way to get expensive-secondhand cards on the relative cheap, in any case (they weren't expecting Umezawa's Jitte to be so devastating, to answer the obvious counterpoint); more like a way to dive into trying out the various precepts of new sets and formats without having to plan out a lot beforehand.

Besides, it'd be a little boring if there were nothing but cards that averaged 4.75 or better on here. Some place for the arcane and unknown is always good.

247322: Doom Blade.author: infernox10
247322: Doom Blade.text_parsed:
Doom Blade simply just isn't good in Commander format.
1-for-1's in Commander are basically pointless, unless they're:
1. Combo-enabling (say, Bone Splinters your Abyssal Gatekeeper with a Grave Pact on the field).
2. Versatile. As someone suggested, Putrefy and Mortify are good examples.
In a format that allows you to build mana because it has long games,
A cheap 1-for-1 just isn't amazing.
(And if you still want it, use something like Rend Flesh, as there are more black creatures running around in EDH than Spirits, and again, cmc isn't a huge issue.)

247323: Garruk Wildspeaker.author: DarthParallax
247323: Garruk Wildspeaker.text_parsed:
Quick run-down on the Planeswalkers:

Everyone knows why they're good. They give free mana, free card advantage, a something else for your opponent to kill other than you, because you can't allow them to build up to the Finishing Move.

This means that half of the reasons they are good are nil. They are Walking Targets. Some get through, some don't, but anything in your opponent's deck remotely similar to 'Doom Blade for planeswalkers' is going to be heading your Walkers' way as soon as they draw it. They are the ultimate bombs. They eat a card from your opponent, or your opponent dies. More often than not, the opponent eats a card to kill them.

Green, White, and Red can all play fast Zoo/Sligh beats. In most cases, those decks don't NEED planeswalkers, they just like them because they are more copies of the same goodies effects they have a lot of already. Which is a fine reason to play them, but not the point I want to make.

Black Planeswalkers are far too slow for the color, and Wizards isn't making another Dark Ritual anytime soon.

On top of everything else that's good about Jace and Tezzeret, they give blue really really good 'ground work'- something Blue used to always have to borrow from White or Green. Mono-Blue isn't something I think we can expect to see for a long time, but Jace, even just the unbanned Beleren version, goes a long way towards it.

The basics of those fast sligh decks came from getting as many permanents under the 'counterspell radar' as possible. Blue doesn't do good with permanents, and doesn't have a lot of good permanents either. Pick anytime you've heard of a blue permanent being decent, and its usually ended up dominating because blue already has everything else it needs in spades. Faeries being an excellent example. They rarely give blue nice stuff that isn't an instant or sorcery. And unlike Faeries, they've let Blue keep Beleren. He doesn't have unsummon, which is sad. But he still affects the board, slightly, by being another thing to point spells and dudes at. This is true of all 'walkers, but I find it most significant for Blue. If tomorrow all the planeswalkers got banned (unlikely in the extreme), Blue would be hurt the worst, I believe.

This is why I think Jace Beleren is better than Garruk Wildspeaker, AND is still actually fair.
247323: Garruk Wildspeaker.text_posted:
Quick run-down on the Planeswalkers: 

Everyone knows why they're good. They give free mana, free card advantage, a something else for your opponent to kill other than you, because you can't allow them to build up to the Finishing Move.

This means that half of the reasons they are good are nil. They are Walking Targets. Some get through, some don't, but anything in your opponent's deck remotely similar to 'Doom Blade for planeswalkers' is going to be heading your Walkers' way as soon as they draw it. They are the ultimate bombs. They eat a card from your opponent, or your opponent dies. More often than not, the opponent eats a card to kill them. 

Green, White, and Red can all play fast Zoo/Sligh beats. In most cases, those decks don't NEED planeswalkers, they just like them because they are more copies of the same goodies effects they have a lot of already. Which is a fine reason to play them, but not the point I want to make.

Black Planeswalkers are far too slow for the color, and Wizards isn't making another Dark Ritual anytime soon.

On top of everything else that's good about Jace and Tezzeret, they give blue really really good 'ground work'- something Blue used to always have to borrow from White or Green. Mono-Blue isn't something I think we can expect to see for a long time, but Jace, even just the unbanned Beleren version, goes a long way towards it.

The basics of those fast sligh decks came from getting as many permanents under the 'counterspell radar' as possible. Blue doesn't do good with permanents, and doesn't have a lot of good permanents either. Pick anytime you've heard of a blue permanent being decent, and its usually ended up dominating because blue already has everything else it needs in spades. Faeries being an excellent example.  They rarely give blue nice stuff that isn't an instant or sorcery. And unlike Faeries, they've let Blue keep Beleren. He doesn't have unsummon, which is sad. But he still affects the board, slightly, by being another thing to point spells and dudes at. This is true of all 'walkers, but I find it most significant for Blue. If tomorrow all the planeswalkers got banned (unlikely in the extreme), Blue would be hurt the worst, I believe.

This is why I think Jace Beleren is better than Garruk Wildspeaker, AND is still actually fair.

247325: Rise from the Grave.author: ProbablyThatGuy
247325: Rise from the Grave.text_parsed:
@tcollins: Sorry, but the creature type shapeshifter doesn't make the creature all creature types, rather, the ability Changeling does, like what Cairn Wanderer has.

This card has great synergy and flavor for my Lim-Dul EDH. One game, the group was mad at me for having Lim out with an Avatar of Woe (someone else's Lim-zombied ftw) equiped with a Thornbite Staff smashing their fields, with Lim-Dul to grab their creatures up. They couldn't get rid of the Staff or Avatar at the time, so they kept trying to kill my poor necromancer, and had gotten him a couple times. Fortunately topdecked this nice fellow, and got to troll them with a "Shoot, now I've gotta pay 11 mana to bring out Lim again... nah, I leave him in the graveyard." Rise from the Grave next turn, "there, now hes a zombie too, you big meanies! Now, die already please."

Beyond that, it is overall a nice option to bring into most multiplayer games, although depending on your deck there might be better cards. I'm not sure how this print got as low as 3.25 rating, especially since it was reprinted for a multiplayer format. I'd say more around 4/5 is fair.

247327: Sign in Blood.author: Henrietta
247327: Sign in Blood.text_parsed: This is a bit of a tangent, but I really wish more draw spells were costed like this. 2U for two cards is the standard for a draw spell now (Divination), but that is just horribly inefficient. For U, you get to draw a card plus gain a bonus (any number of one mana cantrips). Most of those cards don't see competitive play (mainly just brainstorm/preordain/ponder), and adding an extra 2 to the cost and removing whatever bonus for one extra card doesn't see competitive play either. This card is pretty much exactly what draw spells need to be - two cards for two coloured mana with no drawback, or in this case two cards for two coloured mana with an advantage and a drawback that offset each other. This has seen real play in tournaments when it was Standard legal, but it was never even close to being too good.

247329: Ray of Command.author: RxPhantom
247329: Ray of Command.text_parsed:
First, I must say how pleased I am to see the Mirage art, and how happy I am that Mirage and Visions haven't been forgotten.

This card's been a favorite of mine for a long time, and it's the epitome of blue's penchant for manipulation. I can't count the times I've used it, and how many outcomes it's yielded. Plus, it combos with so many things: Ritual of the Machine, Lord of Tresserhorn, Fling, Infernal Tribute, Carrion etc. Not to mention all the creatures that get buffs from sacrificing creatures.

Oh, Ray of Command, so many fond memories.

247330: Afterlife.author: scumbling1
247330: Afterlife.text_parsed:
Afterlife isn't a bad card in EDH. It's instant-speed, fairly-cheap, unconditional removal. You'll most likely be killing a creature that costs more than three mana, and a single 1/1 token doesn't amount to anything in that format.

The problem is that it's white; that color already has the best single-shot removal in the game. When card advantage is of high importance, it's best to keep the one-for-one removal spells to a minimum. It's hard for Afterlife when it has to compete against Swords to Plowshares, Path to Exile, Condemn, and Wing Shards. There's just no room left for it.

The card would have been awesome, were it printed in red, green, or blue.

247332: Invigorate.author: AlphaWolfs
247332: Invigorate.text_parsed:
Once Upon a Time,
Infect was in standard,
The reason why this card was overlooked with infect is because they weren't standard at the same time. Countless people countless times made green infect decks, and every one of them were made for standard online or not, no one even thought of using this card in an Infect deck while it was standard.

Now that standard is no longer threatened by Poisons, people look to Modern to see how venomous they can make it, and have seen the true power of Infect+Inviorate.

The end!

(TL:DR - People didn't think of this card for the longest time with infect was because this and infect were never in standard at the same time).

*ALL Puns in this post were intentional*

247336: Spitebellows.author: Oblivax
247336: Spitebellows.text_parsed: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.
247336: Spitebellows.text_posted: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass. 247336: Spitebellows.author: Brendan_McCoy
247336: Spitebellows.text_parsed:
@Oblivax

"702.72a Evoke represents two abilities: a static ability that functions in any zone from which the card with evoke can be cast and a triggered ability that functions on the battlefield. "Evoke " means "You may cast this card by paying rather than paying its mana cost" and "When this permanent enters the battlefield, if its evoke cost was paid, its controller sacrifices it." Paying a card's evoke cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules 601.2b and 601.2e–g. "

it's not part of the cost that you sacrifice the creature, it's an additional ability put onto the stack when an evoked creature enters the battlefield. When you blink it in response to that ability, you're having a new instance of the creature enter the battlefield, the triggered ability from evoke still on the stack. However, that evoke ability refers to the previous instance of the creature, which was blinked. Please learn what the stack is how and how it and abilities (specifically,triggered abilities) work. The you read the rule on evoke and you missed an important part.

247337: Lightning Greaves.author: DoubleTarget
247337: Lightning Greaves.text_parsed:
Lightning Greaves is unquestionably broken to me. A free equip cost means there's almost no decision about whether or not to use it. You simply use it whenever you can. It also allows for some wild combos from Leonin Shikari to Daru Spiritualist to Cephalid Illusionst (the latter two being better with another free equip cost artifact, Shuko). It's dangerous enough that Wizards has to be careful if they decided to ever print another free equip cost equipment with no drawbacks or else they have to make you work for it (see Puresteel Paladin).

That being said, it takes a broken artifact like Lightning Greaves to make creature-based Commander decks viable so that you can make good use of your creatures before they die to spot removal or a board wipe.

247338: Oblivion Stone.author: AngusMcSillyWilly
247338: Oblivion Stone.text_parsed:
I like the O-Stone. I have used it a fair bit and find it has two great uses. First, obviously to destroy everything. That's always a gas. But second, the threat of destroying everything is just as good, or maybe even better

Your opponent thinks "I'm not going to play my awesome guy as long as O-Stone is ready to go". If you keep the 5 mana ready then it can't even be destroyed without you blowing the O out of everything.

So you end up getting a bunch of extra turns with the other guy holding back. The fate counter thing is just extra bonus.

247338: Oblivion Stone.author: mdakw576
247338: Oblivion Stone.text_parsed:
1) Colorless sweeper with reasonable mana costs means that any EDH deck that needs a sweeper will have this as an option.
2) Great political card with mindgames. When the controller has 5 mana open you have to respect it.
3) Artifact type means it's easy to recur.

I have this in my Maelstrom Wanderer deck as my 1-of sweeper. One problem with running other sweepers (such as Chain Reaction) is that if Wanderer cascades into it and I don't want it, it's a dead card. With this card if I hit it I will always cast it and let it sit around until I need it.

247339: Reiver Demon.author: Ferlord
247339: Reiver Demon.text_parsed:
Reiver Demon, in its time, probably wasn't the best card to play.

In Mirrodin, many of the creatures were Artifacts, and all tournament-worthy decks were artifact based. I know for a fact because one store owner I go to was Mexico's champion in 2004, and he said that every deck was Affinity-based (including his).


I just have 1 question: His ability doesn't activate when Kaalia brings him out, right? Since he wasn't cast, it doesn't count...
The reason I ask is because I've played Kaalia, attacked, brought him out, and then wiped the board without anyone interjecting. I do use the Divine Vs Demonic copy, which says "if you played it from your hand", which confused me at first...

247339: Reiver Demon.author: AshToMoutHound
247339: Reiver Demon.text_parsed:
He and Dread Cacodemon saved my arse once when I was one attack away from dying for seemingly endless amount of turns and pulled the final swamp after getting no lands for many, many turns. They wiped away two waves of centaur/bird tokens, both doubled by Rhys the Redeemed a few times. Then I started bringing my foe's life total down from the 80+ he had gathered with Trostani, Selesnya's Voice and lifted about 40 cards from my GY with Praetor's Counsel. It was EDH and I forgot to use my commander Jarad for the whole game except for the final sacrifice of a demon to end the game. My finest and dumbest survival story in MTG yet, but I'm sure my friend/opponent was a little intimidated after the game. ;D

I love demons and think they would make an interesting tribe. 6/6

247340: Solemn Simulacrum.author: sarroth
247340: Solemn Simulacrum.text_parsed:
@lorendorky: Holly non sequitur Batman, I expected you to ask why it didn't say "dies" like greg2367 pointed out. If that were the case, I'd agree: Troll Ascetic gets an update, why not this guy? The lack of M12's art probably has to do with the fact that the art was commissioned for that release and was a planned spoiler for a website, so that'd be kind of ruined by printing it a month earlier. As far as I know all of the other cards that got new art just got reprints of their past promo art.

I'm in agreement with Chamale that it's disappointing that only one Commander deck has this guy in it. Worse though, is that the one deck that gets it is Green, but the three decks without the best color and mana ramping don't. That's something that continues to puzzle me.

As for the art, it is weird, but I like what they did, given the definition of simulacrum: "a slight, unreal, or superficial likeness or semblance." For that reason, at least, I'll miss this art a little come M12, but the new art is pretty amazing, if a little too reminiscent of Esper.

247342: Buried Alive.author: GrimjawxRULES
247342: Buried Alive.text_parsed:
This card + Dark Ritual is the backup plan for reanimation decks if they don't draw Entomb in their opening hand:

Turn 1: Swamp, Dark Ritual, this
Turn 2: Swamp, Exhume, GG

Some of the most common reanimate targets include Iona, Shield of Emiria, Empyrial Archangel and (if you get the Dark Ritual + Buried Alive on turn 1) Bladewing, the Risen + another dragon of your own choice, all of which are pretty much instant wins.

My favorite use of this card is the following :
-
T1 : Swamp, Dark Ritual, Buried Alive (search for Bladewing the Risen, Dragon Tyrant and Anger)

-
I like this because it combines my inner Johnny (Dragon reanimation combo), my inner Timmy (BIG DRAGON TYRANT!BBQLOLZ!) and my inner Spike (Turn 2 damage is, without a doubt, SUPER EFFECTIVE). All wrapped up in one.

To all who read this: STOP HATING BOARD-WIPES IN EDH. They are doing a public service and de-clogging the board. HELP END THE HATE TODAY.

EDIT: @ ridiculousricky,who said "

247346: Forgotten Cave.author: blurrymadness
247346: Forgotten Cave.text_parsed:
I love this cycle of lands, especially in multicolored decks. If you don't need more than one of that color of mana, you cycle it whenever you get the chance as a rule of thumb. Why? because if you're able to cycle it, you have that color of mana! A neat way to help a new player avoid mana screw.

It's also very good in various other decks/situations, mostly as instant speed draw in non-blue. You can have "too many" lands in your other colors and these help to mitigate that problem.

4/5 IMO

247347: Insurrection.author: Pinto331
247347: Insurrection.text_parsed:
@Negated

This card does not work with Sundial of the Infinite. Read Sundial's rule text.

Damage wears off, and "this turn" and "until end of turn" effects end.

Insurrection lasts until end of turn, so Sundial would end it. Sundial is used to stop triggered effects, mostly anything that says "at the beginning of the next end step".
247347: Insurrection.text_posted:
@Negated

This card does not work with Sundial of the Infinite.  Read Sundial's rule text.

[i]Damage wears off, and "this turn" and "until end of turn" effects end.[/i]

Insurrection lasts until end of turn, so Sundial would end it.  Sundial is used to stop triggered effects, mostly anything that says "at the beginning of the next end step".

247347: Insurrection.author: KasaiAisu
247347: Insurrection.text_parsed:
@Pinto331
You're reading the wrong part of Sundial of the Infinite. Look here:

"Exile all spells and abilities on the stack."

This means that at the end of your turn, the trigger for everybody getting their things back goes on the stack, to which you respond with the Sundial. The trigger goes away and you get to keep all your cool dudes.

247347: Insurrection.author: Mr_McPippens
247347: Insurrection.text_parsed:
At my local card shop's weekly EDH tournament, we do a round of pods of 4, then winners move on to a final pod with the winner being the winner of the tournament. In the first round we had 3 decks with red and 2 with blue. I was using a ghave deck, pumping out creatures. I played storm herd with Cathar's Crusade, beefing up the pegusi with my general. Then each turn after that, each player played insurrection and someone else prevented it in some way.

I play storm herd, do stuff, end turn.
Guy plays insurrection, someone counters.
Next guy plays insurrection, someone uses homeward land (w/e its called) to return all.
Next guy plays an insurrection from the previous guys graveyard with something (dont remember what) and someone wipes the field. Comes back to me and i do practically nothing. Our game lasted 3 or 4 hours and the tournament was canceled because there was no clear winner, so each winner from each other pod got a small reward instead and we called our game a draw with the only reward being fun and epic moments in edh.

247348: Krosan Tusker.author: Minus_Prime
247348: Krosan Tusker.text_parsed:
I never actually met anyone who didn't like Krosan Tusker. It's a 6/5 beatstick that, should you not need one or are not able to summon it, is also both a land and some other card instead. Consider how horrendously overcosted other landcycling creatures wound up being. Sanctum Plowbeast? Six mana of two different colors for a 3/6 Defender that can only grab 2 of 5 basic land types and doesn't draw any extra cards? Please..

The only thing that ever bothered me about this card was the art, because I used to think it was just a giant boar head stuck onto a comically undersized body with almost nonexistent legs. It only recently occurred to me that those legs are both of its front legs, and the beast has taken an abrupt left turn after charging directly at the 'camera'.

247348: Krosan Tusker.author: HotHit
247348: Krosan Tusker.text_parsed:
It makes me sad to think that this isn't in standard. But, Krosan Tusker is one of the most elegantly designed cards in magic. It has basically one ability, but that ability is a keyword and an extra 4 lines of text, for a newer player this is difficult to understand, for a player who's dabbled a little? They've seen enough green land searching to see those extra 4 lines like a keyword.

I've gathered up a weird fight/beast deck and this guy is next to Woolly Thoctar for being so useful, despite being so simple. In my deck alone he provides:

> Annoying pesky blue players who like to spam cancel, it's an ability, not a spell.
> Mana fixing (I run a single plains and mountain just so this guy can find 'em).
> Consistent hand size for bloodrush spam.
> A creature for Domri Rade to find
> As a beast it works with their support cards, my personal favourite being Contested Cliffs, y'know, if Krosan Tusker wasn't just more fun to cycle all the time.
> Crap you killed my Moldgraf monstrosity... Hey remember when I was drawing all those cards earlier?
> You think I shouldn't cycle when I've got 10 mana already? I have no need of fools who can imagine enough land.

247348: Krosan Tusker.author: Laguz
247348: Krosan Tusker.text_parsed:
Land cycling is one of the most underrated abilities the game has ever seen and this is even better. The versatility makes it one of my favorite creatures of all time...shame about the art, I always just pictured the thing bouncing around with a dumb smile on its face like a kangaroo on drugs.

Another way to look at it is like this:
2G
Instant

This spell cannot be countered.
Search your library for a basic land card and put it into your hand.
Draw a card.

Which is already incredible without the 6/5 beat stick that it becomes when you would no longer need to cast such a spell!

But yeah, its a weird bouncing smiling thing.

247350: Oblation.author: Cheza
247350: Oblation.text_parsed:
QUOTE: >>> This seems way more Blue than White. <<<

I don't think so. This card is my best hope that white gains more draw spells (next to Survival Cache). In my opinion, draw is defensive, slow and random. And third one should make it obvious that it shouldn't be blue and give a hint, what is the right color.

Blue should rather have search spells (see Diabolic Tutor // Transmute). If blue is REALLY meant to be the control color, it should control what it is drawing. And search spells are the best way to control what you draw and what you have in your hand.

White on the other hand would profit from draw spells. Drawing means "wasting mana" to replace the card in your hand and have a random extra card. Therefore it is a peaceful, constructive, slow way to win the game on the long run.

If white would also have more cards like Prosperity or Rites of Flourishing, it could fulfill the "peaceful support" role in games with teammates. A Pursuit of Knowledge (renamed into Hope for Salvation) would be wonderful reprint for .

Last but not least, I would really like to see a white Overbeing of Myth or a knight version of Kiyomaro, First to Stand finally returning Empyrial Armor's ability to it's true home - white!

247350: Oblation.author: DarthParallax
247350: Oblation.text_parsed:
'White shouldn't get Draw' is a dumb argument. RED should get draw, but doesn't. Oh, not in the same league as anybody else, but Scry on Magma Jet was beautiful.

Magic is a game, and games work on resources. The Color Pie adds a lot of definition and balance to this game, but some things are just plain necessary to have, or you lose. Mana is #1, Cards are #2. Or the other way around. Either way, every color needs access to Mana and Cards or it loses.

No, not all 'draw spells' should be templated the way Blue ones are- but they should definitely be there, in every color. Squadron Hawk was an excercise in experimentation- turns out that's not the best execution of the idea for fairness, but the fundamental theory is sound: 'Card Advantage' is not 'Blue's Share of the Color Pie'. That would be the same thing as saying 'Winning' is 'Blue's Share of the Color Pie'
(In the old Time Walk/Ancestral Recall days, it was. Do we really want that?)

247350: Oblation.author: NeoKoda
247350: Oblation.text_parsed:
This seems way more Blue than White. But it is a pretty nice card. I rated it a bit lower due to Color Pie strangeness.

EDIT: Let me explain my controversial (apparently, it's rated five stars, yet two people disagree with me) comment. I rated it lower because I don't like color pie bleeds, I think it's poor design to allow two colors to do things equally well, except sparingly. However, I can't recall why I felt this was Blue. I support draw in all colors, but I think only Blue should get it straight up. So, to conclude, I rate cards not just on playability but design, and I now think this is White, since it pretty much banishes the creature, but makes amends. White likes to give stuff in return for your permanent (Path to Exile and Swords to Plowshares for outstanding examples).

About the "draw is random" type comments. Yeah, it is. Yes, it's Blue. Blue lives for knowledge and learning. When you research things, you don't JUST learn what you set out to. You get more than that, for example, if you researched bananas, then you'd learn about the climate of the countries in which they live. Blue can't tutor, but it can manipulate the draw. It can say "Hmm...out of this available material, (cards in the library reveal by Ponder, Preordain or the like) I want to study this (whatever card). But this seems interesting too, I should read that next." This differs from Black's tutoring because Black doesn't really want to learn. It wants to win. It doesn't care about the climate, it cares about bananas, because bananas will kill it's opponent, and empower Black. (Bananas work pretty poorly as an example here, I know.) Black only wants that which will help it directly, so it gets little draw. It does pay life for knowledge, however, because it doesn't really think of life as mattering very much, except that final point. So to Black, it's trading something of almost no value for something potentially helpful. Black drains life because it's selfish and it wants everything of yours for itself.

...I got a little off-topic, but still.

247350: Oblation.text_parsed:
Pretty good and always useful, but giving your opponent cards is usually a bad idea and easy to underestimate. I often make opponents draw something nasty with this.

247350: Oblation.author: GordonFreechmen
247350: Oblation.text_parsed:
Well this is certainly a pretty useful card. And I don't feel as bad about using it. If I am going to tuck someones general, I don't want to completely screw them over. This does that. They get two cards. It's not the best trade, but at least they get something out of it. In EDH I like to be competitive, but I like to also end up liked. As politics unfortunately do play a part.

And Sincleanser. I do think that a card having abilities outside it's pool should be taken on an individual basis. If white gain something like lose two life and draw two cards. Or if Red got a straight up counter target spell card. Well that wouldn't really feel right, and I would probably consider rating it lower. This though is rather fitting, it is in a similar vein to Path. Where normally searching for a land isn't a white ability. So I consider it perfectly okay.

247354: Symbiotic Wurm.author: _X_
247354: Symbiotic Wurm.text_parsed:
This guy is a BAMF. Green loves put into graveyard effects as much as come into play effects and getting mass tokens for either effect is great! Surviving a board wipe and getting tons of free tokens is crazy good for green (necessary in EDH) and this guy is a 7/7 for 8 that can make seven tokens - 14 damage for 8 mana and reanimation loves the creature body. Granted there are guys like Wolfbriar and Verdeloth who can create massive tokens with ridiculous mana, but the real heroes of green can produce those effects conditionally instead making them great cards all the time instead of just some of the time. This guy is on par with examples like: Avenger of Zendikar, Regal Force, Woodfall Primus, Mitotic Slime, Yavimaya Elder, Primeval Titan and the other new Command series fatty Hornet Queen.

5/5

247355: Syphon Mind.author: SAUS3
247355: Syphon Mind.text_parsed:
@lorendorky
lol but if Gandlodder's comment was the only comment forever, it would have been hilarious.

This card is definitely only good in multi-player. In a 1v1, it is too weak for the mana cost. In EDH though, you are usually playing multi-player, and if not, it doesn't do absolutely nothing in 1v1, it's just sub-par.

In horde magic though, this card is perfect. It scales with number of players in 2 ways. It hits all the players so it is always strong regardless of how many people are playing, and it draws more cards if there are more players, which means there will be even more stuff to deal with. It's a perfect fit.

247356: Trade Secrets.author: Kitty_the_Kat
247356: Trade Secrets.text_parsed:
To everyone asking, "why doesn't this mill you everytime?"

First, you do not have to draw the 4. The card says you may draw "Up to 4" so if they try to mill you, you can just choose to draw 0.

Second, this is commonly used in conjunction with Niv-Mizzet, the Firemind because of all the political uses of this card. You can build a temporary ally, and take out another player in the process. Alternatively, you can also target the player with Niv-Mizzet as well and have them take 4 damage each time they draw 2.

That, my friends, is how you cannot be milled to death by this card.

247356: Trade Secrets.author: Salient
247356: Trade Secrets.text_parsed:
": Draw four cards. Something something opponent something."

If you're playing Storm combo and use this, presumably you've already played Orim's Chant or Silence. They'll never have a next turn.

This is the weakest of several options for combo-draw, though. Meditate works the same way (you kill your opponent before they have a chance to benefit from the downside), but is at instant speed, so you can play it on the turn you play Reset and High Tide. Also worth looking at: Diminishing Returns.

247356: Trade Secrets.author: MechaKraken
247356: Trade Secrets.text_parsed:
It makes one wonder, why the heck was this reprinted in a commander deck if it would just be banned later? It was a reprint, so play history had to have existed before the commander decks were sold, wizards should have had a good idea of what to expect from games with this card played in them.

On that note, good riddance indeed to this card, it caused the kinds of problems that make a card worthy of banning in the format. If someone had Fate Unraveler or Niv-Mizzet, the firemind out, it could help to protect from abusing this card, but all too often, people would just team up to get an unfair advantage, kill off the other players, and then concentrate on each other. It was the near equavalent of having a Blue Sun's Zenith or Sphinx's Revelation, for just a measly , which meant it could be cast as early as turn 2 or even 1 with the right opening hand, nevermind during the course of the game...

247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: Nagoragama
247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
Spectacular art, but far inferior to original Akroma. Morph and can't be countered have a negative interaction, if you play it as a morph it can be countered, if you hard cast it you don't get to utilize the surprise of morph. White gives her some protection from removal, but blue only helps her evade flying blockers and bounce, and she is at the mercy of black removal and red burn.

The lack of Haste and First Strike might seem odd to some on a red creature like this, but you have to know something about the set it was originally printed in, Planar Chaos. In this set, the color pie is completely mixed up, by design. The universe is coming apart, and everything is in flux. In this set, haste is a green ability and first strike is a black ability.

This Akroma is from an alternate reality where red mana means something different than what it means in the reality we know of.

247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: Zielheim
247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
This is going to sound silly, but I find her to be superior to the original.

The reason why is the number of ways that Wizards effectively gave original Akroma's abilities onto other creatures. Sword of Vengeance gives anything trample, haste, vigilance, and first strike. This one only has trample, so the amount of redundancy is worth equipping onto her if you have the mana for it (even if you can't equip it directly, giving her haste isn't that much of a problem. With 1 red mana, you can play Burst of Speed to let her swing that turn, or have Anger in your graveyard, or have Urabrask the Hidden out as well), and even boosts from having a (semi-)permanent +2/0 as well so even after the opportunity for her to swing immediately passes, there's still some benefit. There's also the memorial which grants ALL of her abilities to everything, effectively making her no more different than a 6/6 you already have, and possibly even inferior if that creature has other abilities, while this one gets almost DOUBLE the amount. Flying, haste, vigilance, trample, first strike, pro black, red, white, and blue, fire breathing, and can either come in as a surprise or can't be countered whatsoever. There's also Geosurge which adds just enough mana to get her out entirely on turn 5, possibly even earlier than that if you have the right cards. If you can get the Sword on her for free, then you have an 8/6 Flier that runs over stuff, hits first, and can block around turn 5. If not, throw a pair of Lightning Greaves on her so she can swing the moment she shows up, then equip the sword onto her after that for a similar experience.

The short story is, Fury is a better combo-piece than Wrath, while Wrath is a better stand-alone creature. At least to me anyway.

247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: DarthParallax
247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
I don't buy the 'Haste is not Red in Planar Chaos' argument. I think they didn't put it here because they wanted her to look different from Wrath.
Problem: Haste is WAY off color for White in anything BUT PC. I think that Akroma of Wrath was literally an excercise in counting the current perennial keyword abilities, and then slapping a mana cost onto it that sounded right at the time.

What would a Flying, First Strike, Haste, Trample, Vigilance, Double Strike, Lifelink, Deathtouch, Hexproof, protection from (something) creature cost, do you think?

even at a 1/1, that sounds like it should probably cost more than 9 mana... >.> I don't buy the 'Haste is not Red in Planar Chaos' argument. I think they didn't put it here because they wanted her to look different from Wrath.

On the flip side, I don't know why you are complaining about Morph and can't be countered on the same card. each are very good. can't be countered rewards you for hardcasting, and morph is riskier but faster. they are opposites, and opposites actually go quite well together for adding functionality-
what you people seem to want, however, is an all-upside card that doesn't require any real decisions to be made. If Morph and uncounterable had the interaction you wish, then there would be very little point to her converted mana cost, and in fact all you did was design an undercosted overpowered super-bomb.

We need more cards that put stuff like uncounterable and morph on the same card. it's healthy to be forced to think and actually make a decision that matters once in a while.

Or, I guess if you get bored you can just give this Sword of Feast and Famine with Akroma's Memorial out and have friggin done with it. But at least you need 3 different cards to do that, not just one.

247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
After playing with this card again I realized something. Akroma, Angel of Fury is Titan level powerful.You can player her early with morph then when you could normally play a titan you just morph her face up and hit for 6 maybe more if she has some equipment or enchantments on her. Granted Akroma, Angel of Wrath is better for reanimate. But aside from that you put them in a deck of their respectful colors red Akroma is going to be hitting first most of the time. If you don't manage to get her early game, just hard caster her with out worrying about silly things like counterspell.

And that is why for me personally, Akroma, Angel of Fury is one of my favorite Creatures of all time. Not because she is super sexy, not because when I play her I imagine a tornado of fire spiraling out of the sky only to clear a moment later as people look up in awe at the sight of her. Or even because when I finally do attack with her it isn't for 6, but closer to 14 points of damage. Or even the fact that I can have all 4 copies of her on the field at once because of morph... Wait.. Those are the exact reasons she is one of my favorites! ;D

247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed: It's weird.  While this is attacking, it's better than the other Akroma because this has firebreathing and trample, so it can do damage to its opponent. 247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: bowlofgumbo
247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
I go back and forth about the superfluousness of Morph to be honest.

Flying, Trample, First Strike, Vigilance, Haste, Double Protection (Wrath)
Flying, Trample, Firebreathing, Uncounterability, Morph , Double Protection (Fury)

While the Morph allows for Fury to hit the battlefield up to two turns sooner than Wrath, seemingly more than making up for the Haste two turns later, the fact remains that all of Wrath's abilities function together seamlessly and two of Fury's never can - you are always implicitly choosing but one of Morph / Uncounterability. That being said, the (risky) option of going Morph is nifty and I'd be lying if I said I didn't love this card.

247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: casual_melvin
247358: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
@Darthparallax

With the exception of suspend and 1 or 2 black cards haste was green in planar chaos.
That said haste is red everywhere else with a few green, black and blue exceptions with white only getting it on akroma and suspend creatures.
So I think you're right about them wanting a bigger contrast.

I can totally see an 8 or 9 mana 5 colored creature getting those abilities. Say:
Powercreep Elemental 4WUBRG
Legendary Creature-Elemental
Flying, Haste, Trample, Vigilance, Double Strike, Lifelink, Deathtouch, Hexproof, Protection from Planeswalkers

If Powercreep Elemental would be put into a graveyard from anywhere, reveal Powercreep Elemental and shuffle it into its owner's library instead
3/3

it'd probably not get first strike, since that's redundant with double strike, and it might lose an ability for landwalk or flash.

It'd almost certainly get the anti-reanimation text and/or phage/ myojin treatment.

Even with all those abilities a 1/1 would look anemic and a 5/5 or bigger might be too good, but a 3/3 with those abilities seems doable at a reasonable cost.

Oh and I suppose I'll add the obligatory, "I grant Wizards of the Coast, Hasbro Inc and all their subsidiaries full right to the above intellectual property without need for compensation"

Though that's probably already in the terms and service for this website.

Now if this ever gets printed you have someone outside wizards to blame =P


P.S. is there reasoning behind the ordering of keywords for cards with more than one?

It's not always alphabetical, though it almost is on greater morphling and
Cairn Wanderer.

Possibly it follows the order in which they're listed in the Comprehensive rules.
