247361: Intet, the Dreamer.author: Discoduck
247361: Intet, the Dreamer.text_parsed:
So much fun! And great colors! She is my favorite general by far.
I would definitely suggest running Leyline of Anticipation or the like with her, as this allows you to empty the exile zone of free-to-play cards before she dies, if that should happen.
Mystical Tutoring into a Time Stretch when Intet's ability triggers is mean, but very good. And kicking a free Rite of Replication on a Bogardan Hellkite or Primeval Titan is super fun. Use the left over mana to activate Riku of Two Reflections as many times as possible. And remember your Fires of Yavimaya!
Crystal Ball and Sphinx of Jwar Isle are two of her favorite friends. With all of the library ordering going on, definitely bring a Lurking Predators to the party.
Also, one of the best instants to have on hold with her is Time Stop. It just is.

247361: Intet, the Dreamer.author: TezzieAgentOfWoona
247361: Intet, the Dreamer.text_parsed:
Here's a question. Let's say your Scion of the Ur-Dragon becomes a copy of Intet and you use the triggered ability to exile the top card of your deck. The effect reads "For as long as Intet remains on the battlefield", but while she never LEAVES the battlefield, she stops being Intet.

So what happens? Can you still cast the cards or what?
247361: Intet, the Dreamer.text_posted:
Here's a question. Let's say your [autocard]Scion of the Ur-Dragon[/autocard] becomes a copy of Intet and you use the triggered ability to exile the top card of your deck. The effect reads "For as long as Intet remains on the battlefield", but while she never LEAVES the battlefield, she stops being Intet. 

So what happens? Can you still cast the cards or what?

247361: Intet, the Dreamer.author: DarkonCrack
247361: Intet, the Dreamer.text_parsed:
@Tezzieagentofwoona: once Scion Dragon of Ur becomes itself again, it would no longer be "Intet" and therefore you wouldn't be able to cast the card. You can still look at it though :P

@Symmes: She plays spells which means they go directly on the stack and are never cast. If you're looking to help your storm count with her, she does have wonderful cascade colors. Put her on the field, next turn swing at the opponent, pay the 3 and exile a Dragonstorm face down, then cast Bloodbraid Elf and get 3 free Dragons for 7 mana :D Also, Maelstrom Wanderer allows you to double cascade when you cast it (also in color) would be a wondrous tech.

@Mhirnatsu: Nope, she'll enter the battlefield as a new permanent, oblivious to her previous existence. But, that won't stop you from exiling more cards :D

On a personal note though, amazingly fun general. For extra kicks and giggles, run with Djinn of Wishes. Just play everything without a mana cost.

247361: Intet, the Dreamer.author: leomistico
247361: Intet, the Dreamer.text_parsed:
I think that Intet is the funniest of the 10 3-color Dragons.
I like to run it in a deck with only a little of library manipulation, so only sometimes I can predict what I will get, and the other times it's only a matter of chance. I find it much more exiting this way.
There is another thing: let say that you get a counterspell with it. You can play always tapped out without worring because you always have a counterspell online. Let's say that your opponent swallow the bait and play a revelant spell, that you counter with the counterspell from under Intet. From now on, your opponent will play in fear to another trick from Intet, so even if you exile a land, as long as you look at it with a tricky face, your opponent would play assuming things that aren't true... For example, when he/she plays something "interesting", always look at the land under Intet, think for about 5 seconds, and then say "Mmmm... Ok, resolve it!". With Intet you can cheat a lot!

My personal chart of the Dragons:
Intet, the Dreamer
Teneb, the Harvester
Crosis, the Purger
Dromar, the Banisher
Numot, the Devastator
Rith, the Awakener
Oros, the Avenger
Darigaaz, the Igniter
Treva, the Renewer
Vorosh, the Hunter

247362: Numot, the Devastator.author: DacenOctavio
247362: Numot, the Devastator.text_parsed:
Numot, the Devastator is my general of choice because:

1) I can run Sunforger into Double Negative.

2) I can run Avalanche Riders into Venser, the Sojourner.

3) I can recycle all of my Sunforged instants with Venser, Trinket Mage, and Elixir of Immortality.

4) I can go "Turn one Serra Ascendant, turn two Looter Il-Kor, turn 3 Jhoira of the Ghitu" and protect them with counterspells and force them through with burn.

5) I can destroy 2 lands per turn when he's online and wearing the Lightning Greaves I tutored for with Muddle the Mixture. My first targets are Maze of Ith and their coolest dual. They never recover.

I really only resort to my general as a last option you see. The rest of the deck is just that good. However, sometimes, you just need to kill some lands.

247362: Numot, the Devastator.author: Zielheim
247362: Numot, the Devastator.text_parsed:
@lorendorky

There's not exactly much in the ways of acceleration for white and blue. Red has some options, but you've got to be pretty lucky to draw into those cards at just the right time.

@ZEvilMustache

No, but destroying two lands IS fun, however. Remember, White and Red are best known for the ways they can get double strike; Assault Strobe, Concerted Effort, Double Cleave, Rage Reflection, Savage Beating, True Conviction, Psychotic Fury, Sunhome, Fortress of the Legion. Those are basically all of the really useful ones that red and white have access to (there's a handful of others, but they do nothing but grant double strike). Combine that with white and blue's various ways of getting creature's through (via unblockability or protection from their creatures), as well as the equipment that gives trample, and Numot's able to get two hits in with relative ease. It's just a matter of if you have the mana to pay for his ability twice. And to be honest, with that kind of fire power, if you're running him as your commander, you shouldn't really need to nuke their lands.

Which actually leads me to the problem with this guy. The other dragons have an effect that are better in my opinion; Oros can hit their field, so if he gets taken out, he's hit them for far worse. Teneb can bring back whatever's dead, which can seriously help you, and Intet, if you get the top of your deck just right, can let you get whatever spell you want for free, which could turn the tide (I'd say he's weaker than Oros or Teneb, but I'd still rather be able to play my top card for free), and Vorosh can end the game in less hits & works with Graft creatures easily. Ok, so hitting two land isn't bad, but compared to some of the damage the others can do? Especially when Oros shares the same 'double strike giving colors' as Numot and Intent and Vorosh share the 'unblockable' blue cards (as well as being able to trample thanks to green)? I think among the five dragons in the pre-cons, Numot is not the best.

247362: Numot, the Devastator.author: vantha
247362: Numot, the Devastator.text_parsed: I understand that he is a mirror of the Invasion dragons which have combat damage triggers. But Destroying 2 lands per turn is just sick. If you attack with him and activate his ability turn 7 your opponent is down to 4 lands (assuming you are going first). Unless they have a board wipe next turn they are shut out of the game. This ability to take out 2 lands per activation is absurd. There is a reason that Magic has gone away from reprinting Stone Rain effects in Red. They want the Red player from being overly obnoxious and they actually want a more strategic game based on decision making. I am glad that Magic is become more mature and strategic for Red.

247364: Pyrohemia.author: Antsache
247364: Pyrohemia.text_parsed:
@ leomistico

"Tom" is a term that originated in the Time Spiral block that usually refers to cards that finally correct a perceived misplacement of an effect/ability that really "belongs" in one color (or that has experienced some other sort of color shift that brings the pie closer to what it "should" look like). The name "Tom" comes from Prodigal Pyromancer, who was given this nickname as a riff on "Tim," the nickname of Prodigal Sorcerer (which I think he got from Monty Python? I was never really clear on that). Before the introduction of "Tom" the unconditional, vanilla "ping" was most commonly printed on blue creatures, despite it feeling much more at home in red's slice of the pie.

This card might be considered a "Tom" in that sense because universal damage is much more commonplace in red than in black. However, I agree with 2097 that it has some problems, mostly stemming from the "at least one creature has to be out" disease angle. That feels very black, and as such this card feels like a cross between a "Tom" and a typical shifted card, with one half bringing red an effect that fits well within its pie, and the other introducing something foreign.

247365: Teneb, the Harvester.author: Arcanoi
247365: Teneb, the Harvester.text_parsed:
@fggmz:
Teneb and Friends' abilities are triggered. An easy way to differentiate is that all activated abilities feature an intervening colon (:) between the cost and effect. If Teneb's ability was activated, it would read

{2}{B}: Put target creature card from a graveyard onto the battlefield under your control. Activate this ability only during a combat damage step in which Teneb has dealt combat damage to a player and only once per combat damage step.

247365: Teneb, the Harvester.author: ParallaxtheRevan
247365: Teneb, the Harvester.text_parsed:
MisterMelancholy: 2 Reasons,

Color Identity. Crosis is non-Green, further more he's Harmony Chorded, not Dissonance Chorded.

He's not in this cycle. A lot of people forget Crosis' Cycle because the old Dominaria flavor/story has been tossed right out the window, so Arcana on the Mothership doesn't even answer questions about it anymore, really.

Crosis, Dromar, Treva, Rith, and Darigaaz were Legendary Primordial Dragons, and I believe Darigaaz' mother was first discovered by Urza. later the 5 Primordials would play semi-pivotal roles in the Invasion Block story. Yes! the Dragons were the GOOD guys against the Evil Phyrexians! Well, kinda.

They were about as pivotal as Progenitus was to Alara's story. Which is to say, Wizards still abuses it's best Legendary creatures in the Block novels -_-


The Oros, Vorosh, Teneb, Intet, and Numot cycle are the Time Spiral fractured reflections of the PRIMORDIAL Dragons, NOT the Elder Dragons. Look carefully at the triggered abilities.

247366: Vorosh, the Hunter.author: DarthParallax
247366: Vorosh, the Hunter.text_parsed:
I don't know...but I really don't get this Dragon :/

First, do we know what the pattern is for the Timeshifts? I.E., all the Time Spiral Dragons were based on Invasion Dragons. Treva is the "White-based" Dragon from the original cycle, Oros is her counterpart.
I supposed as a "Messed Up World" version of Rith, this SORTA makes sense?

Unfortunately, the flavor all other 9 Dragons in the Mega Cycle is so strong and great, and the mechanics are so well tied together for uniting all 3 different colors, that overall this feels at best like a Blue-Green, not a Blue-Green-Black Dragon :/

If it had the ability read: "2B: Destroy target creature. Put X +1/+1 counters on it, where X is that creature's power" it would have been fantastic and felt like a combination of Simic and Sengir Vampire.
I'm just saying- where, if anywhere, is the Black in this? In fact where's the Blue even? (Flying doesn't count for a 3-colored Dragon, even the non-Blue ones get it.)

247366: Vorosh, the Hunter.author: Gheridarigaaz
247366: Vorosh, the Hunter.text_parsed: It annoys me that everyone complains about this guy . So what if he doesnt affect the board with his ability, he comes in colours that are optimal for affecting it... i don't have to say what blue black and green do together. The 3 best colours for card advantage, they practically give you answers for anything. Problem permanents and spells alike, furthermore, all one has to do to make this guy effective as a general is protect him. He's a darksteel plate and a lightning greaves away from being an irremovable threat. Besides that, he's a brilliant voltron commander without having to put voltron cards into the deck, and there's tons of thing you can do to his ability. +1/+1 counters from spike themes, graft, devour, evolve, sage of fables,bramblewood paragon, oona's blackguard and tons more. I've decided this will be my 3 colour general.

247370: Bathe in Light.author: jonrds
247370: Bathe in Light.text_parsed:
Hmm. I feel like they should have gone with "you control" on this card. Given that brave the elements was printed at 1 less mana, this could have been a cool alternative without being too versatile (you still have to at least splash white and have your creatures share colors).

As it is, it doesnt seem worth it, considering you would mainly want to run this in a multicolor deck, in which case you are probably giving your opponent's creatures protection too. It still works decently as an evasion giver, but it seems like it could be a really mediocre (not quite dead) draw too frequently.

Good design for commander though (casting it on your commander gives all your non-colorless creatures protection). Not too obvious like the new commanders with effects equal to the mana you spent on the commander.

247373: Boros Signet.author: kiseki
247373: Boros Signet.text_parsed:
The signets are flexible and efficient (for mana rocks). You can drop them second turn to get four mana a turn early, or you can drop them on turn three and still have two useful mana left over. My favorite manarock (darksteel ingot) has neither of these advantages.
Unfortunately, this is useless after Armageddon, and can leave you unable to split up your two remaining mana over the course of multiple phases.
If you don't need the color fixing, there are better things like everflowing chalice.

Honestly, I think the only reason it has forestwalk is for flavor because of the creature type.

247374: Chorus of the Conclave.author: DarthParallax
247374: Chorus of the Conclave.text_parsed:
this creature is....odd. Personally, I think 3 power is weak. No, I understand that the card is not really overcosted, and it's also not even supposed to be aggressive. It's one of those 'this creature is actually really an enchantment, that also happens to be able to block' cards. That's cool.

Considering Dryads are kinda like Elves, and they're green to boot, I would say you don't even have to think inside the Commander box to realize it's quite playable. Heh-heh: two words Doubling Season?

But, really, the 3 power is still bugging me. Isn't this supposed to be the Guildmasters of the Selesnya? Just like the Forestwalk was clearly a flavor add-on, I think that the flavor of 'Legendary creature cabal that heads the guild' should be worth 4 power at minimum, maybe even 5. Still keep the toughness end much higher than the power, so that people know they are better off blocking with it. But when I block stuff, it would be nice if they actually killed whatever attacked. :p

247374: Chorus of the Conclave.author: Sootoo
247374: Chorus of the Conclave.text_parsed:
Great general for EDH. You just have to know how to build your deck around it.

I think, WotC really should make more Dryads. It´s a shame, there are hundrets of ugly Goblins, but only about 10 Dryads available, although Dryads are such a damn nice creature type (same goes for Sirens btw). An Elf - Dryad with a tap-ramp ability, would be nice, a haste Dryad, for example, or a Dryad Harbinger, etc... More ways to enable the forestwalk ability, and to make it somehow more efficient, also would be nice.

I for one, really like this creature card. It´s nothing which gives you much combo possibilities, or anything (except for playing around with counters of course), but it´s a nice card, if you don´t like to play fatties, but rather weeny creatures. That she´s only a 3/8 doesn´t bother me much too, since she´s mainly there for defense anyway. If anything, it only makes her (or them?) less of a target for removal spells. WotC just should start to care more about the Dryad tribe and their abilities, then this card will get a 4,5/5, or maybe even a 5/5 from me.

But for now it´s only a 4/5. Still great though.

Edit: I`ve just seen a spoiler of the new Return to Ravnica set, and the new Legendary Dryad "Trostani, Selesnya’s Voice" really looks awesome. Definitely going to be my new general in EDH. Some other new dryads too, and other new Selesnya spells, which are quite awesome.

I really hope WotC continue to bring out more Dryads and make them stronger, somehow, because I for one, think it´s one of the nicest creature types ever.

247375: Cleansing Beam.author: Magnor_Criol
247375: Cleansing Beam.text_parsed:
Actually, I think JWolps has a point. If they tried to make every card in a deck amazing there'd be A) an intense demand for the decks filled with completely awesome cards (more so than there already is) and B) there'd be nothing left for players to customize or improve.

I think they actually think through these things when they're deciding what to put in - the customization and improvement of decks is one of the core principles of the game, and leaving in some underwhelming cards gives less experienced players some guidance in the direction to start heading with that.

That being said, there's still no excuse for Slipstream Eel. =p

Actually, I think JWolps has a point. If they tried to make every card in a deck amazing there'd be A) an intense demand for the decks filled with completely awesome cards (more so than there already is) and B) there'd be nothing left for players to customize or improve.  

I think they actually think through these things when they're deciding what to put in - the customization and improvement of decks is one of the core principles of the game, and leaving in some underwhelming cards gives less experienced players some guidance in the direction to start heading with that. 

That being said, there's still no excuse for [autocard]Slipstream Eel[/autocard]. =p

Actually, no, every card couldn't be awesome. That just wouldn't make sense. Wizards never makes preconstructed decks with nothing but awesome cards in them. For one, if they did, no one would buy booster packs because they could just get everything they need from precons. Two, they would likely have to price the decks higher because they give you more valuable and powerful cards. Three, bad cards are made so that good cards look that much better. If you made nothing but really powerful cards, there would still be a large number of cards that got unplayed for being the worst of those powerful cards.

247376: Dimir Aqueduct.author: Salient
247376: Dimir Aqueduct.text_parsed: This is an awesome landfall-utility land, bouncing Bloodghast into play or trigger other landfall effects. The "return a land" is a triggered ability that goes on the stack when Aqueduct comes into play, so this land can bounce itself every turn. Compare to Undiscovered Paradise, which sits out for a turn, vulnerable if an opponent has a Wasteland or topdecks one. With these lands that can bounce themselves, an opponent has to play their Wasteland and leave it untapped, so they can snipe your land before it bounces itself. (And if they do that, you can just choose to not play Dimir Aqueduct that turn.)

247382: Hex.text_parsed:
It's quite easy to see how this is much better for even just three players than two. For people looking to start Commander, who might appreciate this explained:

Instead of Wrathing everything and losing your own creatures, AND getting the board generally mad at you, you pinpoint a bunch of different targets and take out the most threatening one or two guys from everyone. In commander, it almost reads 'Each opponent sacrifices target creature'. Except that the rules team would burn me alive for that wording. But you get the point.

Remember the Iron Man movie? the part with the terrorists and the hostages? this is THAT. kill the things people want dead, leave the rest.

247382: Hex.author: MacBizzle
247382: Hex.text_parsed:
@ge_erskine:

If a spell or ability has a specific number of targets that need to be met, at least one of them needs to still be a valid target before resolution.

If you cast Ashes to Ashes and your opponent does nothing, you will exile both creatures and take 5 damage. If you cast it and he bounces one of them, you still exile the other and take 5 damage. If both of the targets are gone before resolution, the spell is countered and you take no damage.

247383: Hour of Reckoning.author: sarroth
247383: Hour of Reckoning.text_parsed:
@Henrietta: I don't know what you're trying to say there, but I'd go a step forward and say "great" in token decks rather than decent. Token decks are the ones most likely to make this cost the same as Wrath of God except only affect your opponents. And even if you do have to tap all of your creatures to cast this, then you could consider it only "decent," but still, "Tap all your creatures, destroy all your opponent's creatures" is still really good. And in dedicated token decks, say, a Rhys the Redeemed Commander deck, you won't likely be tapping all of your creatures anyway.

I love this card.

247384: Master Warcraft.text_parsed:
@Doaj - Hardly. This is instant speed, and doesn't rely on you attacking with Odric, Master Tactician(and 3+ other creatures as well) to work. Odric's ability is pretty cool, but doesn't allow you to muck with your opponents' combat phase. I like Odric a bunch, but I'd be inclined to run this with him. Not only can you control your opponent blocking when you attack, but you can decide how your opponent attacks you/another opponent, and how that opponent responds to best suit you.

@Anyone who can't figure out how this card works - Consult Rule 506 and the related rules. This card allows you to:

1) Declare attackers on behalf of an opponent. The attacking opponent can still select the player or planeswalker they are targeting.

2) Declare blockers on behalf of the blocking opponent(if it isn't you). This includes declaring which creatures will block, and how they will block(read the "Card Text" on the de***ion page, and not the text printed on the card image; they've clarified it).

247384: Master Warcraft.author: DoragonShinzui
247384: Master Warcraft.text_parsed:
Because apparently reading oracle text is too difficult for people:

"Cast Master Warcraft only before attackers are declared.
You choose which creatures attack this turn.
You choose which creatures block this turn and how those creatures block."

And for emphasis:

"You choose which creatures attack this turn.
You choose which creatures block this turn and how those creatures block."

What does this mean?

You can choose any number of creatures that will then attack this combat phase, if able. You may choose 0 (preventing any creatures from attacking that turn.)

You can choose any number of creatures that will then block this combat phase, if able. You may choose 0 (meaning every creature will remain unblocked, unless some other combat shenanigans happen.)

You may choose what creatures block what creatures. You may force a 1/1 utility creature to block a 5/5 trampler. You may force every single creature an opponent controls to block your deathtouch creature. If a creature cannot legally attack or block (Pacifism, being tapped, etc.) this spell does nothing to them.

I don't know how this card is hard to understand, but there you go. Any questions?

247384: Master Warcraft.author: Mode
247384: Master Warcraft.text_parsed:
It's been said by greg2367 and Gaffy00 before, but be careful to play this card right:
It says "You choose which creatures attack this turn", not "You choose how creatures attack this turn".
You just get a "which", but not the "how" that you get for the blockers.

So while you get to choose one of the attackers for each blocker,
choosing a player or planeswalker for each attacker is the choice Master Warcraft won't allow you to make!

"4/1/2008 If the defending player controls a planeswalker, the person who cast Master Warcraft first chooses the complete group of creatures that are going to attack. Then, for each of those creatures, the active player chooses who or what it's going to attack."

Now I agree that it might be obvious to some players. But it does have counterintuitive potential, so I wouldn't be surprised if this card has been played incorrectly during various multiplayer matches on the kitchen table.

Considering that, and since this is a reprint for a multiplayer set that's also aimed at casual players,
I think a new reminder text for this would have been a great idea to prevent that issue. Something like:

(The active player still chooses which player or planeswalker each attacker attacks.)

247385: Selesnya Evangel.author: Ferlord
247385: Selesnya Evangel.text_parsed:
The thing that lots of people that I know don't understand about the Ghave deck is that it's not primarily a token deck. SURE, your general can make tokens for mana. But the main mechanic's that are important are the +1/+1 counters and the sacrificing. Why do you think Martyr's Bond was made for this deck?

A year after the release of these decks, I got my friend this deck. He tried to make it a strictly token deck and it fumbled. Again, making lots of creatures isn't Ghave's thing. That's Rhys the Redeemed's thing.

Ghave's thing is making a 1/1 token, activating "enter the battlefield" effects (Soul Warden, Cathars' Crusade, etc.), blocking an incoming attacker, and then sacrificing that 1/1, activating "when a creature you control dies (Deathgreeter, Grave Pact, etc.). If you had some way to abuse the +1/+1 counters on Ghave (Blade of the Bloodchief, Sadistic Glee, the aforementioned Cathars' Crusade) or give you additional tokens (Doubling Season/Parallel Lives), you don't even need to pay that extra to regain a counter while killing it as well.

So, in relation to this card, this doesn't fit in a Ghave deck. It fits in a Rhys deck.

What makes this slightly insane is that it's not legendary (it's very clearly a unique place!), which means you can run four in a non-EDH deck safely (presumably you'd be using one's mana ability to help pay for the other's manland ability).

The neat artwork (really does look like the tomb is straining to burst free of the ground and roam) is nice and crisply printed on the Commander card, too.

247390: Szadek, Lord of Secrets.author: Tonymitsu
247390: Szadek, Lord of Secrets.text_parsed:
Probably best played in a Grixis mill style deck.

Turn X- Activate Bloodchief Ascension
Next turn- Cast him
Following Turn- Give him double-strike; very common in red (Assault Strobe, Double Cleave, Psychotic Fury) or artifact (Fireshrieker, Grappling Hook), swing.

Net results:
You mill 15 cards from your opponent, create a 60 point life swing (that opponent lost 30, you gain 30), and you have a 20/20 flyer on the table set to mill 20 (or 60) cards next turn.

247390: Szadek, Lord of Secrets.author: Loren_Lithium
247390: Szadek, Lord of Secrets.text_parsed: I'm running The Mimeoplasm for my edh commander. And when you combine Szadek, Lord of Secrets with a strong booster as part of The Mimeoplasm's ability you can end up decking people out in one hit. Example: I used that exact style (mainly as an accident) and in just a few turns I was making other players deck out by removing all there deck in one hit. I was doing over 160 points of damage, but with Szadek's ability I was making them remove that many cards from their decks. While I wouldn't recommend this as a great way to make friends, it is incredibly effective. Now with that said I would not use him as my commander. He costs way too much for his ability. But if you can cheat him out by using Mimeoplasm or some other mana ramp style he can make a huge difference in the game. Still a solid 5/5 from me though.

@ asandberge

experiment kraj isn't very good with szadek, as his two abilities are not activated abilities.
his first, flying, is a passive ability
his second, the milling and counter doubling, is a triggered ability, not an activated one
spikeshot elder's ability is an activated one, as you choose when to activate it.

the test of a good card is how quickly people try to kill it, and this guy draws a lot of attention, especially in multiplayer formats. hit one person for 5, then 10, then 20, then maybe 40. they're dead
hit another person for 80, they're dead, then another for 160. everyone's dead

doesn't die to doom blade, but does die to the rarer kill cards, like go for the throat or rend flesh

5/5

247390: Szadek, Lord of Secrets.author: Bobth
247390: Szadek, Lord of Secrets.text_parsed:
@Tonymitsu: You don't deal any damage with this card. It adds +1/+1 counters and mills instead of dealing damage.

Here's the total number of cards this combo mills, with no blockers, assuming you play it on turn 7:

Turn 8: 5
Turn 9: 15
Turn 10: 35
Turn 11: 75

With a Fireshrieker (or any form of double strike):

Turn 8: 15
Turn 9: 45
Turn 10: 105

With an Inquisitor's Flail and Fireshrieker (as per Curlie-Joe's suggestion):

Turn 8: 40
Turn 9: 400

Here's the breakdown on that last one...

Turn 8: You start at 5/5, doubled is 10. For the second strike, you start at 15/15, doubled is 30. 10+30=40.
Turn 9: You start at 45/45, doubled is 90. For the second strike, you start at 135/135, doubled is 270. 40+90+270=400.

Seems viable in EDH to me, though the initial casting cost is probably too high to beat the faster and more overpowered commanders.

@AXER - While I do agree that you should use LoE, I also feel this guy would be great alongside him in a BUG Mill deck, where you can Glimpse the Unthinkable and buff this guy buy 10/10, or maybe alongside Wrexial, the Risen Deep, where again; you have him getting a massive buff, FOR FREE. Lord of Extinction gets that buff as well, but he doesn't have any other abilities either, whereas this guy can fly over many attackers. I would also say that throwing Sword of Vengeance and Swiftfoot Boots (or some other form of protection) basically makes him the most powerful thing on the board while he gets stronger.

247391: Vulturous Zombie.text_parsed:
So, I was playing Riku of Two Reflections against The Mimeoplasm. I had around 30 power worth of creatures, all indestructible thanks to my twin Spearbreaker Behemoths, and dropped him to 8 life (against 35). This was the only thing left alive in his board.
Then, he topdecked a Traumatize. This became a 38/38, flew past my tapped creatures and ended the game for me.

TL,DR: this thing is a huge threat, kill it.

247391: Vulturous Zombie.author: SAUS3
247391: Vulturous Zombie.text_parsed:
@Pinto331
Exiling graveyards isn't just for funsies. The reason people do it is because decks that interact with graveyards - if left unchecked - will absolutely demolish everyone. It would be like if there were no removal spells or counterspells. If the green player just ramps up hard and then just play big, fat monster after big, fat monster, you will just get crushed.

I really like the art on this card and it's actually quite powerful. While lord of extinction is better a lot of the time (in terms of P/T), it doesn't have flying or anything of the sort. Since this guy has flying, it won't be chumped as easily and you don't need any support cards for it to be threatening (unless their deck is based around having chump flying blockers).

This card is also an awesome plant zombie. It grows upon anything that dies, and becomes a relentless monster. I'm using it in my horde deck to add fliers to the horde as well as a creature that doesn't immediately mean game over, but will if you leave it there for too long.

247392: Artisan of Kozilek.author: QuietK
247392: Artisan of Kozilek.text_parsed:
@Mithrandir

The effect occurs whenever a creature enters the battlefield. So using Riku of Two Reflections, this gets a bit ridiculous.

Follow me here:

Using Riku and Doubling Season, pay eleven mana, and get back three creatures. Pay an additional six mana, and put out two copies of each of those creatures.

Let's assume you brought back Primeval Titan, Chancellor of the Spires, and Magmatic Force.

For seventeen mana, your board has 94 power, Annihilator 6, six additional lands, you play three lightning bolts at each players upkeep, and you have three Memory Plunder from the Chancellor.

With an additional six mana, whatever you brought out of your opponents graveyards can be copied using Riku, ensuring further devastation.

All of the above is done with twenty three mana.

247392: Artisan of Kozilek.author: Dragon23
247392: Artisan of Kozilek.text_parsed: @QuietK: No, that's not how it works, and Mithrandir is correct. Artisans ability triggers upon casting, not entering the battlefield, so even if Artisan is countered the ability will remain on the stack. If Riku copies an Artisan and you have a creature in the graveyard, you will end up with Artisan, an Artisan token, and the creature from the grave (you could pay more for a copy of that creature too, but I'll leave that to thought). Artisan's ability will only trigger on casting, so in no way if a copy is made will the copy trigger the ability. If we were talking about Karmic Guide or the sort, it'd be different, but it's all about being cast here.
247392: Artisan of Kozilek.text_posted: @QuietK:  No, that's not how it works, and Mithrandir is correct.  Artisans ability triggers upon [i]casting[/i], not entering the battlefield, so even if Artisan is countered the ability will remain on the stack.  If Riku copies an Artisan and you have a creature in the graveyard, you will end up with Artisan, an Artisan token, and the creature from the grave (you could pay more for a copy of that creature too, but I'll leave that to thought).  Artisan's ability will only trigger on casting, so in no way if a copy is made will the copy trigger the ability. 247392: Artisan of Kozilek.author: Bbone37
247392: Artisan of Kozilek.text_parsed:
"Cool thing, is that if he is countered while his ability is still on the stack, you can return himself with his own ability"

I am almost 100% sure that this is not true. His ability triggers when cast, so he is not in the grave at that time to target himself. Your opponent would be able to counter it, but only after you put him on the stack, his ability on the stack, and chose and already-in-the-grave target. Unless I am entirely wrong, and again I strongly believe that I am not, he cannot recur himself since he is not in the grave when you choose his target.

I am almost 100% sure that this is not true. His ability triggers when cast, so he is not in the grave at that time to target himself. Your opponent would be able to counter it, but only after you put him on the stack, his ability on the stack, and chose and already-in-the-grave target. 247393: Awakening Zone.author: Dr.Pingas
247393: Awakening Zone.text_parsed: Skullclamp and Doubling Season are NOT Awakening Zone. But, if that's really what we're going to discuss here, I'd like to point out between the two, I feel Skullclamp was the much more tame option. Sure, it's broken, but I've honestly never seen the appeal. Card Draw is cool and all, but comparing the two; skullclamp is a much poorer return-on-investment engine for empty card-advantage compared to the sheer in-play board presence Doubling Season affords. Cards-in-hand don't mean crap when you can get absolutely insane in-play cardless advantage.

247393: Awakening Zone.author: DoubleTarget
247393: Awakening Zone.text_parsed:
Skullclamp is also about $20 cheaper than Doubling Season so it was highly unlikely that Doubling Season would appear in a precon. Being able to double a planeswalker's loyalty also makes Wizards very afraid of Doubling Season these days. If the deck had come out a little later, Parallel Lives would have been an easy inclusion.

But back to Awakening Zone. It's a good choice for the precon. Eldrazi Spawns are a versatile resource in a Ghave deck. You get a free creature each turn for cards like Aura Shards or newcomer Mentor of the Meek. It can help pay for Ghave's activation costs and it allows you to freely sacrifice creatures for cards like Grave Pact or Martyr's Bond, two cards that appear in other Commander decks.

247394: Disaster Radius.author: sarroth
247394: Disaster Radius.text_parsed: I don't care if this requires another card or costs 7, Red getting mass damage spells to pseudo-Wrath the board is always a good thing. Sure, Red has Earthquake effects, but most of its mass-damage doesn't affect fliers; to that you can turn to this, Pyrohemia, Chain Reaction, and, of course, Blasphemous Act. Although it's usually good that this doesn't hurt your own creatures, it is fun that with the others you can combo them with Stuffy Doll or, in multicolor, VIgor. But still, I like having 4-5 "Wrath effects" in my Commander decks, and this and the others (and colorless options like All is Dust and Oblivion Stone) give you options when choosing Wraths that you didn't always have. I hope to see more Red Wraths that hit fliers as well in the future. Maybe a Join Forces mass damage spell?

247396: Evolving Wilds.author: Aremath
247396: Evolving Wilds.text_parsed:
@Dadanman: Blood Crypt and other shocklands have basic land types but are not, in fact basic lands. Thus, the only card you can search for with this are forest, mountain, swamp. plains, and island, as well as their snow-covered variants. Their type lines start with, "Basic Land -- ", whereas Blood Crypt just has "Land -- Mountain Swamp".

As for the card, I like it. I play a lot of EDH where often colors are more important than amount of mana, especially in the early game, where the game goes pretty slow. Instead of having to fork over for Shadowmoor filter lands or whatever, I can use this common which is worse, but still gives pretty good fixing. As an added bonus, it filters your deck a little bit. I like the art a bit better than Terramorphic Expanse, but the flavor text is slightly worse.

Don't know why it has a rating of below 4 (well, it's basically 4). Works great in any blue control or combo kind of deck. Gomazoa only costs 2U, meaning that if your deck even runs very little blue you should still be able to cast this with relative consistency.

I've played with this card, it's a beast. Every combat phase where your opponent is attacking, think of it like a Maze of Ith of sorts - whatever creature you choose to block will basically not get through unless they waste a burn spell on this guy, which by itself is pretty epic because you've caused your opponent to waste a burn on a creature, and every burn spell can count in a burn vs combo matchup.

@NoFace22
The trampler has to assign a minimum of 3 dmg to the Gomazoa (unless the trampler has deathtouch, in which case only 1 dmg needs to be assigned). The dmg done to Gomazoa is prevented, but any trample damage still hits the player.

247397: Guard Gomazoa.author: CuriousThing
247397: Guard Gomazoa.text_parsed:
@EternalPhi
Lethal damage is defined as damage greater than or equal to a creature's toughness. You can't choose to assign 1 damage with a creature with deathtouch and then trample the rest over. You would still have to assign 3 damage to Gomazoa.
247397: Guard Gomazoa.text_posted:
@EternalPhi
Lethal damage is defined as damage greater than or equal to a creature's toughness. You can't choose to assign 1 damage with a creature with deathtouch and then trample the rest over. You would still have to assign 3 damage to Gomazoa.

247397: Guard Gomazoa.author: UncreativeNameMaker
247397: Guard Gomazoa.text_parsed:
I think I prefer this over Fog Bank. It cost 1 more, but you get quite a bit for that. It can deal damage to what it blocks, and with 3 toughness it's even a pretty decent blocker against trample. Also makes it a little harder to kill with direct damage.

@CuriousThing
Any nonzero amount of damage from a creature with deathtouch counts as lethal damage. So yes a creature with both deathtouch and trample is allowed to assign just 1 damage to a blocker. Which is probably why there aren't any creatures that have both naturally.

247397: Guard Gomazoa.author: andreagrey
247397: Guard Gomazoa.text_parsed:
Ok question for all where this card's effect is concerned, Q: If this creature blocks a creature with trample does trample damage assign to controller if damage is over the defense of the creature?

Rule 615.6. If damage that would be dealt is prevented, it never happens.
A modified event may occur instead, which may in turn trigger abilities.
Note that the modified event may contain instructions that can’t be carried
out, in which case the impossible instruction is simply ignored.

Now as 702.18. Trample, does not exclusivly state that for this instance, it does state that if damage exceeds creatures defense then assign remaining to controller.

247401: Bladewing the Risen.author: SubstantiaNigra
247401: Bladewing the Risen.text_parsed:
I like playing this in my Dragon Reanimator deck.

Turn 1: Swamp; Dark Ritual; Buried Alive; search Bladewing the Risen and 2 other dragons of your choice.

Turn 2: Mountain, tap Swamp, Reanimate (or Exhume if you played a Mox Diamond/Chrome Mox) Bladewing the Risen, and return...

Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund to the battlefield and swing for 11 on turn 2,
or Kilnmouth Dragon and reveal the 2 dragons you had in your hand to get a turn 2 11/11,
or Broodmate Dragon and get 3 4/4 dragons on turn 2,
or Bogardan Hellkite and have it kill that Phyrexian Walker, Vexing Devil, etc. he may have thrown down and have him eat 2 damage,
or Kokusho, the Evening Star and then Fling it to have your opponent lose 10 life and you gain 5 life (can do this by turn 2 if you played Mox Diamond, Chrome Mox or similar in turn 1/2),
or Jugan, the Rising Star and have it give its 5 +1/+1 counters to that Slumbering Dragon you played with your Mountain this turn,
or Yosei, the Morning Star and Fling it later to tap all those nasty 0 cost artifacts your opponent is playing,
or Keiga, the Tide Star if we want to gain control of that Vexing Devil rather than kill it,
or the near-unkillable Skithiryx, the Blight Dragon and have it gain haste if you played a Swamp rather than a Mountain in turn 2,
or the unkillable Zodiac Dragon,
or Thunder Dragon (or Ryusei, the Falling Star if we're going for overkill) and have it kill all those 0 cost artifacts your opponent played in his turn 1,
or Utvara Hellkite and start accumulating 6/6 dragon tokens,
or Scion of the Ur-Dragon to bring any of the friends listed above for later reanimation, whilst becoming a copy of it for 1 turn (possible by turn 3).

The possibilities are endless.

247404: Fierce Empath.author: Aremath
247404: Fierce Empath.text_parsed:
@Narim: It's not great because Primeval Titan is banned in EDH according to the official deckbuilding policy. Of course, if your playgroup is fine with it, that's okay, but it's still important to respect banlists as they help balance the game.

Regarding the card itself, most green tutors look for things the turn they come into play (e.g. Chord of Calling, Green Sun's Zenith) and as a result cost more to cast than the creature they tutor for. If you're fine spending a turn to cast this, you do get to cast your guys on-curve (or sooner, with ramp). As such, it ends up being pretty versatile.

Better in EDH since the first few turns are often slow. Can also often tutor up your general if it got Condemned, which is great.

247404: Fierce Empath.author: drunyon
247404: Fierce Empath.text_parsed:
One of my all-time favorites in green casual decks. Here are some good targets:

1) Primeval Titan if you're using a deck with powerful lands. Fierce Empath typically always tutors for Primeval Titan in my Ezuri, Renegade Leader French EDH deck, where Primeval Titan is legal. Additionally, Empath is an Elf, so he fits great in Elf EDH decks to tutor for your big non-Elf fatties.
2) Regal Force, for card draw.
3) Woodfall Primus, for getting rid of specific annoying permanents (like Ensnaring Bridge, for example).
4) Steel Hellkite, for more general reusable removal and blocking flyers, two things monogreen has a hard time with.
5) Primalcrux, a monogreen casual favorite. If you run 4 of the Empath(which I do), you're effectively running 8 Primalcruxes.
6) Emrakul, the Aeons Torn. I use Fierce Empath in my Cascade Hypergenesis deck just so I can make sure to tutor for Emrakul or one of my other fatties before I cascade into Hypergenesis.

247405: Hunting Pack.author: Aremath
247405: Hunting Pack.text_parsed:
@Rikerblade: That doesn't work the way you think it does. Storm triggers when you cast the spell. When you copy the spell while it's on the stack, you don't cast the copy. You will get one additional beast, since you get one more instance of the effect, but you don't get to double the storm copies. In fact, I don't think there is a card where you get to cast the same spell twice. It wouldn't make very much sense anyways. Casting is when you pay its mana cost and it goes from being a card in your hand to being a spell on the stack.

This card is fun and cool in many ways, and seems like one of the more fair storm cards since you need to spend some effort getting to 7 mana, and mostly you're relying on your opponent to do much of the work for you.

Still, I love it when I get to respond to someone's combat trick with an extra 4/4.

247411: Oni of Wild Places.author: DarthParallax
247411: Oni of Wild Places.text_parsed:
So what I'm hearing is, Rakdos and Malfegor make this guy pretty good.

Rakdos and Malfegor are pretty good on their own without support. I like cards that support each other, but I don't like cards that REQUIRE support in order to be playable. As much as I like the art, and this being the only mono-Red playable Demon in Magic, and he's a spirit, so he's got a LOT of Flavor points going for him but... he's still probably not good enough to make the cut in my deck.

New to Commander, still experimenting, don't judge.

For some reason, the 100-card deck size is proving very problematic for me. With such a large cardpool, I can't decide, and kind of want to play a 125-card deck, or something. Idea: 15 is 25% of 60, right? From now on, I will play Commander with a 25-card sideboard. My logic is infallible.

umm....I thought the EDH crowd was supposed to be tolerant and happy with most cards? able to see the uses clearly instead of being whiny dummies?


1. play a three color general, to get lots of good spells.
2. play mostly in two colors, black will be for spells, not creatures.
3. except this guy. who will hose all the other black decks, with their Mimeoplasms and their Skullbriars and their Karadors and their Ghaves and you get the point.
4. In non-EDH, you can have good enough manabases to where you run 4 of this guy in the sideboard, and no real 'black' sources, just prophetic prisms and the like. use AGAINST black decks.

just because he's a demon spirit, doesn't mean he plays nice with even his own color. Black does anything to win. up to and including betray itself.

247413: Reins of Power.author: DarthParallax
247413: Reins of Power.text_parsed:
There is only one thing I don't like about this card:

At this mana cost, and it being Blue, haste feels wrong.

I know exactly why it's there, but it being there makes this card play a little too much like the Red family of cards. Also this is an Instant. It is bonkers and wrong for Insurrection to cost half the mana, and be an Instant, in flipping Blue. Blue can get away with playing a low-creature deck, thus enabling to really turn this into almost exactly that.

Imagine if it didn't have Haste. It would be much more Blue and more interesting to think how this might be used if that were the case.

247414: Ruination.author: Werewolf-
247414: Ruination.text_parsed:
If you're playing constructed red burn or sligh you're probably better off with Price of Progress; no reason to destroy your opponents' nonbasics before killing them when you can just kill them outright (at instant speed and for fewer, too).

In EDH, though, everything's a singleton, so every card counts--and in an EDH deck that's interested in land destruction effects like Armageddon, you'll often see Ruination, Wildfire, and Destructive Force functioning as 'geddons 2 through 4.

247415: Evincar's Justice.author: DarthParallax
247415: Evincar's Justice.text_parsed:
Black Sun's Zenith I believe is a better choice than Pestilence over this particular card.

1) X cost = more power
2) Buyback trades for 'Zenith' rider as roughly equal value
3) BSZ shares this card's advantage of being a non-permanent- only Blue and a rare handful of other cards can stop it.
4) Zenith rider works well the Demonic Tutor you WILL have in your deck if you are playing Commander

(Since this is the Commander printing, I'm thinking primarily in that context)

I would be quite interested to here someone compare BSZ to Damnation though. Assume that you are thinking of Kaalia's colors, already have plenty of sweepers including the Disk, and were considering BSZ because of it's great versatility. Would you still pick the Damnation for power, and why?

247416: Living Death.author: MisterAction
247416: Living Death.text_parsed:
This card is CRAZY good in Devour for Power. First you cast The Mimeoplasm and exile the two most dangerous creatures in your opponents' graveyards, minimizing the benefit it will grant to anyone but you. Then, once The Mimeoplasm eats a faceful of removal (which shouldn't be long because it's a very popular target), you cast this, bring all your fatties back, and have The Mimeoplasm copy whatever you killed.

So smooth.

247416: Living Death.author: 18scsc
247416: Living Death.text_parsed:
Ahh, good times. One of my favorite turnarounds.

I remember playing with my white solider deck vs my best friend. Through a combination of what could have been called tactical brilliance on my side, and tactical idiocy on his, I manged to wipe out almost his entire field.

I pass, expecting him to surrender. Instead, instead he grins, a maniacal, evil, soul-chilling grin.

He taps 4 swamps, and 3 mountains, flings his last creature at me for 4 damage.

His laughs grow louder.

Then this is slammed on the table, with all of the awful authority of the first nail driving into the coffin.

1 minute - and multiple nails into my coffin - later I turned that little 20 sided dice onto the side with that white "0" marked into it.

247416: Living Death.author: blurrymadness
247416: Living Death.text_parsed:
Often this is the perfect response to a wrath of god in black aggro.
Several reasons:
-They wrathed because you were ahead
-Black has the best gravehate. If you simply bojuka bog main deck you'll likely face little resistance while gaining back your whole board
-Wrath is sometimes used when they are unaffected (indestructible or some such). This kills *anything*.
-Wrath is usually followed with a fatty. Because of that; this guy kills the fatness when it's dropped while preparing you to win the game.

Might I suggest Putrid Imp, Oona's Prowler, Abyssal Persecutor, and Geralf's? Following a curve like that with the appropriate kill or sacrifice cards handy should take the game quite quickly; Living Death just gives you a backup plan.

Best part is? If you didn't need to use it Game 1 (in a tourny) then it's likely they won't side in grave hate.

247417: Propaganda.author: MasterOfBearLore
247417: Propaganda.text_parsed:
I find this generally better than Norn's Annex, for several reasons:

1. If the opponent is playing white, Norn's Annex is five mana or three mana and four life for half the effect of Propaganda.
2. If the opponent attacking will one-swing you, then they'll probably just pay life to hit you. Propaganda doesn't have a life option. You pay two, or you don't get to attack.
3. If you're playing white, you can just use Ghostly Prison instead, as that's usable in most formats besides Standard and Extended.
4. Phyrexia is balls. Urza destroyed it for a reason.
5. Volrath is awesome, and so is Karn.
247417: Propaganda.text_posted:

3. If you're playing white, you can just use [autocard]Ghostly Prison[/autocard] instead, as that's usable in most formats besides Standard and Extended.

247417: Propaganda.author: voyager1
247417: Propaganda.text_parsed:
@ MasterofBearLore:
Except for item four, I completely agree with you. With Norn's Annex, an aggro deck can simply get ahead in a life race (that's what they're designed to do) and then trade life on a one-for-one basis after the Annex hits. The aggro deck doesn't have to slow it's board development at all against it. Propaganda forces aggressive decks to pay the one resource they usually don't have in abundance.

Also, the Annex is an artifact, which (in my metagame, at least) faces a lot more hate than an enchantment does.

247417: Propaganda.author: Iasonas
247417: Propaganda.text_parsed: I have a question and forgive me if it sounds noobish... Why does a player get to pay cumulative costs to attack a creature if there are multiple Propagandas or Ghostly Prisons but don't get to pay a cumulative cost to untap a creature enchanted with multiple Paralyzes?
247417: Propaganda.text_posted: I have a question and forgive me if it sounds noobish... Why does a player get to pay cumulative costs to attack a creature if there are multiple [autocard]Propaganda[/autocard]s or [autocard]Ghostly Prison[/autocard]s but don't get to pay a cumulative cost to untap a creature enchanted with multiple [autocard]Paralyze[/autocard]s?

247417: Propaganda.author: Pinto331
247417: Propaganda.text_parsed:
@Iasonas

Basically it's the difference between "can" and "can't". Multiple instances of Propaganda all say that creatures can't attack unless you pay , so as long as one of those has not been paid that creature can't attack.

Paralyze on the other hand says that you can untap if you pay , so you only need to pay it once to be able to untap it. Additionally, Paralyze only prevents the creature from untapping during the untap step, not during upkeep.

247417: Propaganda.author: CyanCentaur
247417: Propaganda.text_parsed:
hedkaz: No, protection from blue does not counter this card. Creatures with protection from blue would need to pay to attack you.
Protection from a color grants very specific protections, commonly: a) immunity to damage from that color, b) can't be blocked by a creature of that color, c) can't be targeted by that color. Protection from a color does not stop global effects created by a spell or permanent of that color.
247417: Propaganda.text_posted:

247417: Propaganda.author: Ferlord
247417: Propaganda.text_parsed:
In almost all situations, unless they aren't playing creatures (They probably are. You'd only use this for casual play), they're going to pay a minimum of after you've played this. Either they're attacking with just one creature, or they're playing Naturalize/ something of the sort. One way or another, they're now going to have to go around it. It can mean the difference of whether they can hard-cast Kozilek, Butcher of Truth.

In most situations, though, you'll make them pay more. There are usually more permanents that deserve more hate. I've seen people playing something like Woodfall Primus, just to remove something small like Bloodchief Ascension because it had 1 counter on it... while Grave Pact was out (In retrospect, it was probably more wise). In short, they spent to remove something that cost . That's not too out-of-the-ordinary.

So one way or another, you're going to make your opponents pay more mana than they need to.

247513: Dreadship Reef.author: Missile_Penguin
247513: Dreadship Reef.text_parsed:
Nearly every single Time Spiral card was an homage to at least one previously printed card.

This card is part of a five-card cycle referencing the various kinds of "storage lands;" the first were in Fallen Empires (Icatian Store, et al) then tried again in Mercadian Masques (Subterranean Hangar, et al). This cycle became easily the most successful, finding a way to make the 'storage' part of the land less-clunky, promoting some entrants in this cycle to appear in tournament-caliber constructed decks.
247513: Dreadship Reef.text_posted:
[b]Nearly every single [i]Time Spiral[/i] card was an homage to at least one previously printed card.[/b]

This cycle became easily the most successful, finding a way to make the 'storage' part of the land less-clunky, promoting some entrants in this cycle to appear in tournament-caliber constructed decks.

247519: Triskelavus.author: diabloknk
247519: Triskelavus.text_parsed:
So a Triskelion and a Pentavus glued together and given wings? The idea is funny, but it doesn't really excite me, especially since this card loses trisk's interaction with basilisk collar or anything else that would give it deathtouch, and also can't produce as many tokens as pentavus, nor can it sacrifice those tokens to be put back onto itself in the form of counters.

So at first it does seem like it's truly a triskelion + pentavus, but when you think about it, it's only half of each, and doesn't seem to work all that well.

247520: Avatar of Woe.author: Justice1337
247520: Avatar of Woe.text_parsed:
Wow, this card really outclasses all of the other Avatars by far. For reducing it's mana cost, the condition it requires isn't something that's disfavorable to you, as in Avatar of Might and Avatar of Hope. Insead the condition is neutral to favorable, since when you're in black you often have reasons to have creatures in your own grave, and means to kill creatures of your opponents. To boot, it has the best evasion, fear instead of trample or flying, and the best ability, Terminate versus Firebreathing and the like. I mean, comparing to the other avatars is just silly. This one really just stands on its own.

My advice on how to use it? Let the board get big enough, cast Jokulhaups floating BB, lay it down on resolution. The land destruction serves to protect it, and your opponent's will be hard pressed to play any creatures.

247522: Attrition.author: graey24601
247522: Attrition.text_parsed: @Chiky911 No real benefit in having more than one out. You'd still have to pay the full cost (including the sacrifice) for each nonblack creature you wanted to destroy. The way these things work is "cost : effect" so everything to the left of the colon has to be paid anytime you want the effect on the right of the colon. On permanents without a tap symbol in the cost you can simply repeat the process as many times as you wish (and can afford).

247523: False Prophet.author: yyukichigai
247523: False Prophet.text_parsed:
I have decided this guy is named Bob. Why? He kind of looks like a Bob. Also, its really fun to shout, "Beware the Wrath of Bob!"

Classic board intimidation if ever there were. Costs the same as a Wrath of God, but removes things way more permanently with the trade-off that you have to find some way to kill it. Plenty of options for that: attacking, blocking, Doom Blade.... My personal favorite method is "sacrifice" costs like Fling: because they're costs, rather than effects, your opponent(s) can't bounce/exile/etc. the prophet to stop it from telling everyone else to do the 200 meter dash off of a 7-foot-long ledge. They can still respond to the effect itself of course, but that's usually a lot harder to do.

@SkyknightXi: Yeah, flinging yourself from a cliff wouldn't really make Serra feel all warm and fuzzy, but then again this guy is a False Prophet for a reason.

247524: Yavimaya Elder.author: DarthParallax
247524: Yavimaya Elder.text_parsed:
The best green draw spell. I looked em up. Search 'Community Rating > 4', Green, Rules Text= Draw Cards.

Magus of the Library and Sylvan Library are arguably stronger, but Magus is really just a Library of Alexandria shout-out, so I don't count it, and Sylvan Library is not a creature, so I like Y. Elder for fitting Green's flavor better: We've recently seen a ton of 'just good stuff' creatures with extra abilities, and I think it's going a bit too far, but Green should always have Creatures that can do the work of Spells.

As for the other cards, the Dredge Mechanic turned out to be too strong, so those cards don't count the same way Magus of the Library doesn't count: 'needs Development'. (Magus also isn't all that Green-flavored)

If you take into account, in ADDITION to Tournament Worthiness-- Mechanics are Flavorful, Friendly for Fun, and Overall Balance, then this card sits somewhere either a little better than or a little worse than Solemn Simulacrum, and neither Artifacts nor Green should ever get a card that makes either of these two appear to be pale by comparison. That is an excellent standard to look for 'power creep'. It just doesn't get better than Yavimaya Elder. Or shouldn't.

247524: Yavimaya Elder.author: Brawler_1337
247524: Yavimaya Elder.text_parsed:
Any Green EDH deck should probably make room to run this. You can Natural Order sacking him to get a creature plus two lands. Uril decks can hook up Pattern of Rebirth to him, then make him kill himself for a creature plus 3 more cards. Or you can simply get a +2 any time you have open (maybe an unused Sol Ring?). This guy is very playable.

However, he's playable because he's pretty broken. (What else would you expect from Urza block?) Alone, he's a 3 mana +2 that only requires waiting a turn to use, and he ensures that you have your land drop for two turns. Have more mana open? You can do it right away. That's not even including the numerous other ways to abuse his death effect. Let's hope cheap Green creatures don't end up getting much more useful than this.

I'll give him a 4/5 for usability, but I'm considering lowering that score because of balance issues.

247525: Mother of Runes.author: JaxsonBateman
247525: Mother of Runes.text_parsed:
One of, if not *the* best one drop in white, simply because it's often relevant at any point in a game - early game, it can stop any non-evasive defender without being a chump. Late game, it still causes your opponent to double-remove any of your creatures, provided you're not forced to prematurely activate the ability for any reason.

Part of my standard 20-card early game for any mid/late game monowhite decks I run with (the other 16 cards being 4-ofs of O-Ring, Wrath, Wall of Omens and Swords), and rarely disappoints.

@Dankirk: I'm curious; why do you call it spell bounce? It sounds like you think a spell that's countered due to illegal targets goes back to the hand; in reality its outright countered and goes to the graveyard.

247525: Mother of Runes.author: Nagoragama
247525: Mother of Runes.text_parsed: This card seems pretty good at first glance.  However, you don't truly understand the sheer power of this card until you play it or play against it.  It can make your creatures unblockable.  It counters removal.  Its mere presence on the field totally changes the way your opponent plays, forcing him to consider what you're going to do next with it with every move he makes.  One of the best 1 drops in the game.

247526: Congregate.author: kiseki
247526: Congregate.text_parsed:
This card kills much of the fun in a multiplayer setting when it comes out.
On the Urza's side of this cards comments, someone posted that we should use more board sweepers. This card is most often used, in my experience, as a response to board wipers, leaving someone with a painful about of life (60-100+ is not uncommon). I don't want to kill every player in casual multiplayer by turn four, and if you know their deck has the card focusing on someone who hasn't put any power on the board is seen as puppy kicking. Cards like this create a catch-22 in those situations. You can't have fun because there is too much life to widdle down, or you can't have fun because your best friend got taken out in the first 20 minutes of a 2-hour game.

This is a classic example of an instant that should have been a sorcery.
Can be so much fun mid combat when you have a pair of Kavu Predators coming in hot.
It can also help you transform Chalice of Life a few phases before your turn.

247528: Fog Bank.author: Salient
247528: Fog Bank.text_parsed:
For those who like puzzles: what's really surprising about Fog Bank is just how few attackers can manage to kill it (without the need to activate an ability or cast a spell). There are fewer than ten creature cards with the property "If this creature attacks and Fog Bank blocks it, Fog Bank will die."

Finding even that many takes some work. The obvious place is to browse through Cockatrice-type creatures -- but many of these either specify non-Wall, or require damage to be dealt, etc.

For those who like puzzles, there's at least one of each color, including colorless. I'll spot you the funniest one: Fog Bank dies to Goblin Swine-Rider.

"May you get the noxious pig farts you deserve."
—Suq'Ata curse

Happy hunting...

TPmanW: "I don't think I've ever seen a card that was so heavily effected by combat damage being removed from the stack."

No, this was affected not at all by the M10 combat damage change. Its ability has ALWAYS changed its controller (and thereby removed it from combat) before even first-strike damage happens.

The only way it deals combat damage at all is if it attacks and is unblocked.

247532: Windfall.author: RowanKeltizar
247532: Windfall.text_parsed:
I'm giving Windfall a 5/5 Why?

Hand-cycling is the core and foundation my Niv-Mizzet, the Firemind EDH deck. And in that deck, Windfall is a star player.

Hand-cycling in and of itself is very powerful, under-utilized, and under-rated. It allows you to cycle through your deck and play the cards you need at that specific point in the game. At its best it's almost like having your whole deck in your hand at once (and many times you actually do).

So what's so great about Windfall?

There are two distinct types of hand-cycling. Draw 7 and replacement.

The draw 7's allow you to refill your hand quickly after casting a bunch of spells. They are excellent cards to have in your starting hand and very nice early draws (the cheaper ones). In addition to refilling your own hand, they tend to screw up your opponents carefully mulliganed and tutored hands. They aren't so great in late game because you'll already have a large hand. Without Sphinx in play you will be netting less cards. The most well known draw 7 is Timetwister

Replacement hand-cycling is great in combo with Niv because you'll likely deal the most damage. With one red mana you can cast Winds of Change and deal a ton of damage to some very unfortunate critters or players. They are great to have in your hand late game, but not as good early game.

Windfall is actually a hybrid between the two types and is unique as far as I know (aside from Jace's Archivist. Early game it usually re-fills your hand just like Wheel of Fortune. Late-game it can deal a ton of damage with Niv in play when you have a larger hand... and you get to keep that hand-size. With Consecrated Sphinx in play it's just ridiculous.

247532: Windfall.author: ParallaxtheRevan
247532: Windfall.text_parsed:
Windfall is one of The Best 'draw cards' effects in the game- yet, it's two-sided, and while it certainly allows shenanigans in any deck that can touch its own graveyard (graveyard manipulation is best when you can hit your own as well, relying on your opponent's graveyard for anything other than Tarmogoyf is probably not a safe gamble), at the same time, it seems pretty well balanced- Not an Instant, and OUTSIDE shenanigans, 'really big Loot' is fair and cool.

M12 brought us this ability on a stick at Rare- actually, that card is a little worse than this because in addition to being countered, creatures' abilities can be turned off, and they can be killed, forced to block, fight, exiled...oh Jace's Archivist is good, but it's not what they call ''consistent''.

I have a dangerous question: Is Windfall safe to put on a Planeswalker? NOT for 0, obviously- but- maybe for -2? -3? I liked the idea of a tricky, not-just Draw ability on a Planeswalker when Jace 2 came out. Development is who failed there, not Design. Who thinks Windfall should be a Planeswalker ability?

247533: Sol Ring.author: BegleOne
247533: Sol Ring.text_parsed:
You guys are joking, right? This shouldn't be anywhere near EDH. Then again, Wizards probably shouldn't be anywhere near EDH either.

EDIT: So since I have the lowest-rated comment on this card, let me explain. This is a ridiculously powerful card; banned in Legacy, after all. As a 1 mana utility artifact; I can't think of a single EDH deck it doesn't make better. If a card is a star in every deck, it's too good; that's one of the definitions of "broken", like Rishadan Port was in Masques. If you draw it early in EDH, you have a massive advantage over the guy that doesn't; EDH is best a grand exercise in deck-building synergy and strategy, while Sol Ring is just too damn good in everything and does its part in reducing the game to luck of the draw.

Now, since EDH games go long and this isn't the greatest of draws after you have 10 or so mana, I'm not THAT opposed to it when there are better things I can complain about like Command Tower, which is a better example of a card that just should not be. "Hey fellow WotCr's, lets print the best land card in every EDH deck ever and make buying our sealed decks the only way to get it!" Like I said, they should just stay out of it.

247533: Sol Ring.author: Asmodi0000
247533: Sol Ring.text_parsed:
I understand that EDH is a longer format that makes the first couple of turns less important, and it's rather difficult to truly abuse this card with combos in a singleton format, but I still don't approve of this card being reprinted so... casually.

It's not a card that belongs on the casual table. Before the commander sets came out, I had purchased a Sol Ring, and after only playing with it a few times, I was convinced that it made the game less fun and that I was better off not playing with it. It's a brutal fountain of power that skews the game decisively in your direction, which is one of the reasons it's considered one of the major contenders for the "Power 10".

It's good that it made the commander sets even more of a worthwhile purchase, but it's as if Wizards is trying to say that it is a well-designed card that they're willing to reprint as perfectly playable. When it was released in the Exiled: From the Vault set, people knew that it was broken, and its new mythic rarity status helped cement that notion.

Reprinting it in decks designed for multiplayer, casual games with uncommon status just sends the wrong message, that this card is balanced, which it clearly isn't. If you manage to get one out, but your opponent doesn't, the scales are tipped so far in your favor that it's not even like you're playing the same game anymore. He's trying to climb a hill while you're rolling down stones at him.

But, I will say this. It does let new players have a chance against more experienced/richer opponents. If they are using a sol ring, you should have access to one as well. Though neither of you should really be using it, if he pulls out a gun, you should have a gun too. Why you're playing with a person like that, I don't know, but it happens and it's good to be prepared.

That's why if Wizards reprinted the Moxes, Black Lotus, and all those other cards that are worth hundreds of dollars, I would support that wholeheartedly. After watching people in game stores toting around decks with Moats and Library of Alexandrias play against people with decks made out of cards they got from their first prerelease, I think I understand the value of providing people with the weapons, even if they're not supposed to use them on a day-to-day basis.

247533: Sol Ring.author: UsagiYojimbo
247533: Sol Ring.text_parsed:
Miss Mox: Hello Ms. Sol Ring your application for status as the missing Mox has been, unfortunately, denied.

Sol Ring: That can't be right, I have all the qualifications. I'm a mana artifact that costs {0}.

Miss Mox: *ahem* Well, I'll agree you "effectively" cost {0}, but only if colored mana isn't relevant.

Sol Ring: Exactly, and I tap for {2}! That's something that the Moxen can't do! And I don't have a drawback, like those newfangled new Moxen.

Miss Mox: Yes, well, colored mana is very important, and you only tap for {2} the turn after you're cast. I'm afraid the Moxen have very, very high standards. The best I can do is offer you status in the Slightly Less Powerful Than the Moxen Club. Slightly less prestigious, sure, but it still sets you above almost every other card ever printed.

Sol Ring: Oh, well when you put it like that... I'll take it!

247534: Veteran Explorer.author: Mode
247534: Veteran Explorer.text_parsed:
Fun in eternal formats, where your opponents might not even have basic lands.

But that's not the only reason why i love that card.
It's fun with Landfall obviously. Big mana ramp time with Lotus Cobra!
And I've got a deck that uses Greater Gargodon as sac outlet along with cip triggers, and double them with effects like Planar Birth, Second Sunrise, Saffi Eriksdotter or Angelic Renewal.

I wouldn't call Lavaball Trap such a great combo by the way, on the one hand he does not have to search (let alone find) any lands to put into play. That card's more interesting for Zendikar block constructed, since you can expect your opponents to put multiple lands into play automatically. In other formats you could mainly hope for your opponent to use fetchlands.

Oh, and he's a soldier. This might some day come in handy for tribal if we get more besides Hidden Guerrillas and him :P

247534: Veteran Explorer.author: alexanderwales218
247534: Veteran Explorer.text_parsed:
This is a wonderful EDH/Commander card, both because it's political, and because your deck can usually see a big benefit from having more mana.

Veteran Explorer is best in the kind of deck that can sacrifice him right before your turn, so that you get the benefit before your opponent does. I once sacced him to Carrion Feeder on turn two, which gave me enough mana on turn three to Plow Under his lands and slow him down immensely. The turn after that, I had six mana and he was drawing into nothing.

247534: Veteran Explorer.author: Kelptic183
247534: Veteran Explorer.text_parsed: Accidently went(effectively) infinite with him in my Ghave deck. He was in an opponent's grave, I summoned Puppeteer Clique and brought him back, sacced him to Ghave to get 2 lands. 247537: Butcher of Malakir.author: beefrocks
247537: Butcher of Malakir.text_parsed:
@greg2367 1) "Dies" is a rather violent term; it indicates a presence of life that is no longer there. Magic didn't really want to be one of "those" games. It's just a game, so your cards can't actually "die."
2) "Dies" was actually adopted by Magic, after this card was printed. If can find one old card--just one--that uses "dies," "kills," or "killed" to refer to a creature going to the graveyard from battle or sending a creature to the graveyard from battle, you will have earned my lifelong respect.
3) Death is known as being a permanent state, whereas being "in a graveyard" is something that changes rapidly (It's my job to change it! Here I Rule). As the hag from Prince Caspian said, "Have you ever heard of a witch who truly died? There's always some way to bring them back...."
4) Creatures are "summoned," and then they have "summoning sickness." Then, eventually, they are "sacrificed" or "destroyed." After that, they are either "regenerated" or "put into the graveyard." None of these terms--I repeat, none--are used to refer to the basic human life cycle. When you start to use anthropomorphic terms, you start to bond with those creatures. However, you are a planeswalker. You don't bond with them. You use them in whatever way you see fit.
5) The way this card is printed has been commonly accepted MTG vernacular for many years. (Starts fake "crotchety old man" voice) You punk whippersnappers coming in with yer fancy new words, tryin' to change the way we done it since before yer gran'pappy was in diapers, why, I just got one thing to say to that: "YOU ROTTEN KIDS GET OFF MY LAWN!"(Stops fake "crotchety old man" voice)

@lorendorky The problem, really, is that vampires are black's way of trying to imitate blue. Instead of trying to imitate other colors, they should be trying to create some more originals. Like zombies. However, I, being predisposed to blue anyway, do tend to enjoy a vampire or two every now and then.

247539: Comet Storm.author: sonorhC
247539: Comet Storm.text_parsed:
Fireball was always my favorite of the X red burn spells, because of its ability to hit multiple targets (it's not often that red gets card advantage). But this is Fireball on steroids. Or possibly super-soldier serum. It's so fun to be able to say "Let's see... I need five mana to kill that one creature that's really annoying me, leaving me three mana... I guess I'll kill those other two creatures, too, and also blast my opponent's face".

Vocabulary lesson, by the way: Comet Storm is far, far better than Blaze: You'd be a fool to run Blaze in any deck, but you'd also be a fool to not run Comet Storm in any red deck if you had it. Despite this, however, Comet Storm is not strictly better than Blaze, since Blaze is a little bit cheaper for a single target. The "strictly" in "strictly better" doesn't just mean "a whole lot better".

247539: Comet Storm.author: RegalFanton
247539: Comet Storm.text_parsed:
"Interesting idea I had, if I were to Redirect my comet storm could I avoid the 'another' clause entirely?"

No, that would not work, since the targeting restrictions for the original spell still apply. For example, a Redirected Doom Blade still has to target a non-black creature. So in short, if you Redirect Comet Storm, you still must choose separate and distinct targets. Also, remember that for each time it is kicked you MUST choose a legal target.
247539: Comet Storm.text_posted:
"Interesting idea I had, if I were to [autocard]Redirect[/autocard] my comet storm could I avoid the 'another' clause entirely?"

No, that would not work, since the targeting restrictions for the original spell still apply. For example, a Redirected [autocard]Doom Blade[/autocard] still has to target a non-black creature.  So in short, if you Redirect Comet Storm, you still must choose separate and distinct targets.  Also, remember that for each time it is kicked you MUST choose a legal target.

247539: Comet Storm.author: ZealousEntropy
247539: Comet Storm.text_parsed:
If anyone's still confused about how to figure this card out, think of it this way:

You pay RR to summon one comet. You can spend more mana to adjust either the size of the comet (X) or to summon additional, equally large comets (multikicker).

e.g. a size 5 comet with four targets costs RR (first comet) + 5 (size) + 3 (additional comets) = RR8.
