247540: Lightkeeper of Emeria.author: Salient
247540: Lightkeeper of Emeria.text_parsed:
Lovable. I wouldn't build an EDH angel deck without this, especially mono-white. Even if it's underpowered, paying massive amounts to its multikicker is fun. :)

Weird choice for a reprint, though. You wouldn't want to cheat this into play with Kaalia (can't pay multikicker), it doesn't do anything unusual or cool when Oros fires off his ability (any white creature dodges it), and it doesn't do anything for Tariel... the white mana requirement's restrictive, I've gotten 6 life at best.

If you like the kickery feel of Lightkeeper, try Degavolver as a fun -friendly alternative. If you like the mana-dumping, consider Figure of Destiny or Transcendent Master. (All three are good with Oros.) For solid lifegain, try Shattered Angel, Wall of Reverence, or Auriok Champion. (These play well with Oros and Kaalia; the latter two are excellent with Tariel.)

247542: Wrexial, the Risen Deep.author: MisterAction
247542: Wrexial, the Risen Deep.text_parsed:
This guy is beautiful as one of many things in the toolbox of my The Mimeoplasm EDH deck; sometimes there's an awesome spell in your opponent's graveyard, and when that happens it's satisfying to the point of being story-worthy (such as when he accomplished exactly what Mr. Nagle intended) .

However, he didn't shine the way I hoped when I gave him his own commandership. Mainly because I keep running into decks that don't use instants and sorceries! EDH is all about getting the most use out of each card, and creatures with abilities are often much more repeatable and versatile. Qasali Pridemage and Acidic Slime see play in nearly every deck that can run them, but I don't see a lot of EDH decks mainboarding Naturalize.

Awesome card, can win you the game with correct timing, but don't rely too heavily on him.

247545: Cobra Trap.author: fissionessence
247545: Cobra Trap.text_parsed:
Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #9 - 7/5/2011 - Cobra Trap

This is the kind of card I really want to like. I'm not sure why, but I tend to like Snakes in Magic, even the ones from Kamigawa block . . . kind of. You know, the Orochi. I also like creature tokens. I also like the idea of the Traps.

Things I don't like: Paying six mana for four power and having a really awkward and impossible-to-rely-on trap cost.

Cards like this really frustrate me. I want to play them so much, but they're just not good enough to even count on using in my casual decks. Recently this was printed in one of the Commander decks, and I'd like to see if anyone tries to stick with it. I played a little bit of limited during Zendikar block, and I don't remember ever seeing this spell cast. I'll keep my eye out.

As far as the possibility of me ever using this card . . . I'd really have to find a deck that synergized well enough that six mana for four 1/1s felt worth it. Perhaps with Muraganda Petroglyphs and True Conviction. Oh wait, nombo.

@Townend_GLS

First, use Gomazoa to block an opponent's creature, then tap it and use the ability to put both Gomazoa and the creature it's blocking on top of you and your opponent's libraries' respectively, and then shuffle it.

247547: Journey to Nowhere.author: P.Dockeray
247547: Journey to Nowhere.text_parsed:
The only ruling on this card is- "If Journey to Nowhere leaves the battlefield before its first ability has resolved, its second ability will trigger and do nothing. Then its first ability will resolve and exile the targeted creature forever."

Can someone explain to me how this can happen?
247547: Journey to Nowhere.text_posted:
The only ruling on this card is- "If Journey to Nowhere leaves the battlefield before its first ability has resolved, its second ability will trigger and do nothing. Then its first ability will resolve and exile the targeted creature forever."

Can someone explain to me how this can happen?

247547: Journey to Nowhere.author: Keldane
247547: Journey to Nowhere.text_parsed:
@ P.Dockeray

Your question is related to the stack and the wording of Journey to Nowhere. Its first ability, which exiles a creature, doesn't go on the stack until the enchantment enters the battlefield, so if someone responds to the ability going on the stack by destroying Journey at instant speed, the 'return creature to play' ability goes on the stack on top of the 'exile target creature' ability. The return ability resolves first, attempting to return a creature that isn't exiled yet, then the exile ability resolves, putting the creature outside the game.

Basically, don't destroy Journey before it's finished exiling something if you want to get it back.

@ merigold

If a commander would be put into the graveyard or exile zones, you may choose to put it into the command zone instead. Using Journey to Nowhere or Oblivion Ring on a commander is therefore not recommended, since they can just come back. Instead, consider Oblation or similar 'into library' effects, as that makes them vanish much more effectively.

247550: Punishing Fire.author: TherealphatMatt
247550: Punishing Fire.text_parsed:
This is too amusing not to share....

I was playing Duels of the Planeswalkers 2012 online the other day, against a guy using jace's deck. Now, this guy was obviously new ... his deck had about 70 cards in it and he was using Kraken's Eye. I was playing Chandra's deck, and I drew into this and Chandra's Phoenix.

Poor bastard couldn't play a spell without me getting my fire back, banged him on the head with it, then recast my Phoenix, which would then suicidally attack into his creatures, trading for them or doing damage that he couldn't afford to take. After a couple turns of this I finished him with a Lava Axe. I like to think he learned something.

The art for this card resembles Sunforger.
If you've bought Political Puppets pre-con, I suggest getting rid of this card, because it doesn't do well in EDH at all, and, most important, is not synergetic with Zedruu the Greathearted. You can include some more worthwhile cards, like the aforementioned Sunforger, which can be very helpful with cards like Oblation, Chaos Warp and Wild Ricochet, all conveniently placed in your deck by WotC.

247550: Punishing Fire.author: Wisdomseyes
247550: Punishing Fire.text_parsed:
"This is too amusing not to share....

I was playing Duels of the Planeswalkers 2012 online the other day, against a guy using jace's deck. Now, this guy was obviously new ... his deck had about 70 cards in it and he was using Kraken's Eye. I was playing Chandra's deck, and I drew into this and Chandra's Phoenix.

Poor bastard couldn't play a spell without me getting my fire back, banged him on the head with it, then recast my Phoenix, which would then suicidally attack into his creatures, trading for them or doing damage that he couldn't afford to take. After a couple turns of this I finished him with a Lava Axe. I like to think he learned something."

If you expect to go onto Duels of the Planeswalkers and find any players with an ounce of skill, you will be looking for a very long time. That is similar to looking for a needle in a heystack. You can find it, but not often enough for it to matter.

Onto the card. I can see its card advantage potential. Opponents gain life (which you can make them as said in a previous comment) and you get it back. This was run in the zoo pre ban. Now, i am betting that it was run more for the creature control than for the actual damage. 3 mana for 1 damage isnt all that spectacular. All this card says is that you will always be able to have it in your hand, something red mages crave. Why else would grim lavamancer be used in every red deck wins up to this day?

247550: Punishing Fire.author: blurrymadness
247550: Punishing Fire.text_parsed:
As much as I'm not huge on TheWrathofShane, his comment points out an interesting set of similarities between this and Cursed Scroll
-2 damage that is repeatable
-Costs 3 to repeat
-Requires a small amount of deck tailoring to use properly

The main bonuses that you get out of this, however, are:
-You can't get rid of it without exile effects
-You can pay for it with a payment plan
-You can discard it to other cards without issue for card advantage elsewhere

The bonuses of the scroll are that:
-It's colorless
-Not weak to gravehate
-Requires no specific synergy to work

Both are great Legacy control pieces and even find themselves at the kitchen table :)

247552: Vampire Nighthawk.author: Salient
247552: Vampire Nighthawk.text_parsed:
Since there's lots of comparisons in the other comments: Honestly, I'd rather have this guy poking me for 2 a turn than Hypnotic Specter. Losing even one card randomly from my hand can wreck my strategy, whereas a total life swing of 4 can be survived for a couple turns while I try to draw an answer.

I'm glad Wizards makes cards like this uncommon more frequently nowadays. It's nice to get a playset of cool playable Vampires by just cracking some packs instead of pulling up eBay.

I like that this vamp's a Shaman. It's a neat, unexpected flavor that also justifies the abilities -- it seems like the lifelink and deathtouch come from this supposedly-spiritless creature of the night's spiritual connection to the natural world. You can imagine Nighthawk ritualistically self-painting shamanistic markings along its own arms while it sits in your hand, waiting to be cast into the world.

247552: Vampire Nighthawk.author: Ferlord

WHY isn't this card rated higher?

Come on. There has to be some sort of conspiracy or Internet-Meme thing going on (like the whole Storm Crow thing, as amazing at it is). This card is in no way bad.

Maybe some people think it's not good enough because it is Lightning Boltable. However, it's just for 3 CMC, so that isn't as bad a trade as if you lost your Gigantomancer like that.

Maybe it's because it is 2 black and 1 colourless, but if you're complaining about that, then Phyrexian Obliterator should have a rating of 2/5.

I see nothing wrong with it, and yet, it isn't too that broken. A staple for ANY black strategy as well as any other deck with black in it (except the Coalition deck, of course)

249805: Island.author: marmaris74
249805: Island.text_parsed: I think you are all missing just how good this card is. I mean, c'mon, this is like practically a mox. This is a staple in any counterspell deck. Seriously, zero cmc and it can tap to add {U}. Not to mention that it triggers landfall. And seriously, why in the world did wizards decide that this card shouldn't be affected by the four-card rule? Plus, this combos with so many other cards. For example, with this card and a black lotus on turn one, you can add 4 mana, the equivalent of 4 moxen. On average, that means that this card is as good as two mox sapphires, even better than I said before. With four of these, you can play Jace, the Mind Sculptor for free. If that's not good, then what is? Also, lets say you have one of these, a Kiki-Jiki, and a sky hussar. BAM, that's 1,000,000 damage, right then and there. 5/5

249806: Island.author: Nikeyeia
249806: Island.text_parsed:
Seriously? They reprinted this?
It's like, woah! It taps for mana! COLORED mana! And you can have as many as you want in your deck? And it untaps, FOR FREE even?
Also, two of those combos with Storm Crow. Or Counterspell. Imagine that, only three cards to completely remove any spell? And seeing as you can have as many as you want in a deck, seven of those combos with Vizzerdrix. That's a win over only four turns!
Seriously, buy them! They're just that broken. Get your playset before the prices goes over the skies. With the power of this card, it'll become very hard to find someone to trade you them, since everyone wants it for themselves.
Trust me. This card is going to be among the best cards in almost all formats.

259016: Spawnwrithe.author: kiseki
259016: Spawnwrithe.text_parsed:
Equip it with gorgon flail. Now they need to block it with three creatures to stop the copy, and all of them will die. On second thought, lets just let it through each turn.
Next turn when they block the copy, cast a Lace with Moonglove on it.

The most fascinating thing about this card is that Wizards has not figured out how to make a token for it. Sure they could print a token with everything, including the casting cost, but then it would look like a magic card with a weird picture frame and be completely confusing!
259016: Spawnwrithe.text_posted:
